text: And every night, about midnight, I turned the latch of his door and opened it --oh so gently!

text: I moved it slowly --very, very slowly, so that I might not disturb the old man's sleep.

text: When we reflect how very rarely, from the nature of the case, we have it in our power to detect them, we must admit that they may frequently occur without our cognizance.
author: EAP

text: Scarcely, in truth, is a graveyard ever encroached upon, for any purpose, to any great extent, that skeletons are not found in postures which suggest the most fearful of suspicions.
author: EAP

text: Fearful indeed the suspicion -- but more fearful the doom!
author: EAP

text: It may be asserted, without hesitation, that no event is so terribly well adapted to inspire the supremeness of bodily and of mental distress, as is burial before death.
author: EAP

text: The unendurable oppression of the lungs -- the stifling fumes from the damp earth -- the clinging to the death garments -- the rigid embrace of the narrow house -- the blackness of the absolute Night -- the silence like a sea that overwhelms -- the unseen but palpable presence of the Conqueror Worm -- these things, with the thoughts of the air and grass above, with memory of dear friends who would fly to save us if but informed of our fate, and with consciousness that of this fate they can never be informed -- that our hopeless portion is that of the really dead -- these considerations, I say, carry into the heart, which still palpitates, a degree of appalling and intolerable horror from which the most daring imagination must recoil.
author: EAP

text: We know of nothing so agonizing upon Earth -- we can dream of nothing half so hideous in the realms of the nethermost Hell.
author: EAP

text: And thus all narratives upon this topic have an interest profound; an interest, nevertheless, which, through the sacred awe of the topic itself, very properly and very peculiarly depends upon our conviction of the truth of the matter narrated.
author: EAP

text: What I have now to tell is of my own actual knowledge -- of my own positive and personal experience.
author: EAP

text: For several years I had been subject to attacks of the singular disorder which physicians have agreed to term catalepsy, in default of a more definitive title.
author: EAP

text: Although both the immediate and the predisposing causes, and even the actual diagnosis, of this disease are still mysterious, its obvious and apparent character is sufficiently well understood.
author: EAP

text: Its variations seem to be chiefly of degree.
author: EAP

text: Sometimes the patient lies, for a day only, or even for a shorter period, in a species of exaggerated lethargy.
author: EAP

text: He is senseless and externally motionless; but the pulsation of the heart is still faintly perceptible; some traces of warmth remain; a slight color lingers within the centre of the cheek; and, upon application of a mirror to the lips, we can detect a torpid, unequal, and vacillating action of the lungs.
author: EAP

text: Then again the duration of the trance is for weeks -- even for months; while the closest scrutiny, and the most rigorous medical tests, fail to establish any material distinction between the state of the sufferer and what we conceive of absolute death.
author: EAP

text: Very usually he is saved from premature interment solely by the knowledge of his friends that he has been previously subject to catalepsy, by the consequent suspicion excited, and, above all, by the non-appearance of decay.
author: EAP

text: The advances of the malady are, luckily, gradual.
author: EAP

text: The first manifestations, although marked, are unequivocal.
author: EAP

text: The fits grow successively more and more distinctive, and endure each for a longer term than the preceding.
author: EAP

text: In this lies the principal security from inhumation.
author: EAP

text: The unfortunate whose first attack should be of the extreme character which is occasionally seen, would almost inevitably be consigned alive to the tomb.
author: EAP

text: My own case differed in no important particular from those mentioned in medical books.
author: EAP

text: Sometimes, without any apparent cause, I sank, little by little, into a condition of hemi-syncope, or half swoon; and, in this condition, without pain, without ability to stir, or, strictly speaking, to think, but with a dull lethargic consciousness of life and of the presence of those who surrounded my bed, I remained, until the crisis of the disease restored me, suddenly, to perfect sensation.
author: EAP

text: At other times I was quickly and impetuously smitten.
author: EAP

text: I grew sick, and numb, and chilly, and dizzy, and so fell prostrate at once.
author: EAP

text: Then, for weeks, all was void, and black, and silent, and Nothing became the universe.
author: EAP

text: Total annihilation could be no more.
author: EAP

text: From these latter attacks I awoke, however, with a gradation slow in proportion to the suddenness of the seizure.
author: EAP

text: Just as the day dawns to the friendless and houseless beggar who roams the streets throughout the long desolate winter night -- just so tardily -- just so wearily -- just so cheerily came back the light of the Soul to me.
author: EAP

text: Apart from the tendency to trance, however, my general health appeared to be good; nor could I perceive that it was at all affected by the one prevalent malady -- unless, indeed, an idiosyncrasy in my ordinary sleep may be looked upon as superinduced.
author: EAP

text: Upon awaking from slumber, I could never gain, at once, thorough possession of my senses, and always remained, for many minutes, in much bewilderment and perplexity; -- the mental faculties in general, but the memory in especial, being in a condition of absolute abeyance.
author: EAP

text: In all that I endured there was no physical suffering but of moral distress an infinitude.
author: EAP

text: My fancy grew charnel, I talked "of worms, of tombs, and epitaphs."
author: EAP

text: I was lost in reveries of death, and the idea of premature burial held continual possession of my brain.
author: EAP

text: The ghastly Danger to which I was subjected haunted me day and night.
author: EAP

text: In the former, the torture of meditation was excessive -- in the latter, supreme.
author: EAP

text: When the grim Darkness overspread the Earth, then, with every horror of thought, I shook -- shook as the quivering plumes upon the hearse.
author: EAP

text: When Nature could endure wakefulness no longer, it was with a struggle that I consented to sleep -- for I shuddered to reflect that, upon awaking, I might find myself the tenant of a grave.
author: EAP

text: And when, finally, I sank into slumber, it was only to rush at once into a world of phantasms, above which, with vast, sable, overshadowing wing, hovered, predominant, the one sepulchral Idea.
author: EAP

text: From the innumerable images of gloom which thus oppressed me in dreams, I select for record but a solitary vision.
author: EAP

text: Methought I was immersed in a cataleptic trance of more than usual duration and profundity.
author: EAP

text: Suddenly there came an icy hand upon my forehead, and an impatient, gibbering voice whispered the word "Arise!"
author: EAP

text: The darkness was total.
author: EAP

text: I could not see the figure of him who had aroused me.
author: EAP

text: I could call to mind neither the period at which I had fallen into the trance, nor the locality in which I then lay.
author: EAP

text: While I remained motionless, and busied in endeavors to collect my thought, the cold hand grasped me fiercely by the wrist, shaking it petulantly, while the gibbering voice said again: "Arise!
author: EAP

text: did I not bid thee arise?"
author: EAP

text: "And who," I demanded, "art thou?"
author: EAP

text: "I have no name in the regions which I inhabit," replied the voice, mournfully; "I was mortal, but am fiend.
author: EAP

text: I was merciless, but am pitiful.
author: EAP

text: Thou dost feel that I shudder.
author: EAP

text: -- My teeth chatter as I speak, yet it is not with the chilliness of the night -- of the night without end.
author: EAP

text: But this hideousness is insufferable.
author: EAP

text: How canst thou tranquilly sleep?
author: EAP

text: I cannot rest for the cry of these great agonies.
author: EAP

text: These sights are more than I can bear.
author: EAP

text: Come with me into the outer Night, and let me unfold to thee the graves.
author: EAP

text: Is not this a spectacle of woe?
author: EAP

text: I looked; and the unseen figure, which still grasped me by the wrist, had caused to be thrown open the graves of all mankind, and from each issued the faint phosphoric radiance of decay, so that I could see into the innermost recesses, and there view the shrouded bodies in their sad and solemn slumbers with the worm.
author: EAP

text: the real sleepers were fewer, by many millions, than those who slumbered not at all; and there was a feeble struggling; and there was a general sad unrest; and from out the depths of the countless pits there came a melancholy rustling from the garments of the buried.
author: EAP

text: And of those who seemed tranquilly to repose, I saw that a vast number had changed, in a greater or less degree, the rigid and uneasy position in which they had originally been entombed.
author: EAP

text: And the voice again said to me as I gazed: "Is it not -- oh!
author: EAP

text: is it not a pitiful sight?"
author: EAP

text: -- but, before I could find words to reply, the figure had ceased to grasp my wrist, the phosphoric lights expired, and the graves were closed with a sudden violence, while from out them arose a tumult of despairing cries, saying again: "Is it not -- O, God, is it not a very pitiful sight?"
author: EAP

text: Phantasies such as these, presenting themselves at night, extended their terrific influence far into my waking hours.
author: EAP

text: My nerves became thoroughly unstrung, and I fell a prey to perpetual horror.
author: EAP

text: I hesitated to ride, or to walk, or to indulge in any exercise that would carry me from home.
author: EAP

text: In fact, I no longer dared trust myself out of the immediate presence of those who were aware of my proneness to catalepsy, lest, falling into one of my usual fits, I should be buried before my real condition could be ascertained.
author: EAP

text: I doubted the care, the fidelity of my dearest friends.
author: EAP

text: I dreaded that, in some trance of more than customary duration, they might be prevailed upon to regard me as irrecoverable.
author: EAP

text: I even went so far as to fear that, as I occasioned much trouble, they might be glad to consider any very protracted attack as sufficient excuse for getting rid of me altogether.
author: EAP

text: It was in vain they endeavored to reassure me by the most solemn promises.
author: EAP

text: I exacted the most sacred oaths, that under no circumstances they would bury me until decomposition had so materially advanced as to render farther preservation impossible.
author: EAP

text: And, even then, my mortal terrors would listen to no reason -- would accept no consolation.
author: EAP

text: I entered into a series of elaborate precautions.
author: EAP

text: Among other things, I had the family vault so remodelled as to admit of being readily opened from within.
author: EAP

text: The slightest pressure upon a long lever that extended far into the tomb would cause the iron portal to fly back.
author: EAP

text: There were arrangements also for the free admission of air and light, and convenient receptacles for food and water, within immediate reach of the coffin intended for my reception.
author: EAP

text: This coffin was warmly and softly padded, and was provided with a lid, fashioned upon the principle of the vault-door, with the addition of springs so contrived that the feeblest movement of the body would be sufficient to set it at liberty.
author: EAP

text: Besides all this, there was suspended from the roof of the tomb, a large bell, the rope of which, it was designed, should extend through a hole in the coffin, and so be fastened to one of the hands of the corpse.
author: EAP

text: what avails the vigilance against the Destiny of man?
author: EAP

text: Not even these well-contrived securities sufficed to save from the uttermost agonies of living inhumation, a wretch to these agonies foredoomed!
author: EAP

text: There arrived an epoch -- as often before there had arrived -- in which I found myself emerging from total unconsciousness into the first feeble and indefinite sense of existence.
author: EAP

text: Slowly -- with a tortoise gradation -- approached the faint gray dawn of the psychal day.
author: EAP

text: An apathetic endurance of dull pain.
author: EAP

text: No care -- no hope -- no effort.
author: EAP

text: Then, after a long interval, a ringing in the ears; then, after a lapse still longer, a prickling or tingling sensation in the extremities; then a seemingly eternal period of pleasurable quiescence, during which the awakening feelings are struggling into thought; then a brief re-sinking into non-entity; then a sudden recovery.
author: EAP

text: At length the slight quivering of an eyelid, and immediately thereupon, an electric shock of a terror, deadly and indefinite, which sends the blood in torrents from the temples to the heart.
author: EAP

text: And now the first positive effort to think.
author: EAP

text: And now the first endeavor to remember.
author: EAP

text: And now a partial and evanescent success.
author: EAP

text: And now the memory has so far regained its dominion, that, in some measure, I am cognizant of my state.
author: EAP

text: I feel that I am not awaking from ordinary sleep.
author: EAP

text: I recollect that I have been subject to catalepsy.
author: EAP

text: And now, at last, as if by the rush of an ocean, my shuddering spirit is overwhelmed by the one grim Danger -- by the one spectral and ever-prevalent idea.
author: EAP

text: For some minutes after this fancy possessed me, I remained without motion.
author: EAP

text: I could not summon courage to move.
author: EAP

text: I dared not make the effort which was to satisfy me of my fate -- and yet there was something at my heart which whispered me it was sure.
author: EAP

text: Despair -- such as no other species of wretchedness ever calls into being -- despair alone urged me, after long irresolution, to uplift the heavy lids of my eyes.
author: EAP

text: It was dark -- all dark.
author: EAP

text: I knew that the fit was over.
author: EAP

text: I knew that the crisis of my disorder had long passed.
author: EAP

text: I knew that I had now fully recovered the use of my visual faculties -- and yet it was dark -- all dark -- the intense and utter raylessness of the Night that endureth for evermore.
author: EAP

text: I endeavored to shriek-, and my lips and my parched tongue moved convulsively together in the attempt -- but no voice issued from the cavernous lungs, which oppressed as if by the weight of some incumbent mountain, gasped and palpitated, with the heart, at every elaborate and struggling inspiration.
author: EAP

text: The movement of the jaws, in this effort to cry aloud, showed me that they were bound up, as is usual with the dead.
author: EAP

text: I felt, too, that I lay upon some hard substance, and by something similar my sides were, also, closely compressed.
author: EAP

text: So far, I had not ventured to stir any of my limbs -- but now I violently threw up my arms, which had been lying at length, with the wrists crossed.
author: EAP

text: They struck a solid wooden substance, which extended above my person at an elevation of not more than six inches from my face.
author: EAP

text: I could no longer doubt that I reposed within a coffin at last.
author: EAP

text: And now, amid all my infinite miseries, came sweetly the cherub Hope -- for I thought of my precautions.
author: EAP

text: I writhed, and made spasmodic exertions to force open the lid: it would not move.
author: EAP

text: I felt my wrists for the bell-rope: it was not to be found.
author: EAP

text: And now the Comforter fled for ever, and a still sterner Despair reigned triumphant; for I could not help perceiving the absence of the paddings which I had so carefully prepared -- and then, too, there came suddenly to my nostrils the strong peculiar odor of moist earth.
author: EAP

text: The conclusion was irresistible.
author: EAP

text: I was not within the vault.
author: EAP

text: I had fallen into a trance while absent from home-while among strangers -- when, or how, I could not remember -- and it was they who had buried me as a dog -- nailed up in some common coffin -- and thrust deep, deep, and for ever, into some ordinary and nameless grave.
author: EAP

text: As this awful conviction forced itself, thus, into the innermost chambers of my soul, I once again struggled to cry aloud.
author: EAP

text: And in this second endeavor I succeeded.
author: EAP

text: A long, wild, and continuous shriek, or yell of agony, resounded through the realms of the subterranean Night.
author: EAP

text: said a gruff voice, in reply.
author: EAP

text: "What the devil's the matter now!"
author: EAP

text: "Get out o' that!"
author: EAP

text: "What do you mean by yowling in that ere kind of style, like a cattymount?"
author: EAP

text: said a fourth; and hereupon I was seized and shaken without ceremony, for several minutes, by a junto of very rough-looking individuals.
author: EAP

text: They did not arouse me from my slumber -- for I was wide awake when I screamed -- but they restored me to the full possession of my memory.
author: EAP

text: This adventure occurred near Richmond, in Virginia.
author: EAP

text: Accompanied by a friend, I had proceeded, upon a gunning expedition, some miles down the banks of the James River.
author: EAP

text: Night approached, and we were overtaken by a storm.
author: EAP

text: The cabin of a small sloop lying at anchor in the stream, and laden with garden mould, afforded us the only available shelter.
author: EAP

text: We made the best of it, and passed the night on board.
author: EAP

text: I slept in one of the only two berths in the vessel -- and the berths of a sloop of sixty or twenty tons need scarcely be described.
author: EAP

text: That which I occupied had no bedding of any kind.
author: EAP

text: Its extreme width was eighteen inches.
author: EAP

text: The distance of its bottom from the deck overhead was precisely the same.
author: EAP

text: I found it a matter of exceeding difficulty to squeeze myself in.
author: EAP

text: Nevertheless, I slept soundly, and the whole of my vision -- for it was no dream, and no nightmare -- arose naturally from the circumstances of my position -- from my ordinary bias of thought -- and from the difficulty, to which I have alluded, of collecting my senses, and especially of regaining my memory, for a long time after awaking from slumber.
author: EAP

text: The men who shook me were the crew of the sloop, and some laborers engaged to unload it.
author: EAP

text: From the load itself came the earthly smell.
author: EAP

text: The bandage about the jaws was a silk handkerchief in which I had bound up my head, in default of my customary nightcap.
author: EAP

text: The tortures endured, however, were indubitably quite equal for the time, to those of actual sepulture.
author: EAP

text: They were fearfully -- they were inconceivably hideous; but out of Evil proceeded Good; for their very excess wrought in my spirit an inevitable revulsion.
author: EAP

text: My soul acquired tone -- acquired temper.
author: EAP

text: I took vigorous exercise.
author: EAP

text: I breathed the free air of Heaven.
author: EAP

text: I thought upon other subjects than Death.
author: EAP

text: I discarded my medical books.
author: EAP

text: I read no "Night Thoughts" -- no fustian about churchyards -- no bugaboo tales -- such as this.
author: EAP

text: In short, I became a new man, and lived a man's life.
author: EAP

text: From that memorable night, I dismissed forever my charnel apprehensions, and with them vanished the cataleptic disorder, of which, perhaps, they had been less the consequence than the cause.
author: EAP

text: There are moments when, even to the sober eye of Reason, the world of our sad Humanity may assume the semblance of a Hell -- but the imagination of man is no Carathis, to explore with impunity its every cavern.
author: EAP

text: the grim legion of sepulchral terrors cannot be regarded as altogether fanciful -- but, like the Demons in whose company Afrasiab made his voyage down the Oxus, they must sleep, or they will devour us -- they must be suffered to slumber, or we perish.
author: EAP

text: THE mental features discoursed of as the analytical, are, in themselves, but little susceptible of analysis.
author: EAP

text: We appreciate them only in their effects.
author: EAP

text: We know of them, among other things, that they are always to their possessor, when inordinately possessed, a source of the liveliest enjoyment.
author: EAP

text: As the strong man exults in his physical ability, delighting in such exercises as call his muscles into action, so glories the analyst in that moral activity which disentangles.
author: EAP

text: He derives pleasure from even the most trivial occupations bringing his talent into play.
author: EAP

text: He is fond of enigmas, of conundrums, of hieroglyphics; exhibiting in his solutions of each a degree of acumen which appears to the ordinary apprehension prï¿½ternatural.
author: EAP

text: His results, brought about by the very soul and essence of method, have, in truth, the whole air of intuition.
author: EAP

text: The faculty of re-solution is possibly much invigorated by mathematical study, and especially by that highest branch of it which, unjustly, and merely on account of its retrograde operations, has been called, as if par excellence, analysis.
author: EAP

text: Yet to calculate is not in itself to analyse.
author: EAP

text: A chess-player, for example, does the one without effort at the other.
author: EAP

text: It follows that the game of chess, in its effects upon mental character, is greatly misunderstood.
author: EAP

text: I am not now writing a treatise, but simply prefacing a somewhat peculiar narrative by observations very much at random; I will, therefore, take occasion to assert that the higher powers of the reflective intellect are more decidedly and more usefully tasked by the unostentatious game of draughts than by all the elaborate frivolity of chess.
author: EAP

text: In this latter, where the pieces have different and bizarre motions, with various and variable values, what is only complex is mistaken (a not unusual error) for what is profound.
author: EAP

text: The attention is here called powerfully into play.
author: EAP

text: If it flag for an instant, an oversight is committed, resulting in injury or defeat.
author: EAP

text: The possible moves being not only manifold but involute, the chances of such oversights are multiplied; and in nine cases out of ten it is the more concentrative rather than the more acute player who conquers.
author: EAP

text: In draughts, on the contrary, where the moves are unique and have but little variation, the probabilities of inadvertence are diminished, and the mere attention being left comparatively unemployed, what advantages are obtained by either party are obtained by superior acumen.
author: EAP

text: To be less abstract --Let us suppose a game of draughts where the pieces are reduced to four kings, and where, of course, no oversight is to be expected.
author: EAP

text: It is obvious that here the victory can be decided (the players being at all equal) only by some recherche movement, the result of some strong exertion of the intellect.
author: EAP

text: Deprived of ordinary resources, the analyst throws himself into the spirit of his opponent, identifies himself therewith, and not unfrequently sees thus, at a glance, the sole methods (sometimes indeed absurdly simple ones) by which he may seduce into error or hurry into miscalculation.
author: EAP

text: Whist has long been noted for its influence upon what is termed the calculating power; and men of the highest order of intellect have been known to take an apparently unaccountable delight in it, while eschewing chess as frivolous.
author: EAP

text: Beyond doubt there is nothing of a similar nature so greatly tasking the faculty of analysis.
author: EAP

text: The best chess-player in Christendom may be little more than the best player of chess; but proficiency in whist implies capacity for success in all those more important undertakings where mind struggles with mind.
author: EAP

text: When I say proficiency, I mean that perfection in the game which includes a comprehension of all the sources whence legitimate advantage may be derived.
author: EAP

text: These are not only manifold but multiform, and lie frequently among recesses of thought altogether inaccessible to the ordinary understanding.
author: EAP

text: To observe attentively is to remember distinctly; and, so far, the concentrative chess-player will do very well at whist; while the rules of Hoyle (themselves based upon the mere mechanism of the game) are sufficiently and generally comprehensible.
author: EAP

text: Thus to have a retentive memory, and to proceed by "the book," are points commonly regarded as the sum total of good playing.
author: EAP

text: But it is in matters beyond the limits of mere rule that the skill of the analyst is evinced.
author: EAP

text: He makes, in silence, a host of observations and inferences.
author: EAP

text: So, perhaps, do his companions; and the difference in the extent of the information obtained, lies not so much in the validity of the inference as in the quality of the observation.
author: EAP

text: The necessary knowledge is that of what to observe.
author: EAP

text: Our player confines himself not at all; nor, because the game is the object, does he reject deductions from things external to the game.
author: EAP

text: He examines the countenance of his partner, comparing it carefully with that of each of his opponents.
author: EAP

text: He considers the mode of assorting the cards in each hand; often counting trump by trump, and honor by honor, through the glances bestowed by their holders upon each.
author: EAP

text: He notes every variation of face as the play progresses, gathering a fund of thought from the differences in the expression of certainty, of surprise, of triumph, or of chagrin.
author: EAP

text: From the manner of gathering up a trick he judges whether the person taking it can make another in the suit.
author: EAP

text: He recognises what is played through feint, by the air with which it is thrown upon the table.
author: EAP

text: A casual or inadvertent word; the accidental dropping or turning of a card, with the accompanying anxiety or carelessness in regard to its concealment; the counting of the tricks, with the order of their arrangement; embarrassment, hesitation, eagerness or trepidation --all afford, to his apparently intuitive perception, indications of the true state of affairs.
author: EAP

text: The first two or three rounds having been played, he is in full possession of the contents of each hand, and thenceforward puts down his cards with as absolute a precision of purpose as if the rest of the party had turned outward the faces of their own.
author: EAP

text: The analytical power should not be confounded with simple ingenuity; for while the analyst is necessarily ingenious, the ingenious man is often remarkably incapable of analysis.
author: EAP

text: The constructive or combining power, by which ingenuity is usually manifested, and to which the phrenologists (I believe erroneously) have assigned a separate organ, supposing it a primitive faculty, has been so frequently seen in those whose intellect bordered otherwise upon idiocy, as to have attracted general observation among writers on morals.
author: EAP

text: Between ingenuity and the analytic ability there exists a difference far greater, indeed, than that between the fancy and the imagination, but of a character very strictly analogous.
author: EAP

text: It will be found, in fact, that the ingenious are always fanciful, and the truly imaginative never otherwise than analytic.
author: EAP

text: Residing in Paris during the spring and part of the summer of 18--, I there became acquainted with a Monsieur C. Auguste Dupin.
author: EAP

text: This young gentleman was of an excellent -- indeed of an illustrious family, but, by a variety of untoward events, had been reduced to such poverty that the energy of his character succumbed beneath it, and he ceased to bestir himself in the world, or to care for the retrieval of his fortunes.
author: EAP

text: By courtesy of his creditors, there still remained in his possession a small remnant of his patrimony; and, upon the income arising from this, he managed, by means of a rigorous economy, to procure the necessaries of life, without troubling himself about its superfluities.
author: EAP

text: Books, indeed, were his sole luxuries, and in Paris these are easily obtained.
author: EAP

text: Our first meeting was at an obscure library in the Rue Montmartre, where the accident of our both being in search of the same very rare and very remarkable volume, brought us into closer communion.
author: EAP

text: We saw each other again and again.
author: EAP

text: I was deeply interested in the little family history which he detailed to me with all that candor which a Frenchman indulges whenever mere self is his theme.
author: EAP

text: I was astonished, too, at the vast extent of his reading; and, above all, I felt my soul enkindled within me by the wild fervor, and the vivid freshness of his imagination.
author: EAP

text: Seeking in Paris the objects I then sought, I felt that the society of such a man would be to me a treasure beyond price; and this feeling I frankly confided to him.
author: EAP

text: It was at length arranged that we should live together during my stay in the city; and as my worldly circumstances were somewhat less embarrassed than his own, I was permitted to be at the expense of renting, and furnishing in a style which suited the rather fantastic gloom of our common temper, a time-eaten and grotesque mansion, long deserted through superstitions into which we did not inquire, and tottering to its fall in a retired and desolate portion of the Faubourg St. Germain.
author: EAP

text: Had the routine of our life at this place been known to the world, we should have been regarded as madmen --although, perhaps, as madmen of a harmless nature.
author: EAP

text: Our seclusion was perfect.
author: EAP

text: We admitted no visitors.
author: EAP

text: Indeed the locality of our retirement had been carefully kept a secret from my own former associates; and it had been many years since Dupin had ceased to know or be known in Paris.
author: EAP

text: We existed within ourselves alone.
author: EAP

text: At such times I could not help remarking and admiring (although from his rich ideality I had been prepared to expect it) a peculiar analytic ability in Dupin.
author: EAP

text: He seemed, too, to take an eager delight in its exercise --if not exactly in its display --and did not hesitate to confess the pleasure thus derived.
author: EAP

text: He boasted to me, with a low chuckling laugh, that most men, in respect to himself, wore windows in their bosoms, and was wont to follow up such assertions by direct and very startling proofs of his intimate knowledge of my own.
author: EAP

text: His manner at these moments was frigid and abstract; his eyes were vacant in expression; while his voice, usually a rich tenor, rose into a treble which would have sounded petulantly but for the deliberateness and entire distinctness of the enunciation.
author: EAP

text: Observing him in these moods, I often dwelt meditatively upon the old philosophy of the Bi-Part Soul, and amused myself with the fancy of a double Dupin --the creative and the resolvent.
author: EAP

text: Let it not be supposed, from what I have just said, that I am detailing any mystery, or penning any romance.

text: What I have described in the Frenchman, was merely the result of an excited, or perhaps of a diseased intelligence.

text: We were strolling one night down a long dirty street, in the vicinity of the Palais Royal.

author: EAP

text: In an instant afterward I recollected myself, and my astonishment was profound.
author: EAP

text: As we crossed into this street, a fruiterer, with a large basket upon his head, brushing quickly past us, thrust you upon a pile of paving-stones collected at a spot where the causeway is undergoing repair.

text: You stepped upon one of the loose fragments, slipped, slightly strained your ankle, appeared vexed or sulky, muttered a few words, turned to look at the pile, and then proceeded in silence.

author: EAP

text: "You kept your eyes upon the ground --glancing, with a petulant expression, at the holes and ruts in the pavement, (so that I saw you were still thinking of the stones,) until we reached the little alley called Lamartine, which has been paved, by way of experiment, with the overlapping and riveted blocks.
author: EAP

text: Here your countenance brightened up, and, perceiving your lips move, I could not doubt that you murmured the word 'stereotomy,' a term very affectedly applied to this species of pavement.
author: EAP

text: I knew that you could not say to yourself 'stereotomy' without being brought to think of atomies, and thus of the theories of Epicurus; and since, when we discussed this subject not very long ago, I mentioned to you how singularly, yet with how little notice, the vague guesses of that noble Greek had met with confirmation in the late nebular cosmogony, I felt that you could not avoid casting your eyes upward to the great nebula in Orion, and I certainly expected that you would do so.
author: EAP

text: You did look up; and I was now assured that I had correctly followed your steps.
author: EAP

text: But in that bitter tirade upon Chantilly, which appeared in yesterday's 'Musï¿½e,' the satirist, making some disgraceful allusions to the cobbler's change of name upon assuming the buskin, quoted a Latin line about which we have often conversed.

text: --This morning, about three o'clock, the inhabitants of the Quartier St. Roch were aroused from sleep by a succession of terrific shrieks, issuing, apparently, from the fourth story of a house in the Rue Morgue, known to be in the sole occupancy of one Madame L'Espanaye, and her daughter, Mademoiselle Camille L'Espanaye.

text: Vidocq, for example, was a good guesser, and a persevering man.

text: But, without educated thought, he erred continually by the very intensity of his investigations.
author: EAP

text: He impaired his vision by holding the object too close.
author: EAP

text: He might see, perhaps, one or two points with unusual clearness, but in so doing he, necessarily, lost sight of the matter as a whole.
author: EAP

text: Thus there is such a thing as being too profound.
author: EAP

text: Truth is not always in a well.
author: EAP

text: In fact, as regards the more important knowledge, I do believe that she is invariably superficial.
author: EAP

text: The depth lies in the valleys where we seek her, and not upon the mountain-tops where she is found.
author: EAP

text: The modes and sources of this kind of error are well typified in the contemplation of the heavenly bodies.
author: EAP

text: To look at a star by glances --to view it in a side-long way, by turning toward it the exterior portions of the retina (more susceptible of feeble impressions of light than the interior), is to behold the star distinctly -- is to have the best appreciation of its lustre --a lustre which grows dim just in proportion as we turn our vision fully upon it.
author: EAP

text: A greater number of rays actually fall upon the eye in the latter case, but, in the former, there is the more refined capacity for comprehension.
author: EAP

text: By undue profundity we perplex and enfeeble thought; and it is possible to make even Venus herself vanish from the firmanent by a scrutiny too sustained, too concentrated, or too direct.
author: EAP

text: "As for these murders, let us enter into some examinations for ourselves, before we make up an opinion respecting them.
author: EAP

text: An inquiry will afford us amusement," (I thought this an odd term, so applied, but said nothing) "and, besides, Le Bon once rendered me a service for which I am not ungrateful.
author: EAP

text: We will go and see the premises with our own eyes.
author: EAP

text: I know G___, the Prefect of Police, and shall have no difficulty in obtaining the necessary permission."
author: EAP

text: The permission was obtained, and we proceeded at once to the Rue Morgue.
author: EAP

text: This is one of those miserable thoroughfares which intervene between the Rue Richelieu and the Rue St. Roch.
author: EAP

text: It was late in the afternoon when we reached it; as this quarter is at a great distance from that in which we resided.
author: EAP

text: The house was readily found; for there were still many persons gazing up at the closed shutters, with an objectless curiosity, from the opposite side of the way.
author: EAP

text: It was an ordinary Parisian house, with a gateway, on one side of which was a glazed watch-box, with a sliding panel in the window, indicating a loge de concierge.
author: EAP

text: Before going in we walked up the street, turned down an alley, and then, again turning, passed in the rear of the building --Dupin, meanwhile, examining the whole neighborhood, as well as the house, with a minuteness of attention for which I could see no possible object.
author: EAP

text: Retracing our steps, we came again to the front of the dwelling, rang, and, having shown our credentials, were admitted by the agents in charge.
author: EAP

text: We went up stairs --into the chamber where the body of Mademoiselle L'Espanaye had been found, and where both the deceased still lay.
author: EAP

text: The disorders of the room had, as usual, been suffered to exist.
author: EAP

text: I saw nothing beyond what had been stated in the "Gazette des Tribunaux."
author: EAP

text: Dupin scrutinized every thing --not excepting the bodies of the victims.
author: EAP

text: We then went into the other rooms, and into the yard; a gendarme accompanying us throughout.
author: EAP

text: The examination occupied us until dark, when we took our departure.
author: EAP

text: On our way home my companion stepped in for a moment at the office of one of the daily papers.
author: EAP

text: I have said that the whims of my friend were manifold, and that Je les mï¿½nagais: --for this phrase there is no English equivalent.
author: EAP

text: It was his humor, now, to decline all conversation on the subject of the murder, until about noon the next day.
author: EAP

text: He then asked me, suddenly, if I had observed any thing peculiar at the scene of the atrocity.
author: EAP

text: There was something in his manner of emphasizing the word "peculiar," which caused me to shudder, without knowing why.
author: EAP

text: "No, nothing peculiar," I said; "nothing more, at least, than we both saw stated in the paper."
author: EAP

text: "The 'Gazette,' " he replied, "has not entered, I fear, into the unusual horror of the thing.
author: EAP

text: But dismiss the idle opinions of this print.
author: EAP

text: It appears to me that this mystery is considered insoluble, for the very reason which should cause it to be regarded as easy of solution --I mean for the outrï¿½ character of its features.
author: EAP

text: The police are confounded by the seeming absence of motive --not for the murder itself --but for the atrocity of the murder.
author: EAP

text: They are puzzled, too, by the seeming impossibility of reconciling the voices heard in contention, with the facts that no one was discovered up stairs but the assassinated Mademoiselle L'Espanaye, and that there were no means of egress without the notice of the party ascending.
author: EAP

text: The wild disorder of the room; the corpse thrust, with the head downward, up the chimney; the frightful mutilation of the body of the old lady; these considerations, with those just mentioned, and others which I need not mention, have sufficed to paralyze the powers, by putting completely at fault the boasted acumen, of the government agents.
author: EAP

text: They have fallen into the gross but common error of confounding the unusual with the abstruse.
author: EAP

text: But it is by these deviations from the plane of the ordinary, that reason feels its way, if at all, in its search for the true.
author: EAP

text: In investigations such as we are now pursuing, it should not be so much asked 'what has occurred,' as 'what has occurred that has never occurred before.'
author: EAP

text: In fact, the facility with which I shall arrive, or have arrived, at the solution of this mystery, is in the direct ratio of its apparent insolubility in the eyes of the police."
author: EAP

text: I stared at the speaker in mute astonishment.
author: EAP

text: "I am now awaiting," continued he, looking toward the door of our apartment --"I am now awaiting a person who, although perhaps not the perpetrator of these butcheries, must have been in some measure implicated in their perpetration.
author: EAP

text: Of the worst portion of the crimes committed, it is probable that he is innocent.
author: EAP

text: I hope that I am right in this supposition; for upon it I build my expectation of reading the entire riddle.
author: EAP

text: I look for the man here --in this room --every moment.
author: EAP

text: It is true that he may not arrive; but the probability is that he will.
author: EAP

text: Should he come, it will be necessary to detain him.
author: EAP

text: Here are pistols; and we both know how to use them when occasion demands their use."
author: EAP

text: I took the pistols, scarcely knowing what I did, or believing what I heard, while Dupin went on, very much as if in a soliloquy.
author: EAP

text: I have already spoken of his abstract manner at such times.
author: EAP

text: His discourse was addressed to myself; but his voice, although by no means loud, had that intonation which is commonly employed in speaking to some one at a great distance.
author: EAP

text: His eyes, vacant in expression, regarded only the wall.
author: EAP

text: "That the voices heard in contention," he said, "by the party upon the stairs, were not the voices of the women themselves, was fully proved by the evidence.
author: EAP

text: This relieves us of all doubt upon the question whether the old lady could have first destroyed the daughter, and afterward have committed suicide.
author: EAP

text: I speak of this point chiefly for the sake of method; for the strength of Madame L'Espanaye would have been utterly unequal to the task of thrusting her daughter's corpse up the chimney as it was found; and the nature of the wounds upon her own person entirely preclude the idea of self-destruction.
author: EAP

text: Murder, then, has been committed by some third party; and the voices of this third party were those heard in contention.
author: EAP

text: Let me now advert --not to the whole testimony respecting these voices --but to what was peculiar in that testimony.
author: EAP

text: Did you observe any thing peculiar about it?"
author: EAP

text: I remarked that, while all the witnesses agreed in supposing the gruff voice to be that of a Frenchman, there was much disagreement in regard to the shrill, or, as one individual termed it, the harsh voice.
author: EAP

text: "That was the evidence itself," said Dupin, "but it was not the peculiarity of the evidence.
author: EAP

text: You have observed nothing distinctive.
author: EAP

text: Yet there was something to be observed.
author: EAP

text: The witnesses, as you remark, agreed about the gruff voice; they were here unanimous.
author: EAP

text: But in regard to the shrill voice, the peculiarity is --not that they disagreed --but that, while an Italian, an Englishman, a Spaniard, a Hollander, and a Frenchman attempted to describe it, each one spoke of it as that of a foreigner.
author: EAP

text: Each is sure that it was not the voice of one of his own countrymen.
author: EAP

text: Each likens it --not to the voice of an individual of any nation with whose language he is conversant --but the converse.
author: EAP

text: The Frenchman supposes it the voice of a Spaniard, and 'might have distinguished some words had he been acquainted with the Spanish.'
author: EAP

text: The Dutchman maintains it to have been that of a Frenchman; but we find it stated that 'not understanding French this witness was examined through an interpreter.'
author: EAP

text: The Englishman thinks it the voice of a German, and 'does not understand German.'
author: EAP

text: The Spaniard 'is sure' that it was that of an Englishman, but 'judges by the intonation' altogether, 'as he has no knowledge of the English.'
author: EAP

text: The Italian believes it the voice of a Russian, but 'has never conversed with a native of Russia.'
author: EAP

text: A second Frenchman differs, moreover, with the first, and is positive that the voice was that of an Italian; but, not being cognizant of that tongue, is, like the Spaniard, 'convinced by the intonation.'
author: EAP

text: Now, how strangely unusual must that voice have really been, about which such testimony as this could have been elicited!
author: EAP

text: --in whose tones, even, denizens of the five great divisions of Europe could recognise nothing familiar!
author: EAP

text: You will say that it might have been the voice of an Asiatic --of an African.
author: EAP

text: Neither Asiatics nor Africans abound in Paris; but, without denying the inference, I will now merely call your attention to three points.
author: EAP

text: The voice is termed by one witness 'harsh rather than shrill.'
author: EAP

text: It is represented by two others to have been 'quick and unequal.'
author: EAP

text: No words --no sounds resembling words --were by any witness mentioned as distinguishable.
author: EAP

text: "I know not," continued Dupin, "what impression I may have made, so far, upon your own understanding; but I do not hesitate to say that legitimate deductions even from this portion of the testimony --the portion respecting the gruff and shrill voices --are in themselves sufficient to engender a suspicion which should give direction to all farther progress in the investigation of the mystery.
author: EAP

text: I said 'legitimate deductions;' but my meaning is not thus fully expressed.
author: EAP

text: I designed to imply that the deductions are the sole proper ones, and that the suspicion arises inevitably from them as the single result.
author: EAP

text: What the suspicion is, however, I will not say just yet.
author: EAP

text: I merely wish you to bear in mind that, with myself, it was sufficiently forcible to give a definite form --a certain tendency --to my inquiries in the chamber.
author: EAP

text: "Let us now transport ourselves, in fancy, to this chamber.
author: EAP

text: What shall we first seek here?
author: EAP

text: The means of egress employed by the murderers.
author: EAP

text: It is not too much to say that neither of us believe in praeternatural events.
author: EAP

text: Madame and Mademoiselle L'Espanaye were not destroyed by spirits.
author: EAP

text: The doers of the deed were material, and escaped materially.
author: EAP

text: Fortunately, there is but one mode of reasoning upon the point, and that mode must lead us to a definite decision.
author: EAP

text: --Let us examine, each by each, the possible means of egress.
author: EAP

text: It is clear that the assassins were in the room where Mademoiselle L'Espanaye was found, or at least in the room adjoining, when the party ascended the stairs.
author: EAP

text: It is then only from these two apartments that we have to seek issues.
author: EAP

text: The police have laid bare the floors, the ceilings, and the masonry of the walls, in every direction.
author: EAP

text: No secret issues could have escaped their vigilance.
author: EAP

text: But, not trusting to their eyes, I examined with my own.
author: EAP

text: There were, then, no secret issues.
author: EAP

text: Both doors leading from the rooms into the passage were securely locked, with the keys inside.
author: EAP

text: Let us turn to the chimneys.
author: EAP

text: These, although of ordinary width for some eight or ten feet above the hearths, will not admit, throughout their extent, the body of a large cat.
author: EAP

text: The impossibility of egress, by means already stated, being thus absolute, we are reduced to the windows.
author: EAP

text: Through those of the front room no one could have escaped without notice from the crowd in the street.
author: EAP

text: The murderers must have passed, then, through those of the back room.
author: EAP

text: Now, brought to this conclusion in so unequivocal a manner as we are, it is not our part, as reasoners, to reject it on account of apparent impossibilities.
author: EAP

text: It is only left for us to prove that these apparent 'impossibilities' are, in reality, not such.
author: EAP

text: "There are two windows in the chamber.
author: EAP

text: One of them is unobstructed by furniture, and is wholly visible.
author: EAP

text: The lower portion of the other is hidden from view by the head of the unwieldy bedstead which is thrust close up against it.
author: EAP

text: The former was found securely fastened from within.
author: EAP

text: It resisted the utmost force of those who endeavored to raise it.
author: EAP

text: A large gimlet-hole had been pierced in its frame to the left, and a very stout nail was found fitted therein, nearly to the head.
author: EAP

text: Upon examining the other window, a similar nail was seen similarly fitted in it; and a vigorous attempt to raise this sash, failed also.
author: EAP

text: The police were now entirely satisfied that egress had not been in these directions.
author: EAP

text: And, therefore, it was thought a matter of supererogation to withdraw the nails and open the windows.
author: EAP

text: "My own examination was somewhat more particular, and was so for the reason I have just given --because here it was, I knew, that all apparent impossibilities must be proved to be not such in reality.
author: EAP

text: "I proceeded to think thus --ï¿½ posteriori.
author: EAP

text: The murderers did escape from one of these windows.
author: EAP

text: This being so, they could not have re-fastened the sashes from the inside, as they were found fastened; --the consideration which put a stop, through its obviousness, to the scrutiny of the police in this quarter.
author: EAP

text: Yet the sashes were fastened.
author: EAP

text: They must, then, have the power of fastening themselves.
author: EAP

text: There was no escape from this conclusion.
author: EAP

text: I stepped to the unobstructed casement, withdrew the nail with some difficulty, and attempted to raise the sash.
author: EAP

text: It resisted all my efforts, as I had anticipated.
author: EAP

text: A concealed spring must, I now knew, exist; and this corroboration of my idea convinced me that my premises, at least, were correct, however mysterious still appeared the circumstances attending the nails.
author: EAP

text: A careful search soon brought to light the hidden spring.
author: EAP

text: I pressed it, and, satisfied with the discovery, forbore to upraise the sash.
author: EAP

text: "I now replaced the nail and regarded it attentively.
author: EAP

text: A person passing out through this window might have reclosed it, and the spring would have caught --but the nail could not have been replaced.
author: EAP

text: The conclusion was plain, and again narrowed in the field of my investigations.
author: EAP

text: The assassins must have escaped through the other window.
author: EAP

text: Supposing, then, the springs upon each sash to be the same, as was probable, there must be found a difference between the nails, or at least between the modes of their fixture.
author: EAP

text: Getting upon the sacking of the bedstead, I looked over the head-board minutely at the second casement.
author: EAP

text: Passing my hand down behind the board, I readily discovered and pressed the spring, which was, as I had supposed, identical in character with its neighbor.
author: EAP

text: I now looked at the nail.
author: EAP

text: It was as stout as the other, and apparently fitted in the same manner --driven in nearly up to the head.
author: EAP

text: "You will say that I was puzzled; but, if you think so, you must have misunderstood the nature of the inductions.
author: EAP

text: To use a sporting phrase, I had not been once 'at fault.'
author: EAP

text: The scent had never for an instant been lost.
author: EAP

text: There was no flaw in any link of the chain.
author: EAP

text: I had traced the secret to its ultimate result, --and that result was the nail.
author: EAP

text: It had, I say, in every respect, the appearance of its fellow in the other window; but this fact was an absolute nullity (conclusive as it might seem to be) when compared with the consideration that here, at this point, terminated the clew.
author: EAP

text: 'There must be something wrong,' I said, 'about the nail.'
author: EAP

text: I touched it; and the head, with about a quarter of an inch of the shank, came off in my fingers.
author: EAP

text: The rest of the shank was in the gimlet-hole, where it had been broken off.
author: EAP

text: The fracture was an old one (for its edges were incrusted with rust), and had apparently been accomplished by the blow of a hammer, which had partially imbedded, in the top of the bottom sash, the head portion of the nail.
author: EAP

text: I now carefully replaced this head portion in the indentation whence I had taken it, and the resemblance to a perfect nail was complete -- the fissure was invisible.
author: EAP

text: Pressing the spring, I gently raised the sash for a few inches; the head went up with it, remaining firm in its bed.
author: EAP

text: I closed the window, and the semblance of the whole nail was again perfect.
author: EAP

text: "The riddle, so far, was now unriddled.
author: EAP

text: The assassin had escaped through the window which looked upon the bed.
author: EAP

text: Dropping of its own accord upon his exit (or perhaps purposely closed), it had become fastened by the spring; and it was the retention of this spring which had been mistaken by the police for that of the nail, --farther inquiry being thus considered unnecessary.
author: EAP

text: "The next question is that of the mode of descent.
author: EAP

text: Upon this point I had been satisfied in my walk with you around the building.
author: EAP

text: About five feet and a half from the casement in question there runs a lightning-rod.
author: EAP

text: From this rod it would have been impossible for any one to reach the window itself, to say nothing of entering it.
author: EAP

text: I observed, however, that the shutters of the fourth story were of the peculiar kind called by Parisian carpenters ferrades --a kind rarely employed at the present day, but frequently seen upon very old mansions at Lyons and Bourdeaux.
author: EAP

text: They are in the form of an ordinary door, (a single, not a folding door) except that the lower half is latticed or worked in open trellis --thus affording an excellent hold for the hands.
author: EAP

text: In the present instance these shutters are fully three feet and a half broad.
author: EAP

text: When we saw them from the rear of the house, they were both about half open --that is to say, they stood off at right angles from the wall.
author: EAP

text: It is probable that the police, as well as myself, examined the back of the tenement; but, if so, in looking at these ferrades in the line of their breadth (as they must have done), they did not perceive this great breadth itself, or, at all events, failed to take it into due consideration.
author: EAP

text: In fact, having once satisfied themselves that no egress could have been made in this quarter, they would naturally bestow here a very cursory examination.
author: EAP

text: It was clear to me, however, that the shutter belonging to the window at the head of the bed, would, if swung fully back to the wall, reach to within two feet of the lightning-rod.
author: EAP

text: It was also evident that, by exertion of a very unusual degree of activity and courage, an entrance into the window, from the rod, might have been thus effected.
author: EAP

text: --By reaching to the distance of two feet and a half (we now suppose the shutter open to its whole extent) a robber might have taken a firm grasp upon the trellis-work.
author: EAP

text: Letting go, then, his hold upon the rod, placing his feet securely against the wall, and springing boldly from it, he might have swung the shutter so as to close it, and, if we imagine the window open at the time, might even have swung himself into the room.
author: EAP

text: "I wish you to bear especially in mind that I have spoken of a very unusual degree of activity as requisite to success in so hazardous and so difficult a feat.
author: EAP

text: It is my design to show you, first, that the thing might possibly have been accomplished: --but, secondly and chiefly, I wish to impress upon your understanding the very extraordinary --the almost prï¿½ternatural character of that agility which could have accomplished it.
author: EAP

text: "You will say, no doubt, using the language of the law, that 'to make out my case,' I should rather undervalue, than insist upon a full estimation of the activity required in this matter.
author: EAP

text: This may be the practice in law, but it is not the usage of reason.
author: EAP

text: My ultimate object is only the truth.
author: EAP

text: My immediate purpose is to lead you to place in juxta-position, that very unusual activity of which I have just spoken, with that very peculiar shrill (or harsh) and unequal voice, about whose nationality no two persons could be found to agree, and in whose utterance no syllabification could be detected."
author: EAP

text: At these words a vague and half-formed conception of the meaning of Dupin flitted over my mind.
author: EAP

text: I seemed to be upon the verge of comprehension, without power to comprehend --as men, at times, find themselves upon the brink of remembrance, without being able, in the end, to remember.
author: EAP

text: My friend went on with his discourse.
author: EAP

text: "You will see," he said, "that I have shifted the question from the mode of egress to that of ingress.
author: EAP

text: It was my design to convey the idea that both were effected in the same manner, at the same point.
author: EAP

text: Let us now revert to the interior of the room.
author: EAP

text: Let us survey the appearances here.
author: EAP

text: The drawers of the bureau, it is said, had been rifled, although many articles of apparel still remained within them.
author: EAP

text: The conclusion here is absurd.
author: EAP

text: It is a mere guess --a very silly one --and no more.
author: EAP

text: How are we to know that the articles found in the drawers were not all these drawers had originally contained?
author: EAP

text: Madame L'Espanaye and her daughter lived an exceedingly retired life --saw no company --seldom went out --had little use for numerous changes of habiliment.
author: EAP

text: Those found were at least of as good quality as any likely to be possessed by these ladies.
author: EAP

text: If a thief had taken any, why did he not take the best --why did he not take all?
author: EAP

text: In a word, why did he abandon four thousand francs in gold to encumber himself with a bundle of linen?
author: EAP

text: The gold was abandoned.
author: EAP

text: Nearly the whole sum mentioned by Monsieur Mignaud, the banker, was discovered, in bags, upon the floor.
author: EAP

text: I wish you, therefore, to discard from your thoughts the blundering idea of motive, engendered in the brains of the police by that portion of the evidence which speaks of money delivered at the door of the house.
author: EAP

text: Coincidences ten times as remarkable as this (the delivery of the money, and murder committed within three days upon the party receiving it), happen to all of us every hour of our lives, without attracting even momentary notice.
author: EAP

text: Coincidences, in general, are great stumbling-blocks in the way of that class of thinkers who have been educated to know nothing of the theory of probabilities -- that theory to which the most glorious objects of human research are indebted for the most glorious of illustration.
author: EAP

text: In the present instance, had the gold been gone, the fact of its delivery three days before would have formed something more than a coincidence.
author: EAP

text: It would have been corroborative of this idea of motive.
author: EAP

text: But, under the real circumstances of the case, if we are to suppose gold the motive of this outrage, we must also imagine the perpetrator so vacillating an idiot as to have abandoned his gold and his motive together.
author: EAP

text: "Keeping now steadily in mind the points to which I have drawn your attention --that peculiar voice, that unusual agility, and that startling absence of motive in a murder so singularly atrocious as this --let us glance at the butchery itself.
author: EAP

text: Here is a woman strangled to death by manual strength, and thrust up a chimney, head downward.
author: EAP

text: Ordinary assassins employ no such modes of murder as this.
author: EAP

text: Least of all, do they thus dispose of the murdered.
author: EAP

text: In the manner of thrusting the corpse up the chimney, you will admit that there was something excessively outrï¿½ --something altogether irreconcilable with our common notions of human action, even when we suppose the actors the most depraved of men.
author: EAP

text: Think, too, how great must have been that strength which could have thrust the body up such an aperture so forcibly that the united vigor of several persons was found barely sufficient to drag it down!
author: EAP

text: "Turn, now, to other indications of the employment of a vigor most marvellous.
author: EAP

text: On the hearth were thick tresses --very thick tresses --of grey human hair.
author: EAP

text: These had been torn out by the roots.
author: EAP

text: You are aware of the great force necessary in tearing thus from the head even twenty or thirty hairs together.
author: EAP

text: You saw the locks in question as well as myself.
author: EAP

text: Their roots (a hideous sight!)
author: EAP

text: were clotted with fragments of the flesh of the scalp --sure token of the prodigious power which had been exerted in uprooting perhaps half a million of hairs at a time.
author: EAP

text: The throat of the old lady was not merely cut, but the head absolutely severed from the body: the instrument was a mere razor.
author: EAP

text: I wish you also to look at the brutal ferocity of these deeds.
author: EAP

text: Of the bruises upon the body of Madame L'Espanaye I do not speak.
author: EAP

text: Monsieur Dumas, and his worthy coadjutor Monsieur Etienne, have pronounced that they were inflicted by some obtuse instrument; and so far these gentlemen are very correct.
author: EAP

text: The obtuse instrument was clearly the stone pavement in the yard, upon which the victim had fallen from the window which looked in upon the bed.
author: EAP

text: This idea, however simple it may now seem, escaped the police for the same reason that the breadth of the shutters escaped them --because, by the affair of the nails, their perceptions had been hermetically sealed against the possibility of the windows having ever been opened at all.
author: EAP

text: "If now, in addition to all these things, you have properly reflected upon the odd disorder of the chamber, we have gone so far as to combine the ideas of an agility astounding, a strength superhuman, a ferocity brutal, a butchery without motive, a grotesquerie in horror absolutely alien from humanity, and a voice foreign in tone to the ears of men of many nations, and devoid of all distinct or intelligible syllabification.
author: EAP

text: What result, then, has ensued?
author: EAP

text: What impression have I made upon your fancy?"
author: EAP

text: I felt a creeping of the flesh as Dupin asked me the question.
author: EAP

text: "A madman," I said, "has done this deed --some raving maniac, escaped from a neighboring Maison de Santï¿½."
author: EAP

text: "In some respects," he replied, "your idea is not irrelevant.
author: EAP

text: But the voices of madmen, even in their wildest paroxysms, are never found to tally with that peculiar voice heard upon the stairs.
author: EAP

text: I AM come of a race noted for vigor of fancy and ardor of passion.
author: EAP

text: Men have called me mad; but the question is not yet settled, whether madness is or is not the loftiest intelligence -- whether much that is glorious- whether all that is profound -- does not spring from disease of thought -- from moods of mind exalted at the expense of the general intellect.
author: EAP

text: They who dream by day are cognizant of many things which escape those who dream only by night.
author: EAP

text: In their gray visions they obtain glimpses of eternity, and thrill, in awakening, to find that they have been upon the verge of the great secret.
author: EAP

text: In snatches, they learn something of the wisdom which is of good, and more of the mere knowledge which is of evil.
author: EAP

text: They penetrate, however, rudderless or compassless into the vast ocean of the "light ineffable," and again, like the adventures of the Nubian geographer, "agressi sunt mare tenebrarum, quid in eo esset exploraturi."

text: We will say, then, that I am mad.

text: I grant, at least, that there are two distinct conditions of my mental existence -- the condition of a lucid reason, not to be disputed, and belonging to the memory of events forming the first epoch of my life -- and a condition of shadow and doubt, appertaining to the present, and to the recollection of what constitutes the second great era of my being.
author: EAP

text: Therefore, what I shall tell of the earlier period, believe; and to what I may relate of the later time, give only such credit as may seem due, or doubt it altogether, or, if doubt it ye cannot, then play unto its riddle the Oedipus.
author: EAP

text: She whom I loved in youth, and of whom I now pen calmly and distinctly these remembrances, was the sole daughter of the only sister of my mother long departed.
author: EAP

text: Eleonora was the name of my cousin.
author: EAP

text: We had always dwelled together, beneath a tropical sun, in the Valley of the Many-Colored Grass.
author: EAP

text: No unguided footstep ever came upon that vale; for it lay away up among a range of giant hills that hung beetling around about it, shutting out the sunlight from its sweetest recesses.
author: EAP

text: No path was trodden in its vicinity; and, to reach our happy home, there was need of putting back, with force, the foliage of many thousands of forest trees, and of crushing to death the glories of many millions of fragrant flowers.
author: EAP

text: Thus it was that we lived all alone, knowing nothing of the world without the valley -- I, and my cousin, and her mother.
author: EAP

text: From the dim regions beyond the mountains at the upper end of our encircled domain, there crept out a narrow and deep river, brighter than all save the eyes of Eleonora; and, winding stealthily about in mazy courses, it passed away, at length, through a shadowy gorge, among hills still dimmer than those whence it had issued.
author: EAP

text: We called it the "River of Silence"; for there seemed to be a hushing influence in its flow.
author: EAP

text: No murmur arose from its bed, and so gently it wandered along, that the pearly pebbles upon which we loved to gaze, far down within its bosom, stirred not at all, but lay in a motionless content, each in its own old station, shining on gloriously forever.
author: EAP

text: The margin of the river, and of the many dazzling rivulets that glided through devious ways into its channel, as well as the spaces that extended from the margins away down into the depths of the streams until they reached the bed of pebbles at the bottom, -- these spots, not less than the whole surface of the valley, from the river to the mountains that girdled it in, were carpeted all by a soft green grass, thick, short, perfectly even, and vanilla-perfumed, but so besprinkled throughout with the yellow buttercup, the white daisy, the purple violet, and the ruby-red asphodel, that its exceeding beauty spoke to our hearts in loud tones, of the love and of the glory of God.
author: EAP

text: And, here and there, in groves about this grass, like wildernesses of dreams, sprang up fantastic trees, whose tall slender stems stood not upright, but slanted gracefully toward the light that peered at noon-day into the centre of the valley.
author: EAP

text: Their mark was speckled with the vivid alternate splendor of ebony and silver, and was smoother than all save the cheeks of Eleonora; so that, but for the brilliant green of the huge leaves that spread from their summits in long, tremulous lines, dallying with the Zephyrs, one might have fancied them giant serpents of Syria doing homage to their sovereign the Sun.
author: EAP

text: Hand in hand about this valley, for fifteen years, roamed I with Eleonora before Love entered within our hearts.
author: EAP

text: It was one evening at the close of the third lustrum of her life, and of the fourth of my own, that we sat, locked in each other's embrace, beneath the serpent-like trees, and looked down within the water of the River of Silence at our images therein.
author: EAP

text: We spoke no words during the rest of that sweet day, and our words even upon the morrow were tremulous and few.
author: EAP

text: We had drawn the God Eros from that wave, and now we felt that he had enkindled within us the fiery souls of our forefathers.
author: EAP

text: The passions which had for centuries distinguished our race, came thronging with the fancies for which they had been equally noted, and together breathed a delirious bliss over the Valley of the Many-Colored Grass.
author: EAP

text: A change fell upon all things.
author: EAP

text: Strange, brilliant flowers, star-shaped, burn out upon the trees where no flowers had been known before.
author: EAP

text: The tints of the green carpet deepened; and when, one by one, the white daisies shrank away, there sprang up in place of them, ten by ten of the ruby-red asphodel.
author: EAP

text: And life arose in our paths; for the tall flamingo, hitherto unseen, with all gay glowing birds, flaunted his scarlet plumage before us.
author: EAP

text: The golden and silver fish haunted the river, out of the bosom of which issued, little by little, a murmur that swelled, at length, into a lulling melody more divine than that of the harp of Aeolus-sweeter than all save the voice of Eleonora.
author: EAP

text: And now, too, a voluminous cloud, which we had long watched in the regions of Hesper, floated out thence, all gorgeous in crimson and gold, and settling in peace above us, sank, day by day, lower and lower, until its edges rested upon the tops of the mountains, turning all their dimness into magnificence, and shutting us up, as if forever, within a magic prison-house of grandeur and of glory.
author: EAP

text: The loveliness of Eleonora was that of the Seraphim; but she was a maiden artless and innocent as the brief life she had led among the flowers.
author: EAP

text: No guile disguised the fervor of love which animated her heart, and she examined with me its inmost recesses as we walked together in the Valley of the Many-Colored Grass, and discoursed of the mighty changes which had lately taken place therein.
author: EAP

text: At length, having spoken one day, in tears, of the last sad change which must befall Humanity, she thenceforward dwelt only upon this one sorrowful theme, interweaving it into all our converse, as, in the songs of the bard of Schiraz, the same images are found occurring, again and again, in every impressive variation of phrase.
author: EAP

text: She had seen that the finger of Death was upon her bosom -- that, like the ephemeron, she had been made perfect in loveliness only to die; but the terrors of the grave to her lay solely in a consideration which she revealed to me, one evening at twilight, by the banks of the River of Silence.
author: EAP

text: She grieved to think that, having entombed her in the Valley of the Many-Colored Grass, I would quit forever its happy recesses, transferring the love which now was so passionately her own to some maiden of the outer and everyday world.
author: EAP

text: And, then and there, I threw myself hurriedly at the feet of Eleonora, and offered up a vow, to herself and to Heaven, that I would never bind myself in marriage to any daughter of Earth -- that I would in no manner prove recreant to her dear memory, or to the memory of the devout affection with which she had blessed me.
author: EAP

text: And I called the Mighty Ruler of the Universe to witness the pious solemnity of my vow.
author: EAP

text: And the curse which I invoked of Him and of her, a saint in Helusion should I prove traitorous to that promise, involved a penalty the exceeding great horror of which will not permit me to make record of it here.
author: EAP

text: And the bright eyes of Eleonora grew brighter at my words; and she sighed as if a deadly burthen had been taken from her breast; and she trembled and very bitterly wept; but she made acceptance of the vow, (for what was she but a child?)

text: and it made easy to her the bed of her death.
author: EAP

text: And she said to me, not many days afterward, tranquilly dying, that, because of what I had done for the comfort of her spirit she would watch over me in that spirit when departed, and, if so it were permitted her return to me visibly in the watches of the night; but, if this thing were, indeed, beyond the power of the souls in Paradise, that she would, at least, give me frequent indications of her presence, sighing upon me in the evening winds, or filling the air which I breathed with perfume from the censers of the angels.
author: EAP

text: And, with these words upon her lips, she yielded up her innocent life, putting an end to the first epoch of my own.
author: EAP

text: Thus far I have faithfully said.

text: -- Years dragged themselves along heavily, and still I dwelled within the Valley of the Many-Colored Grass; but a second change had come upon all things.

author: EAP

text: Yet the promises of Eleonora were not forgotten; for I heard the sounds of the swinging of the censers of the angels; and streams of a holy perfume floated ever and ever about the valley; and at lone hours, when my heart beat heavily, the winds that bathed my brow came unto me laden with soft sighs; and indistinct murmurs filled often the night air, and once -- oh, but once only!

text: Weak-minded, and beset with constitutional infirmities akin to my own, my parents could do but little to check the evil propensities which distinguished me.

text: Thenceforward my voice was a household law; and at an age when few children have abandoned their leading-strings, I was left to the guidance of my own will, and became, in all but name, the master of my own actions.

text: My earliest recollections of a school-life are connected with a large, rambling, cottage-built, and somewhat decayed building in a misty-looking village of England, where were a vast number of gigantic and gnarled trees, and where all the houses were excessively ancient.
author: EAP

text: In truth, it was a dream-like and spirit-soothing place, that venerable old town.
author: EAP

text: At this moment, in fancy, I feel the refreshing chilliness of its deeply-shadowed avenues, inhale the fragrance of its thousand shrubberies, and thrill anew with undefinable delight, at the deep, hollow note of the church-bell, breaking, each hour, with sullen and sudden roar, upon the stillness of the dusky atmosphere in which the old, fretted, Gothic steeple lay imbedded and asleep.
author: EAP

text: It gives me, perhaps, as much of pleasure as I can now in any manner experience, to dwell upon minute recollections of the school and its concerns.

text: The house, I have said, was old, irregular, and cottage-built.

text: The grounds were extensive, and an enormously high and solid brick wall, topped with a bed of mortar and broken glass, encompassed the whole.

text: This prison-like rampart formed the limit of our domain.

text: Beyond it we saw but thrice a week -- once every Saturday afternoon, when, attended by two ushers, we were permitted to take brief walks in a body through some of the neighbouring fields -- and twice during Sunday, when we were paraded in the same formal manner to the morning and evening service in the one church of the village.
author: EAP

text: Of this church the principal of our school was pastor.

text: Oh, gigantic paradox, too utterly monstrous for solution!

author: EAP

text: A huge bucket with water stood at one extremity of the room, and a clock of stupendous dimensions at the other.

text: Encompassed by the massy walls of this venerable academy I passed, yet not in tedium or disgust, the years of the third lustrum of my life.

text: The teeming brain of childhood requires no external world of incident to occupy or amuse it; and the apparently dismal monotony of a school was replete with more intense excitement than my riper youth has derived from luxury, or my full manhood from crime.

text: In childhood I must have felt with the energy of a man what I now find stamped upon memory in lines as vivid, as deep, and as durable as the exergues of the Carthaginian medals.
