text: This ballast being discarded, and a clear sunshine evaporating the dew, and at the same time expanding the gas in the silk, the whole will again rapidly ascend.
author: EAP

text: To check this ascent, the only recourse is, (or rather was, until Mr. Green's invention of the guide-rope,) the permission of the escape of gas from the valve; but, in the loss of gas, is a proportionate general loss of ascending power; so that, in a comparatively brief period, the best-constructed balloon must necessarily exhaust all its resources, and come to the earth.
author: EAP

text: This was the great obstacle to voyages of length.
author: EAP

text: The guide-rope remedies the difficulty in the simplest manner conceivable.
author: EAP

text: It is merely a very long rope which is suffered to trail from the car, and the effect of which is to prevent the balloon from changing its level in any material degree.
author: EAP

text: If, for example, there should be a deposition of moisture upon the silk, and the machine begins to descend in consequence, there will be no necessity for discharging ballast to remedy the increase of weight, for it is remedied, or counteracted, in an exactly just proportion, by the deposit on the ground of just so much of the end of the rope as is necessary.
author: EAP

text: If, on the other hand, any circumstances should cause undue levity, and consequent ascent, this levity is immediately counteracted by the additional weight of rope upraised from the earth.
author: EAP

text: Thus, the balloon can neither ascend or descend, except within very narrow limits, and its resources, either in gas or ballast, remain comparatively unimpaired.
author: EAP

text: When passing over an expanse of water, it becomes necessary to employ small kegs of copper or wood, filled with liquid ballast of a lighter nature than water.
author: EAP

text: These float, and serve all the purposes of the mere rope on land.
author: EAP

text: Another most important office of the guide-rope, is to point out the direction of the balloon.
author: EAP

text: The rope drags, either on land or sea, while the balloon is free; the latter, consequently, is always in advance, when any progress whatever is made : a comparison, therefore, by means of the compass, of the relative positions of two objects, will always indicate the course.
author: EAP

text: In the same way, the angle formed by the rope with the vertical axis of the machine, indicates the velocity.
author: EAP

text: When there is no angle -- in other words, when the rope hangs perpendicularly, the whole apparatus is stationary; but the larger the angle, that is to say, the farther the balloon precedes the end of the rope, the greater the velocity; and the converse.
author: EAP

text: As the original design was to cross the British Channel, and alight as near Paris as possible, the voyagers had taken the precaution to prepare themselves with passports directed to all parts of the Continent, specifying the nature of the expedition, as in the case of the Nassau voyage, and entitling the adventurers to exemption from the usual formalities of office : unexpected events, however, rendered these passports superfluous.
author: EAP

text: The inflation was commenced very quietly at daybreak, on Saturday morning, the 6th instant, in the Court-Yard of Weal-Vor House, Mr. Osborne's seat, about a mile from Penstruthal, in North Wales; and at 7 minutes past 11, every thing being ready for departure, the balloon was set free, rising gently but steadily, in a direction nearly South; no use being made, for the first half hour, of either the screw or the rudder.
author: EAP

text: We proceed now with the journal, as transcribed by Mr. Forsyth from the joint MSS.
author: EAP

text: of Mr. Monck Mason, and Mr. Ainsworth.
author: EAP

text: The body of the journal, as given, is in the hand-writing of Mr. Mason, and a P. S. is appended, each day, by Mr. Ainsworth, who has in preparation, and will shortly give the public a more minute, and no doubt, a thrillingly interesting account of the voyage.
author: EAP

text: Saturday, April the 6th.
author: EAP

text: -- Every preparation likely to embarrass us, having been made over night, we commenced the inflation this morning at daybreak; but owing to a thick fog, which encumbered the folds of the silk and rendered it unmanageable, we did not get through before nearly eleven o'clock.
author: EAP

text: Cut loose, then, in high spirits, and rose gently but steadily, with a light breeze at North, which bore us in the direction of the Bristol Channel.
author: EAP

text: Found the ascending force greater than we had expected; and as we arose higher and so got clear of the cliffs, and more in the sun's rays, our ascent became very rapid.
author: EAP

text: I did not wish, however, to lose gas at so early a period of the adventure, and so concluded to ascend for the present.
author: EAP

text: We soon ran out our guide-rope; but even when we had raised it clear of the earth, we still went up very rapidly.
author: EAP

text: The balloon was unusually steady, and looked beautifully.
author: EAP

text: In about 10 minutes after starting, the barometer indicated an altitude of 15,000 feet.
author: EAP

text: The weather was remarkably fine, and the view of the subjacent country -- a most romantic one when seen from any point, -- was now especially sublime.
author: EAP

text: The numerous deep gorges presented the appearance of lakes, on account of the dense vapors with which they were filled, and the pinnacles and crags to the South East, piled in inextricable confusion, resembling nothing so much as the giant cities of eastern fable.
author: EAP

text: We were rapidly approaching the mountains in the South; but our elevation was more than sufficient to enable us to pass them in safety.
author: EAP

text: In a few minutes we soared over them in fine style; and Mr. Ainsworth, with the seamen, was surprised at their apparent want of altitude when viewed from the car, the tendency of great elevation in a balloon being to reduce inequalities of the surface below, to nearly a dead level.
author: EAP

text: At half-past eleven still proceeding nearly South, we obtained our first view of the Bristol Channel; and, in fifteen minutes afterward, the line of breakers on the coast appeared immediately beneath us, and we were fairly out at sea.
author: EAP

text: We now resolved to let off enough gas to bring our guide-rope, with the buoys affixed, into the water.
author: EAP

text: This was immediately done, and we commenced a gradual descent.
author: EAP

text: In about 20 minutes our first buoy dipped, and at the touch of the second soon afterwards, we remained stationary as to elevation.
author: EAP

text: We were all now anxious to test the efficiency of the rudder and screw, and we put them both into requisition forthwith, for the purpose of altering our direction more to the eastward, and in a line for Paris.
author: EAP

text: By means of the rudder we instantly effected the necessary change of direction, and our course was brought nearly at right angles to that of the wind; when we set in motion the spring of the screw, and were rejoiced to find it propel us readily as desired.
author: EAP

text: Upon this we gave nine hearty cheers, and dropped in the sea a bottle, enclosing a slip of parchment with a brief account of the principle of the invention.
author: EAP

text: Hardly, however, had we done with our rejoicings, when an unforeseen accident occurred which discouraged us in no little degree.
author: EAP

text: The steel rod connecting the spring with the propeller was suddenly jerked out of place, at the car end, (by a swaying of the car through some movement of one of the two seamen we had taken up,) and in an instant hung dangling out of reach, from the pivot of the axis of the screw.
author: EAP

text: While we were endeavoring to regain it, our attention being completely absorbed, we became involved in a strong current of wind from the East, which bore us, with rapidly increasing force, towards the Atlantic.
author: EAP

text: We soon found ourselves driving out to sea at the rate of not less, certainly, than 50 or 60 miles an hour, so that we came up with Cape Clear, at some 40 miles to our North, before we had secured the rod, and had time to think what we were about.
author: EAP

text: It was now that Mr. Ainsworth made an extraordinary, but to my fancy, a by no means unreasonable or chimerical proposition, in which he was instantly seconded by Mr. Holland -- viz.
author: EAP

text: : that we should take advantage of the strong gale which bore us on, and in place of beating back to Paris, make an attempt to reach the coast of North America.
author: EAP

text: After slight reflection I gave a willing assent to this bold proposition, which (strange to say) met with objection from the two seamen only.
author: EAP

text: As the stronger party, however, we overruled their fears, and kept resolutely upon our course.
author: EAP

text: We steered due West; but as the trailing of the buoys materially impeded our progress, and we had the balloon abundantly at command, either for ascent or descent, we first threw out fifty pounds of ballast, and then wound up (by means of a windlass) so much of the rope as brought it quite clear of the sea.
author: EAP

text: We perceived the effect of this manoeuvre immediately, in a vastly increased rate of progress and, as the gale freshened, we flew with a velocity nearly inconceivable; the ide-rope flying out behind the car, like a streamer from a vessel.
author: EAP

text: It is needless to say that a very short time sufficed us to lose sight of the coast.
author: EAP

text: We passed over innumerable vessels of all kinds, a few of which were endeavoring to beat up, but the most of them lying to.
author: EAP

text: We occasioned the greatest excitement on board all -- an excitement greatly relished by ourselves, and especially by our two men, who, now under the influence of a dram of Geneva, seemed resolved to give all scruple, or fear, to the wind.
author: EAP

text: Many of the vessels fired signal guns; some displayed flags and in all we were saluted with loud cheers (which we heard with surprising distinctness) and the waving of caps and handkerchiefs.
author: EAP

text: We kept on in this manner throughout the day, with no material incident, and, as the shades of night closed around us, we made a rough estimate of the distance traversed.
author: EAP

text: It could not have been less than 500 miles, and was probably much more.
author: EAP

text: The propeller was kept in constant operation, and, no doubt, aided our progress materially.
author: EAP

text: As the sun went down, the gale freshened into an absolute hurricane, and the ocean beneath was clearly visible on account of its phosphorescence.
author: EAP

text: The wind was from the East all night, and gave us the brightest omen of success.
author: EAP

text: We suffered no little from cold, and the dampness of the atmosphere was most unpleasant; but the ample space in the car enabled us to lie down, and by means of cloaks and a few blankets, we did sufficiently well.
author: EAP

text: The last nine hours have been unquestionably the most exciting of my life.
author: EAP

text: I can conceive nothing more sublimating than the strange peril and novelty of an adventure such as this.
author: EAP

text: May God grant that we succeed !
author: EAP

text: I ask not success for mere safety to my insignificant person, but for the sake of human knowledge and -- for the vastness of the triumph.
author: EAP

text: And yet the feat is only so evidently feasible that the sole wonder is why men have scrupled to attempt it before.
author: EAP

text: One single gale such as now befriends us -- let such a tempest whirl forward a balloon for 4 or 5 days (these gales often last longer) and the voyager will be easily borne, in that period, from coast to coast.
author: EAP

text: In view of such a gale the broad Atlantic becomes a mere lake.
author: EAP

text: I am more struck, just now, with the supreme silence which reigns in the sea beneath us, notwithstanding its agitation, than with any other phenomenon presenting itself.
author: EAP

text: The waters give up no voice to the heavens.
author: EAP

text: The immense flaming ocean writhes and is tortured uncomplainingly.
author: EAP

text: The mountainous surges suggest the idea of innumerable dumb gigantic fiends struggling in impotent agony.
author: EAP

text: In a night such as is this to me, a man lives -- lives a whole century of ordinary life -- nor would I forego this rapturous delight for that of a whole century of ordinary existence.
author: EAP

text: [Mr. Mason's MS.] This morning the gale, by 10, had subsided to an eight or nine -- knot breeze, (for a vessel at sea,) and bears us, perhaps, 30 miles per hour, or more.
author: EAP

text: It has veered, however, very considerably to the north; and now, at sundown, we are holding our course due west, principally by the screw and rudder, which answer their purposes to admiration.
author: EAP

text: I regard the project as thoroughly successful, and the easy navigation of the air in any direction (not exactly in the teeth of a gale) as no longer problematical.
author: EAP

text: We could not have made head against the strong wind of yesterday; but, by ascending, we might have got out of its influence, if requisite.
author: EAP

text: Against a pretty stiff breeze, I feel convinced, we can make our way with the propeller.
author: EAP

text: At noon, to-day, ascended to an elevation of nearly 25,000 feet (about the height of Cotopaxi), by discharging ballast.
author: EAP

text: Did this to search for a more direct current, but found none so favorable as the one we are now in.
author: EAP

text: We have an abundance of gas to take us across this small pond, even should the voyage last 3 weeks.
author: EAP

text: I have not the slightest fear for the result.
author: EAP

text: The difficulty has been strangely exaggerated and misapprehended.
author: EAP

text: I can choose my current, and should I find all currents against me, I can make very tolerable headway with the propeller.
author: EAP

text: We have had no incidents worth recording.
author: EAP

text: The night promises fair.
author: EAP

text: I have little to record, except the fact (to me quite a surprising one) that, at an elevation equal to that of Cotopaxi, I experienced neither very intense cold, nor headache, nor difficulty of breathing; neither, I find, did Mr. Mason, nor Mr. Holland, nor Sir Everard.
author: EAP

text: Mr. Osborne complained of constriction of the chest -- but this soon wore off.
author: EAP

text: We have flown at a great rate during the day, and we must be more than half way across the Atlantic.
author: EAP

text: We have passed over some 20 or 30 vessels of various kinds, and all seem to be delightfully astonished.
author: EAP

text: Crossing the ocean in a balloon is not so difficult a feat after all.
author: EAP

text: Omne ignotum pro magnifico.
author: EAP

text: Mem : at 25,000 feet elevation the sky appears nearly black, and the stars are distinctly visible; while the sea does not seem convex (as one might suppose) but absolutely and most unequivocally concave.
author: EAP

text: * Monday, the 8th.
author: EAP

text: [Mr. Mason's MS.] This morning we had again some little trouble with the rod of the propeller, which must be entirely remodelled, for fear of serious accident -- I mean the steel rod -- not the vanes.
author: EAP

text: The latter could not be improved.
author: EAP

text: The wind has been blowing steadily and strongly from the north-east all day and so far fortune seems bent upon favoring us.
author: EAP

text: Just before day, we were all somewhat alarmed at some odd noises and concussions in the balloon, accompanied with the apparent rapid subsidence of the whole machine.
author: EAP

text: These phenomena were occasioned by the expansion of the gas, through increase of heat in the atmosphere, and the consequent disruption of the minute particles of ice with which the network had become encrusted during the night.
author: EAP

text: Threw down several bottles to the vessels below.
author: EAP

text: Saw one of them picked up by a large ship -- seemingly one of the New York line packets.
author: EAP

text: Endeavored to make out her name, but could not be sure of it.
author: EAP

text: Mr. Osbornes telescope made it out something like "Atalanta."
author: EAP

text: It is now 12 ,at night, and we are still going nearly west, at a rapid pace.
author: EAP

text: The sea is peculiarly phosphorescent.
author: EAP

text: It is now 2, A.M., and nearly calm, as well as I can judge -- but it is very difficult to determine this point, since we move with the air so completely.
author: EAP

text: The vanes are working admirably.
author: EAP

text: I have not slept since quitting Wheal-Vor, but can stand it no longer, and must take a nap.
author: EAP

text: We cannot be far from the American coast.
author: EAP

text: [Mr. Ainsworth's MS.] One, P.M. We are in full view of the low coast of South Carolina.
author: EAP

text: The great problem is accomplished.
author: EAP

text: We have crossed the Atlantic -- fairly and easily crossed it in a balloon !
author: EAP

text: God be praised !
author: EAP

text: Who shall say that anything is impossible hereafter?
author: EAP

text: --------------- The Journal here ceases.
author: EAP

text: Some particulars of the descent were communicated, however, by Mr. Ainsworth to Mr. Forsyth.
author: EAP

text: It was nearly dead calm when the voyagers first came in view of the coast, which was immediately recognized by both the seamen, and by Mr. Osborne.
author: EAP

text: The latter gentleman having acquaintances at Fort Moultrie, it was immediately resolved to descend in its vicinity.
author: EAP

text: The balloon was brought over the beach (the tide being out and the sand hard, smooth, and admirably adapted for a descent,) and the grapnel let go, which took firm hold at once.
author: EAP

text: The inhabitants of the island, and of the fort, thronged out, of course, to see the balloon; but it was with the greatest difficulty that any one could be made to credit the actual voyage -- the crossing of the Atlantic.
author: EAP

text: The grapnel caught at 2, P.M., precisely; and thus the whole voyage was completed in 75 hours; or rather less, counting from shore to shore.
author: EAP

text: No serious accident occurred.
author: EAP

text: No real danger was at any time apprehended.
author: EAP

text: The balloon was exhausted and secured without trouble; and when the MS. from which this narrative is compiled was despatched from Charleston, the party were still at Fort Moultrie.
author: EAP

text: Their farther intentions were not ascertained; but we can safely promise our readers some additional information either on Monday or in the course of the next day, at farthest.
author: EAP

text: This is unquestionably the most stupendous, the most interesting, and the most important undertaking, ever accomplished or even attempted by man.
author: EAP

text: What magnificent events may ensue, it would be useless now to think of determining.
author: EAP

text: -- Mr. Ainsworth has not attempted to account for this phenomenon, which, however, is quite susceptible of explanation.
author: EAP

text: A line dropped from an elevation of 25,000 feet, perpendicularly to the surface of the earth (or sea), would form the perpendicular of a right-angled triangle, of which the base would extend from the right angle to the horizon, and the hypothenuse from the horizon to the balloon.
author: EAP

text: But the 25,000 feet of altitude is little or nothing, in comparison with the extent of prospect.
author: EAP

text: In other words, the base and hypothenuse of the supposed triangle would be so long when compared with the perpendicular, that the two former may be regarded as nearly parallel.
author: EAP

text: In this manner the horizon of the aeronaut would appear to be on a level with the car.
author: EAP

text: But, as the point immediately beneath him seems, and is, at a great distance below him, it seems, of course, also, at a great distance below the horizon.
author: EAP

text: Hence the impression of concavity; and this impression must remain, until the elevation shall bear so great a proportion to the extent of prospect, that the apparent parallelism of the base and hypothenuse disappears -- when the earth's real convexity must appear.
author: EAP

text: IN THE consideration of the faculties and impulses -- of the prima mobilia of the human soul, the phrenologists have failed to make room for a propensity which, although obviously existing as a radical, primitive, irreducible sentiment, has been equally overlooked by all the moralists who have preceded them.
author: EAP

text: In the pure arrogance of the reason, we have all overlooked it.
author: EAP

text: We have suffered its existence to escape our senses, solely through want of belief -- of faith; -- whether it be faith in Revelation, or faith in the Kabbala.
author: EAP

text: The idea of it has never occurred to us, simply because of its supererogation.
author: EAP

text: We saw no need of the impulse -- for the propensity.
author: EAP

text: We could not perceive its necessity.
author: EAP

text: We could not understand, that is to say, we could not have understood, had the notion of this primum mobile ever obtruded itself; -- we could not have understood in what manner it might be made to further the objects of humanity, either temporal or eternal.
author: EAP

text: It cannot be denied that phrenology and, in great measure, all metaphysicianism have been concocted a priori.
author: EAP

text: The intellectual or logical man, rather than the understanding or observant man, set himself to imagine designs -- to dictate purposes to God.
author: EAP

text: Having thus fathomed, to his satisfaction, the intentions of Jehovah, out of these intentions he built his innumerable systems of mind.
author: EAP

text: In the matter of phrenology, for example, we first determined, naturally enough, that it was the design of the Deity that man should eat.
author: EAP

text: We then assigned to man an organ of alimentiveness, and this organ is the scourge with which the Deity compels man, will-I nill-I, into eating.
author: EAP

text: Secondly, having settled it to be God's will that man should continue his species, we discovered an organ of amativeness, forthwith.
author: EAP

text: And so with combativeness, with ideality, with causality, with constructiveness, -- so, in short, with every organ, whether representing a propensity, a moral sentiment, or a faculty of the pure intellect.
author: EAP

text: And in these arrangements of the Principia of human action, the Spurzheimites, whether right or wrong, in part, or upon the whole, have but followed, in principle, the footsteps of their predecessors: deducing and establishing every thing from the preconceived destiny of man, and upon the ground of the objects of his Creator.
author: EAP

text: It would have been wiser, it would have been safer, to classify (if classify we must) upon the basis of what man usually or occasionally did, and was always occasionally doing, rather than upon the basis of what we took it for granted the Deity intended him to do.
author: EAP

text: If we cannot comprehend God in his visible works, how then in his inconceivable thoughts, that call the works into being?
author: EAP

text: If we cannot understand him in his objective creatures, how then in his substantive moods and phases of creation?
author: EAP

text: Induction, a posteriori, would have brought phrenology to admit, as an innate and primitive principle of human action, a paradoxical something, which we may call perverseness, for want of a more characteristic term.
author: EAP

text: In the sense I intend, it is, in fact, a mobile without motive, a motive not motivirt.
author: EAP

text: Through its promptings we act without comprehensible object; or, if this shall be understood as a contradiction in terms, we may so far modify the proposition as to say, that through its promptings we act, for the reason that we should not.
author: EAP

text: In theory, no reason can be more unreasonable, but, in fact, there is none more strong.
author: EAP

text: With certain minds, under certain conditions, it becomes absolutely irresistible.
author: EAP

text: I am not more certain that I breathe, than that the assurance of the wrong or error of any action is often the one unconquerable force which impels us, and alone impels us to its prosecution.
author: EAP

text: Nor will this overwhelming tendency to do wrong for the wrong's sake, admit of analysis, or resolution into ulterior elements.
author: EAP

text: It is a radical, a primitive impulse-elementary.
author: EAP

text: It will be said, I am aware, that when we persist in acts because we feel we should not persist in them, our conduct is but a modification of that which ordinarily springs from the combativeness of phrenology.
author: EAP

text: But a glance will show the fallacy of this idea.
author: EAP

text: The phrenological combativeness has for its essence, the necessity of self-defence.
author: EAP

text: It is our safeguard against injury.
author: EAP

text: Its principle regards our well-being; and thus the desire to be well is excited simultaneously with its development.
author: EAP

text: It follows, that the desire to be well must be excited simultaneously with any principle which shall be merely a modification of combativeness, but in the case of that something which I term perverseness, the desire to be well is not only not aroused, but a strongly antagonistical sentiment exists.
author: EAP

text: An appeal to one's own heart is, after all, the best reply to the sophistry just noticed.
author: EAP

text: No one who trustingly consults and thoroughly questions his own soul, will be disposed to deny the entire radicalness of the propensity in question.
author: EAP

text: It is not more incomprehensible than distinctive.
author: EAP

text: There lives no man who at some period has not been tormented, for example, by an earnest desire to tantalize a listener by circumlocution.
author: EAP

text: The speaker is aware that he displeases; he has every intention to please, he is usually curt, precise, and clear, the most laconic and luminous language is struggling for utterance upon his tongue, it is only with difficulty that he restrains himself from giving it flow; he dreads and deprecates the anger of him whom he addresses; yet, the thought strikes him, that by certain involutions and parentheses this anger may be engendered.
author: EAP

text: That single thought is enough.
author: EAP

text: The impulse increases to a wish, the wish to a desire, the desire to an uncontrollable longing, and the longing (to the deep regret and mortification of the speaker, and in defiance of all consequences) is indulged.
author: EAP

text: We have a task before us which must be speedily performed.
author: EAP

text: We know that it will be ruinous to make delay.
author: EAP

text: The most important crisis of our life calls, trumpet-tongued, for immediate energy and action.
author: EAP

text: We glow, we are consumed with eagerness to commence the work, with the anticipation of whose glorious result our whole souls are on fire.
author: EAP

text: It must, it shall be undertaken to-day, and yet we put it off until to-morrow, and why?
author: EAP

text: There is no answer, except that we feel perverse, using the word with no comprehension of the principle.
author: EAP

text: To-morrow arrives, and with it a more impatient anxiety to do our duty, but with this very increase of anxiety arrives, also, a nameless, a positively fearful, because unfathomable, craving for delay.
author: EAP

text: This craving gathers strength as the moments fly.
author: EAP

text: The last hour for action is at hand.
author: EAP

text: We tremble with the violence of the conflict within us, -- of the definite with the indefinite -- of the substance with the shadow.
author: EAP

text: But, if the contest have proceeded thus far, it is the shadow which prevails, -- we struggle in vain.
author: EAP

text: The clock strikes, and is the knell of our welfare.
author: EAP

text: At the same time, it is the chanticleer -- note to the ghost that has so long overawed us.
author: EAP

text: It flies -- it disappears -- we are free.
author: EAP

text: The old energy returns.
author: EAP

text: We will labor now.
author: EAP

text: Alas, it is too late!
author: EAP

text: We stand upon the brink of a precipice.
author: EAP

text: We peer into the abyss -- we grow sick and dizzy.
author: EAP

text: Our first impulse is to shrink from the danger.
author: EAP

text: By slow degrees our sickness and dizziness and horror become merged in a cloud of unnamable feeling.
author: EAP

text: By gradations, still more imperceptible, this cloud assumes shape, as did the vapor from the bottle out of which arose the genius in the Arabian Nights.
author: EAP

text: But out of this our cloud upon the precipice's edge, there grows into palpability, a shape, far more terrible than any genius or any demon of a tale, and yet it is but a thought, although a fearful one, and one which chills the very marrow of our bones with the fierceness of the delight of its horror.
author: EAP

text: It is merely the idea of what would be our sensations during the sweeping precipitancy of a fall from such a height.
author: EAP

text: And this fall -- this rushing annihilation -- for the very reason that it involves that one most ghastly and loathsome of all the most ghastly and loathsome images of death and suffering which have ever presented themselves to our imagination -- for this very cause do we now the most vividly desire it.
author: EAP

text: And because our reason violently deters us from the brink, therefore do we the most impetuously approach it.
author: EAP

text: There is no passion in nature so demoniacally impatient, as that of him who, shuddering upon the edge of a precipice, thus meditates a Plunge.
author: EAP

text: To indulge, for a moment, in any attempt at thought, is to be inevitably lost; for reflection but urges us to forbear, and therefore it is, I say, that we cannot.
author: EAP

text: If there be no friendly arm to check us, or if we fail in a sudden effort to prostrate ourselves backward from the abyss, we plunge, and are destroyed.
author: EAP

text: Examine these similar actions as we will, we shall find them resulting solely from the spirit of the Perverse.
author: EAP

text: We perpetrate them because we feel that we should not.
author: EAP

text: Beyond or behind this there is no intelligible principle; and we might, indeed, deem this perverseness a direct instigation of the Arch-Fiend, were it not occasionally known to operate in furtherance of good.
author: EAP

text: I have said thus much, that in some measure I may answer your question, that I may explain to you why I am here, that I may assign to you something that shall have at least the faint aspect of a cause for my wearing these fetters, and for my tenanting this cell of the condemned.
author: EAP

text: Had I not been thus prolix, you might either have misunderstood me altogether, or, with the rabble, have fancied me mad.
author: EAP

text: As it is, you will easily perceive that I am one of the many uncounted victims of the Imp of the Perverse.
author: EAP

text: It is impossible that any deed could have been wrought with a more thorough deliberation.
author: EAP

text: For weeks, for months, I pondered upon the means of the murder.
author: EAP

text: I rejected a thousand schemes, because their accomplishment involved a chance of detection.
author: EAP

text: At length, in reading some French Memoirs, I found an account of a nearly fatal illness that occurred to Madame Pilau, through the agency of a candle accidentally poisoned.
author: EAP

text: The idea struck my fancy at once.
author: EAP

text: I knew my victim's habit of reading in bed.
author: EAP

text: I knew, too, that his apartment was narrow and ill-ventilated.
author: EAP

text: But I need not vex you with impertinent details.
author: EAP

text: I need not describe the easy artifices by which I substituted, in his bed-room candle-stand, a wax-light of my own making for the one which I there found.
author: EAP

text: The next morning he was discovered dead in his bed, and the Coroner's verdict was -- "Death by the visitation of God."
author: EAP

text: Having inherited his estate, all went well with me for years.
author: EAP

text: The idea of detection never once entered my brain.
author: EAP

text: Of the remains of the fatal taper I had myself carefully disposed.
author: EAP

text: I had left no shadow of a clew by which it would be possible to convict, or even to suspect me of the crime.
author: EAP

text: It is inconceivable how rich a sentiment of satisfaction arose in my bosom as I reflected upon my absolute security.
author: EAP

text: For a very long period of time I was accustomed to revel in this sentiment.
author: EAP

text: It afforded me more real delight than all the mere worldly advantages accruing from my sin.
author: EAP

text: But there arrived at length an epoch, from which the pleasurable feeling grew, by scarcely perceptible gradations, into a haunting and harassing thought.
author: EAP

text: It harassed because it haunted.
author: EAP

text: I could scarcely get rid of it for an instant.
author: EAP

text: It is quite a common thing to be thus annoyed with the ringing in our ears, or rather in our memories, of the burthen of some ordinary song, or some unimpressive snatches from an opera.
author: EAP

text: Nor will we be the less tormented if the song in itself be good, or the opera air meritorious.
author: EAP

text: In this manner, at last, I would perpetually catch myself pondering upon my security, and repeating, in a low undertone, the phrase, "I am safe."
author: EAP

text: One day, whilst sauntering along the streets, I arrested myself in the act of murmuring, half aloud, these customary syllables.
author: EAP

text: In a fit of petulance, I remodelled them thus; "I am safe -- I am safe -- yes -- if I be not fool enough to make open confession!"
author: EAP

text: No sooner had I spoken these words, than I felt an icy chill creep to my heart.
author: EAP

text: I had had some experience in these fits of perversity, (whose nature I have been at some trouble to explain), and I remembered well that in no instance I had successfully resisted their attacks.
author: EAP

text: And now my own casual self-suggestion that I might possibly be fool enough to confess the murder of which I had been guilty, confronted me, as if the very ghost of him whom I had murdered -- and beckoned me on to death.
author: EAP

text: At first, I made an effort to shake off this nightmare of the soul.
author: EAP

text: I walked vigorously -- faster -- still faster -- at length I ran.
author: EAP

text: I felt a maddening desire to shriek aloud.
author: EAP

text: Every succeeding wave of thought overwhelmed me with new terror, for, alas!
author: EAP

text: I well, too well understood that to think, in my situation, was to be lost.
author: EAP

text: I still quickened my pace.
author: EAP

text: I bounded like a madman through the crowded thoroughfares.
author: EAP

text: At length, the populace took the alarm, and pursued me.
author: EAP

text: I felt then the consummation of my fate.
author: EAP

text: Could I have torn out my tongue, I would have done it, but a rough voice resounded in my ears -- a rougher grasp seized me by the shoulder.
author: EAP

text: I turned -- I gasped for breath.
author: EAP

text: For a moment I experienced all the pangs of suffocation; I became blind, and deaf, and giddy; and then some invisible fiend, I thought, struck me with his broad palm upon the back.
author: EAP

text: The long imprisoned secret burst forth from my soul.
author: EAP

text: They say that I spoke with a distinct enunciation, but with marked emphasis and passionate hurry, as if in dread of interruption before concluding the brief, but pregnant sentences that consigned me to the hangman and to hell.
author: EAP

author: EAP

author: EAP

author: EAP

text: MANY years ago, I contracted an intimacy with a Mr. William Legrand.
author: EAP

text: He was of an ancient Huguenot family, and had once been wealthy; but a series of misfortunes had reduced him to want.
author: EAP

text: To avoid the mortification consequent upon his disasters, he left New Orleans, the city of his forefathers, and took up his residence at Sullivan's Island, near Charleston, South Carolina.
author: EAP

text: This Island is a very singular one.
author: EAP

text: It consists of little else than the sea sand, and is about three miles long.
author: EAP

text: Its breadth at no point exceeds a quarter of a mile.
author: EAP

text: It is separated from the main land by a scarcely perceptible creek, oozing its way through a wilderness of reeds and slime, a favorite resort of the marsh-hen.
author: EAP

text: The vegetation, as might be supposed, is scant, or at least dwarfish.
author: EAP

text: No trees of any magnitude are to be seen.
author: EAP

text: Near the western extremity, where Fort Moultrie stands, and where are some miserable frame buildings, tenanted, during summer, by the fugitives from Charleston dust and fever, may be found, indeed, the bristly palmetto; but the whole island, with the exception of this western point, and a line of hard, white beach on the seacoast, is covered with a dense undergrowth of the sweet myrtle, so much prized by the horticulturists of England.
author: EAP

text: The shrub here often attains the height of fifteen or twenty feet, and forms an almost impenetrable coppice, burthening the air with its fragrance.
author: EAP

text: In the inmost recesses of this coppice, not far from the eastern or more remote end of the island, Legrand had built himself a small hut, which he occupied when I first, by mere accident, made his acquaintance.
author: EAP

text: This soon ripened into friendship --for there was much in the recluse to excite interest and esteem.
author: EAP

text: I found him well educated, with unusual powers of mind, but infected with misanthropy, and subject to perverse moods of alternate enthusiasm and melancholy.
author: EAP

text: He had with him many books, but rarely employed them.
author: EAP

text: His chief amusements were gunning and fishing, or sauntering along the beach and through the myrtles, in quest of shells or entomological specimens;-his collection of the latter might have been envied by a Swammerdamm.
author: EAP

text: In these excursions he was usually accompanied by an old negro, called Jupiter, who had been manumitted before the reverses of the family, but who could be induced, neither by threats nor by promises, to abandon what he considered his right of attendance upon the footsteps of his young "Massa Will."
author: EAP

text: It is not improbable that the relatives of Legrand, conceiving him to be somewhat unsettled in intellect, had contrived to instil this obstinacy into Jupiter, with a view to the supervision and guardianship of the wanderer.
author: EAP

text: The winters in the latitude of Sullivan's Island are seldom very severe, and in the fall of the year it is a rare event indeed when a fire is considered necessary.
author: EAP

text: About the middle of October, 18--, there occurred, however, a day of remarkable chilliness.
author: EAP

text: Just before sunset I scrambled my way through the evergreens to the hut of my friend, whom I had not visited for several weeks --my residence being, at that time, in Charleston, a distance of nine my miles from the Island, while the facilities of passage and re-passage were very far behind those of the present day.
author: EAP

text: Upon reaching the hut I rapped, as was my custom, and getting no reply, sought for the key where I knew it was secreted, unlocked the door and went in.
author: EAP

author: EAP

author: EAP

author: EAP

author: EAP

text: We crossed the creek at the head of the island by means of a skiff, and, ascending the high grounds on the shore of the mainland, proceeded in a northwesterly direction, through a tract of country excessively wild and desolate, where no trace of a human footstep was to be seen.

text: It was a species of table land, near the summit of an almost inaccessible hill, densely wooded from base to pinnacle, and interspersed with huge crags that appeared to lie loosely upon the soil, and in many cases were prevented from precipitating themselves into the valleys below, merely by the support of the trees against which they reclined.

text: During this colloquy no portion of Jupiter's person could be seen; but the beetle, which he had suffered to descend, was now visible at the end of the string, and glistened, like a globe of burnished gold, in the last rays of the setting sun, some of which still faintly illumined the eminence upon which we stood.

text: To speak the truth, I had no especial relish for such amusement at any time, and, at that particular moment, would most willingly have declined it; for the night was coming on, and I felt much fatigued with the exercise already taken; but I saw no mode of escape, and was fearful of disturbing my poor friend's equanimity by a refusal.
author: EAP

text: Could I have depended, indeed, upon Jupiter's aid, I would have had no hesitation in attempting to get the lunatic home by force; but I was too well assured of the old negro's disposition, to hope that he would assist me, under any circumstances, in a personal contest with his master.
author: EAP

text: I made no doubt that the latter had been infected with some of the innumerable Southern superstitions about money buried, and that his phantasy had received confirmation by the finding of the scarabaeus, or, perhaps, by Jupiter's obstinacy in maintaining it to be "a bug of real gold."
author: EAP

author: EAP

text: Upon the whole, I was sadly vexed and puzzled, but, at length, I concluded to make a virtue of necessity --to dig with a good will, and thus the sooner to convince the visionary, by ocular demonstration, of the fallacy of the opinions he entertained.
author: EAP

text: The lanterns having been lit, we all fell to work with a zeal worthy a more rational cause; and, as the glare fell upon our persons and implements, I could not help thinking how picturesque a group we composed, and how strange and suspicious our labors must have appeared to any interloper who, by chance, might have stumbled upon our whereabouts.
author: EAP

text: There were diamonds --some of them exceedingly large and fine --a hundred and ten in all, and not one of them small; eighteen rubies of remarkable brilliancy; --three hundred and ten emeralds, all very beautiful; and twenty-one sapphires, with an opal.

author: EAP

author: EAP

text: Besides all this, there was a vast quantity of solid gold ornaments; --nearly two hundred massive finger and ear rings; --rich chains --thirty of these, if I remember; --eighty-three very large and heavy crucifixes; --five gold censers of great value; --a prodigious golden punch-bowl, ornamented with richly chased vine-leaves and Bacchanalian figures; with two sword-handles exquisitely embossed, and many other smaller articles which I cannot recollect.
author: EAP

text: The weight of these valuables exceeded three hundred and fifty pounds avoirdupois; and in this estimate I have not included one hundred and ninety-seven superb gold watches; three of the number being worth each five hundred dollars, if one.
author: EAP

text: Many of them were very old, and as time keepers valueless; the works having suffered, more or less, from corrosion --but all were richly jewelled and in cases of great worth.
author: EAP

text: We estimated the entire contents of the chest, that night, at a million and a half of dollars; and, upon the subsequent disposal of the trinkets and jewels (a few being retained for our own use), it was found that we had greatly undervalued the treasure.

text: When you first made this assertion I thought you were jesting; but afterwards I called to mind the peculiar spots on the back of the insect, and admitted to myself that your remark had some little foundation in fact.
author: EAP

text: Still, the sneer at my graphic powers irritated me --for I am considered a good artist --and, therefore, when you handed me the scrap of parchment, I was about to crumple it up and throw it angrily into the fire."
author: EAP

text: "The scrap of paper, you mean," said I.
author: EAP

text: "No; it had much of the appearance of paper, and at first I supposed it to be such, but when I came to draw upon it, I discovered it, at once, to be a piece of very thin parchment.
author: EAP

text: It was quite dirty, you remember.
author: EAP

text: Well, as I was in the very act of crumpling it up, my glance fell upon the sketch at which you had been looking, and you may imagine my astonishment when I perceived, in fact, the figure of a death's-head just where, it seemed to me, I had made the drawing of the beetle.
author: EAP

text: For a moment I was too much amazed to think with accuracy.
author: EAP

text: I knew that my design was very different in detail from this --although there was a certain similarity in general outline.
author: EAP

text: Presently I took a candle, and seating myself at the other end of the room, proceeded to scrutinize the parchment more closely.
author: EAP

text: Upon turning it over, I saw my own sketch upon the reverse, just as I had made it.
author: EAP

text: My first idea, now, was mere surprise at the really remarkable similarity of outline --at the singular coincidence involved in the fact, that unknown to me, there should have been a skull upon the other side of the parchment, immediately beneath my figure of the scarabaeus and that this skull, not only in outline, but in size, should so closely resemble my drawing.
author: EAP

text: I say the singularity of this coincidence absolutely stupefied me for a time.
author: EAP

text: This is the usual effect of such coincidences.
author: EAP

text: The mind struggles to establish a connection --a sequence of cause and effect --and, being unable to do so, suffers a species of temporary paralysis.
author: EAP

text: But, when I recovered from this stupor, there dawned upon me gradually a conviction which startled me even far more than the coincidence.
author: EAP

text: I began distinctly, positively, to remember that there had been no drawing on the parchment when I made my sketch of the scarabaeus.
author: EAP

text: I became perfectly certain of this; for I recollected turning up first one side and then the other, in search of the cleanest spot.
author: EAP

text: Had the skull been then there, of course I could not have failed to notice it.
author: EAP

text: Here was indeed a mystery which I felt it impossible to explain; but, even at that early moment, there it seemed to glimmer, faintly, within the most remote and secret chambers of my intellect, a glow-worm-like conception of that truth which last night's adventure brought to so magnificent a demonstration.
author: EAP

text: I arose at once, and putting the parchment securely away, dismissed all farther reflection until I should be alone.
author: EAP

text: "When you had gone, and when Jupiter was fast asleep, I betook myself to a more methodical investigation of the affair.
author: EAP

text: In the first place I considered the manner in which the parchment had come into my possession.
author: EAP

text: The spot where we discovered the scarabaeus was on the coast of the main land, about a mile eastward of the island, and but a short distance above high water mark.
author: EAP

text: Upon my taking hold of it, it gave me a sharp bite, which caused me to let it drop.
author: EAP

text: Jupiter, with his accustomed caution, before seizing the insect, which had flown towards him, looked about him for a leaf, or something of that nature, by which to take hold of it.
author: EAP

text: It was at this moment that his eyes, and mine also, fell upon the scrap of parchment, which I then supposed to be paper.
author: EAP

text: It was lying half buried in the sand, a corner sticking up.
author: EAP

text: Near the spot where we found it, I observed the remnants of the hull of what appeared to have been a ship's long boat.
author: EAP

text: The wreck seemed to have been there for a very great while; for the resemblance to boat timbers could scarcely be traced.
author: EAP

text: "Well, Jupiter picked up the parchment, wrapped the beetle in it, and gave it to me.
author: EAP

text: Soon afterwards we turned to go home, and on the way met Lieutenant G--.
author: EAP

text: I showed him the insect, and he begged me to let him take it to the fort.
author: EAP

text: On my consenting, he thrust it forthwith into his waistcoat pocket, without the parchment in which it had been wrapped, and which I had continued to hold in my hand during his inspection.
author: EAP

text: Perhaps he dreaded my changing my mind, and thought it best to make sure of the prize at once --you know how enthusiastic he is on all subjects connected with Natural History.
author: EAP

text: At the same time without being conscious of it, I must have deposited the parchment in my own pocket.
author: EAP

text: "You remember that when I went to the table, for the purpose of making a sketch of the beetle, I found no paper where it was usually kept.
author: EAP

text: I looked in the drawer, and found none there.
author: EAP

text: I searched my pockets, hoping to find an old letter --and then my hand fell upon the parchment.
author: EAP

text: I thus detail the precise mode in which it came into my possession; for the circumstances impressed me with peculiar force.
author: EAP

text: "No doubt you will think me fanciful --but I had already established a kind of connexion.
author: EAP

text: I had put together two links of a great chain.
author: EAP

text: There was a boat lying on a sea-coast, and not far from the boat was a parchment --not a paper --with a skull depicted on it.
author: EAP

text: You will, of course, ask 'where is the connexion?'
author: EAP

text: I reply that the skull, or death's-head, is the well-known emblem of the pirate.
author: EAP

text: The flag of the death's-head is hoisted in all engagements.
author: EAP

text: "I have said that the scrap was parchment, and not paper.
author: EAP

text: Parchment is durable --almost imperishable.
author: EAP

text: Matters of little moment are rarely consigned to parchment; since, for the mere ordinary purposes of drawing or writing, it is not nearly so well adapted as paper.
author: EAP

text: This reflection suggested some meaning --some relevancy --in the death's-head.
author: EAP

text: I did not fail to observe, also, the form of the parchment.
author: EAP

text: Although one of its corners had been, by some accident, destroyed, it could be seen that the original form was oblong.
author: EAP

text: It was just such a slip, indeed, as might have been chosen for a memorandum --for a record of something to be long remembered and carefully preserved."
author: EAP

text: "But," I interposed, "you say that the skull was not upon the parchment when you made the drawing of the beetle.
author: EAP

text: How then do you trace any connexion between the boat and the skull --since this latter, according to your own admission, must have been designed (God only knows how or by whom) at some period subsequent to your sketching the scarabaeus?"
author: EAP

text: "Ah, hereupon turns the whole mystery; although the secret, at this point, I had comparatively little difficulty in solving.
author: EAP

text: My steps were sure, and could afford but a single result.
author: EAP

text: I reasoned, for example, thus: When I drew the scarabaeus, there was no skull apparent on the parchment.
author: EAP

text: When I had completed the drawing, I gave it to you, and observed you narrowly until you returned it.
author: EAP

text: You, therefore, did not design the skull, and no one else was present to do it.
author: EAP

text: Then it was not done by human agency.
author: EAP

text: And nevertheless it was done.
author: EAP

text: "At this stage of my reflections I endeavored to remember, and did remember, with entire distinctness, every incident which occurred about the period in question.
author: EAP

text: The weather was chilly (oh rare and happy accident!
author: EAP

text: ), and a fire was blazing on the hearth.
author: EAP

text: I was heated with exercise and sat near the table.
author: EAP

text: You, however, had drawn a chair close to the chimney.
author: EAP

text: Just as I placed the parchment in your hand, and as you were in the act of inspecting it, Wolf, the Newfoundland, entered, and leaped upon your shoulders.
author: EAP

text: With your left hand you caressed him and kept him off, while your right, holding the parchment, was permitted to fall listlessly between your knees, and in close proximity to the fire.
author: EAP

text: At one moment I thought the blaze had caught it, and was about to caution you, but, before I could speak, you had withdrawn it, and were engaged in its examination.
author: EAP

text: When I considered all these particulars, I doubted not for a moment that heat had been the agent in bringing to light, on the parchment, the skull which I saw designed on it.
author: EAP

text: You are well aware that chemical preparations exist, and have existed time out of mind, by means of which it is possible to write on either paper or vellum, so that the characters shall become visible only when subjected to the action of fire.
author: EAP

text: Zaffre, digested in aqua regia, and diluted with four times its weight of water, is sometimes employed; a green tint results.
author: EAP

text: The regulus of cobalt, dissolved in spirit of nitre, gives a red.
author: EAP

text: These colors disappear at longer or shorter intervals after the material written on cools, but again become apparent upon the re-application of heat.
author: EAP

text: "I now scrutinized the death's-head with care.
author: EAP

text: Its outer edges --the edges of the drawing nearest the edge of the vellum --were far more distinct than the others.
author: EAP

text: It was clear that the action of the caloric had been imperfect or unequal.
author: EAP

text: I immediately kindled a fire, and subjected every portion of the parchment to a glowing heat.
author: EAP

text: At first, the only effect was the strengthening of the faint lines in the skull; but, on persevering in the experiment, there became visible, at the corner of the slip, diagonally opposite to the spot in which the death's-head was delineated, the figure of what I at first supposed to be a goat.
author: EAP

text: A closer scrutiny, however, satisfied me that it was intended for a kid."
author: EAP

text: said I, "to be sure I have no right to laugh at you --a million and a half of money is too serious a matter for mirth --but you are not about to establish a third link in your chain --you will not find any especial connexion between your pirates and goat --pirates, you know, have nothing to do with goats; they appertain to the farming interest."
author: EAP

text: "But I have just said that the figure was not that of a goat."
author: EAP

text: "Well, a kid then --pretty much the same thing."
author: EAP

text: "Pretty much, but not altogether," said Legrand.
author: EAP

text: "You may have heard of one Captain Kidd.
author: EAP

text: I at once looked on the figure of the animal as a kind of punning or hieroglyphical signature.
author: EAP

text: I say signature; because its position on the vellum suggested this idea.
author: EAP

text: The death's-head at the corner diagonally opposite, had, in the same manner, the air of a stamp, or seal.
author: EAP

text: But I was sorely put out by the absence of all else --of the body to my imagined instrument --of the text for my context."
author: EAP

text: "I presume you expected to find a letter between the stamp and the signature."
author: EAP

text: "Something of that kind.
author: EAP

text: The fact is, I felt irresistibly impressed with a presentiment of some vast good fortune impending.
author: EAP

text: I can scarcely say why.
author: EAP

text: Perhaps, after all, it was rather a desire than an actual belief; --but do you know that Jupiter's silly words, about the bug being of solid gold, had a remarkable effect on my fancy?
author: EAP

text: And then the series of accidents and coincidences --these were so very extraordinary.
author: EAP

text: Do you observe how mere an accident it was that these events should have occurred on the sole day of all the year in which it has been, or may be, sufficiently cool for fire, and that without the fire, or without the intervention of the dog at the precise moment in which he appeared, I should never have become aware of the death's-head, and so never the possessor of the treasure?"
author: EAP

text: "But proceed --I am all impatience."
author: EAP

text: "Well; you have heard, of course, the many stories current --the thousand vague rumors afloat about money buried, somewhere on the Atlantic coast, by Kidd and his associates.
author: EAP

text: These rumors must have had some foundation in fact.
author: EAP

text: And that the rumors have existed so long and so continuously could have resulted, it appeared to me, only from the circumstance of the buried treasure still remaining entombed.
author: EAP

text: Had Kidd concealed his plunder for a time, and afterwards reclaimed it, the rumors would scarcely have reached us in their present unvarying form.
author: EAP

text: You will observe that the stories told are all about money-seekers, not about money-finders.
author: EAP

text: Had the pirate recovered his money, there the affair would have dropped.
author: EAP

text: It seemed to me that some accident --say the loss of a memorandum indicating its locality --had deprived him of the means of recovering it, and that this accident had become known to is followers, who otherwise might never have heard that treasure had been concealed at all, and who, busying themselves in vain, because unguided attempts, to regain it, had given first birth, and then universal currency, to the reports which are now so common.
author: EAP

text: Have you ever heard of any important treasure being unearthed along the coast?"
author: EAP

text: "But that Kidd's accumulations were immense, is well known.
author: EAP

text: I took it for granted, therefore, that the earth still held them; and you will scarcely be surprised when I tell you that I felt a hope, nearly amounting to certainty, that the parchment so strangely found, involved a lost record of the place of deposit."
author: EAP

text: "But how did you proceed?"
author: EAP

text: "I held the vellum again to the fire, after increasing the heat; but nothing appeared.
author: EAP

text: I now thought it possible that the coating of dirt might have something to do with the failure; so I carefully rinsed the parchment by pouring warm water over it, and, having done this, I placed it in a tin pan, with the skull downwards, and put the pan upon a furnace of lighted charcoal.
author: EAP

text: In a few minutes, the pan having become thoroughly heated, I removed the slip, and, to my inexpressible joy, found it spotted, in several places, with what appeared to be figures arranged in lines.
author: EAP

text: Again I placed it in the pan, and suffered it to remain another minute.
author: EAP

text: On taking it off, the whole was just as you see it now."
author: EAP

text: Here Legrand, having re-heated the parchment, submitted It my inspection.
author: EAP

text: The following characters were rudely traced, in a red tint, between the death's-head and the goat: 53++!305))6*;4826)4+.)4+);806*;48!8`60))85;]8*:+*8!83(88)5*!
author: EAP

text: ; "But," said I, returning him the slip, "I am as much in the dark as ever.
author: EAP

text: Were all the jewels of Golconda awaiting me on my solution of this enigma, I am quite sure that I should be unable to earn them."
author: EAP

text: "And yet," said Legrand, "the solution is by no means so difficult as you might be led to imagine from the first hasty inspection of the characters.
author: EAP

text: These characters, as any one might readily guess, form a cipher --that is to say, they convey a meaning; but then, from what is known of Kidd, I could not suppose him capable of constructing any of the more abstruse cryptographs.
author: EAP

text: I made up my mind, at once, that this was of a simple species --such, however, as would appear, to the crude intellect of the sailor, absolutely insoluble without the key."
author: EAP

text: "And you really solved it?"
author: EAP

text: "Readily; I have solved others of an abstruseness ten thousand times greater.
author: EAP

text: Circumstances, and a certain bias of mind, have led me to take interest in such riddles, and it may well be doubted whether human ingenuity can construct an enigma of the kind which human ingenuity may not, by proper application, resolve.
author: EAP

text: In fact, having once established connected and legible characters, I scarcely gave a thought to the mere difficulty of developing their import.
author: EAP

text: "In the present case --indeed in all cases of secret writing --the first question regards the language of the cipher; for the principles of solution, so far, especially, as the more simple ciphers are concerned, depend on, and are varied by, the genius of the particular idiom.
author: EAP

text: In general, there is no alternative but experiment (directed by probabilities) of every tongue known to him who attempts the solution, until the true one be attained.
author: EAP

text: But, with the cipher now before us, all difficulty is removed by the signature.
author: EAP

text: The pun on the word 'Kidd' is appreciable in no other language than the English.
author: EAP

text: But for this consideration I should have begun my attempts with the Spanish and French, as the tongues in which a secret of this kind would most naturally have been written by a pirate of the Spanish main.
author: EAP

text: As it was, I assumed the cryptograph to be English.
author: EAP

text: "You observe there are no divisions between the words.
author: EAP

text: Had there been divisions, the task would have been comparatively easy.
author: EAP

text: In such case I should have commenced with a collation and analysis of the shorter words, and, had a word of a single letter occurred, as is most likely, (a or I, for example,) I should have considered the solution as assured.
author: EAP

text: But, there being no division, my first step was to ascertain the predominant letters, as well as the least frequent.
author: EAP

text: Counting all, I constructed a table, thus: Of the character 8 there are 33. ; " 26.
author: EAP

text: "Now, in English, the letter which most frequently occurs is e. Afterwards, the succession runs thus: a o i d h n r s t u y c f g l m w b k p q x z. E however predominates so remarkably that an individual sentence of any length is rarely seen, in which it is not the prevailing character.
author: EAP

text: "Here, then, we have, in the very beginning, the groundwork for something more than a mere guess.
author: EAP

text: The general use which may be made of the table is obvious --but, in this particular cipher, we shall only very partially require its aid.
author: EAP

text: As our predominant character is 8, we will commence by assuming it as the e of the natural alphabet.
author: EAP

text: To verify the supposition, let us observe if the 8 be seen often in couples --for e is doubled with great frequency in English --in such words, for example, as 'meet,' 'fleet,' 'speed, 'seen,' 'been,' 'agree,' &c. In the present instance we see it doubled less than five times, although the cryptograph is brief.
author: EAP

text: "Let us assume 8, then, as e. Now, of all words in the language, 'the' is the most usual; let us see, therefore, whether they are not repetitions of any three characters in the same order of collocation, the last of them being 8.
author: EAP

text: If we discover repetitions of such letters, so arranged, they will most probably represent the word 'the.'
author: EAP

text: On inspection, we find no less than seven such arrangements, the characters being ;48.
author: EAP

text: We may, therefore, assume that the semicolon represents t, that 4 represents h, and that 8 represents e --the last being now well confirmed.
author: EAP

text: Thus a great step has been taken.
author: EAP

text: "But, having established a single word, we are enabled to establish a vastly important point; that is to say, several commencements and terminations of other words.
author: EAP

text: Let us refer, for example, to the last instance but one, in which the combination ;48 occurs --not far from the end of the cipher.
author: EAP

text: We know that the semicolon immediately ensuing is the commencement of a word, and, of the six characters succeeding this 'the,' we are cognizant of no less than five.
author: EAP

text: Let us set these characters down, thus, by the letters we know them to represent, leaving a space for the unknown-- t eeth "Here we are enabled, at once, to discard the 'th,' as forming no portion of the word commencing with the first t; since, by experiment of the entire alphabet for a letter adapted to the vacancy we perceive that no word can be formed of which this th can be a part.
author: EAP

text: We are thus narrowed into t ee and, going through the alphabet, if necessary, as before, we arrive at the word 'tree,' as the sole possible reading.
author: EAP

text: We thus gain another letter, r, represented by (, with the words 'the tree' in juxtaposition.
author: EAP

text: "Looking beyond these words, for a short distance, we again see the combination ;48, and employ it by way of termination to what immediately precedes.
author: EAP

text: We have thus this arrangement: the tree ;4(+?34 the, or substituting the natural letters, where known, it reads thus: the tree thr+?3h the.
author: EAP

text: "Now, if, in place of the unknown characters, we leave blank spaces, or substitute dots, we read thus: the tree thr...h the, when the word 'through' makes itself evident at once.
author: EAP

text: But this discovery gives us three new letters, o, u and g, represented by + ?
author: EAP

text: "Looking now, narrowly, through the cipher for combinations of known characters, we find, not very far from the beginning, this arrangement, 83(88, or egree, which, plainly, is the conclusion of the word 'degree,' and gives us another letter, d, represented by !.
author: EAP

text: "Four letters beyond the word 'degree,' we perceive the combination ;46(;88*.
author: EAP

text: "Translating the known characters, and representing the unknown by dots, as before, we read thus: th.rtee an arrangement immediately suggestive of the word 'thirteen,' and again furnishing us with two new characters, i and n, represented by 6 and *.
author: EAP

text: "Referring, now, to the beginning of the cryptograph, we find the combination, 53++!.
author: EAP

text: "Translating, as before, we obtain .good, which assures us that the first letter is A, and that the first two words are 'A good.'
author: EAP

text: "To avoid confusion, it is now time that we arrange our key, as far as discovered, in a tabular form.
author: EAP

text: It will stand thus: 5 represents a ! "
author: EAP

text: d 8 " e 3 " g 4 " h 6 " i * " n + " o ( " r ; " t "We have, therefore, no less than ten of the most important letters represented, and it will be unnecessary to proceed with the details of the solution.
author: EAP

text: I have said enough to convince you that ciphers of this nature are readily soluble, and to give you some insight into the rationale of their development.
author: EAP

text: But be assured that the specimen before us appertains to the very simplest species of cryptograph.
author: EAP

text: It now only remains to give you the full translation of the characters upon the parchment, as unriddled.
author: EAP

text: Here it is: 'A good glass in the bishop's hostel in the devil's seat twenty-one degrees and thirteen minutes northeast and by north main branch seventh limb east side shoot from the left eye of the death's-head a bee line from the tree through the shot fifty feet out.'"
author: EAP

text: "But," said I, "the enigma seems still in as bad a condition as ever.
author: EAP

text: How is it possible to extort a meaning from all this jargon about 'devil's seats,' 'death's-heads,' and 'bishop's hostel'?"
author: EAP

text: "I confess," replied Legrand, "that the matter still wears a serious aspect, when regarded with a casual glance.
author: EAP

text: My first endeavor was to divide the sentence into the natural division intended by the cryptographist."
author: EAP

text: "You mean, to punctuate it?"
author: EAP

text: "Something of that kind."
author: EAP

text: "But how was it possible to effect this?"
author: EAP

text: "I reflected that it had been a point with the writer to run his words together without division, so as to increase the difficulty of solution.
author: EAP

text: Now, a not overacute man, in pursuing such an object, would be nearly certain to overdo the matter.
author: EAP

text: When, in the course of his composition, he arrived at a break in his subject which would naturally require a pause, or a point, he would be exceedingly apt to run his characters, at this place, more than usually close together.
author: EAP

text: If you will observe the MS., in the present instance, you will easily detect five such cases of unusual crowding.
author: EAP

text: Acting on this hint, I made the division thus: 'A good glass in the bishop's hostel in the devil's --twenty-one degrees and thirteen minutes --northeast and by north --main branch seventh limb east side --shoot from the left eye of the death's-head --a bee-line from the tree through the shot fifty feet out.'"
author: EAP

text: "Even this division," said I, "leaves me still in the dark."
author: EAP

text: "It left me also in the dark," replied Legrand, "for a few days; during which I made diligent inquiry, in the neighborhood of Sullivan's Island, for any building which went by the name of the 'Bishop's Hotel'; for, of course, I dropped the obsolete word 'hostel.'
author: EAP

text: Gaining no information on the subject, I was on the point of extending my sphere of search, and proceeding in a more systematic manner, when, one morning, it entered into my head, quite suddenly, that this 'Bishop's Hostel' might have some reference to an old family, of the name of Bessop, which, time out of mind, had held possession of an ancient manor-house, about four miles to the northward of the Island.
author: EAP

text: I accordingly went over to the plantation, and reinstituted my inquiries among the older negroes of the place.
author: EAP

text: At length one of the most aged of the women said that she had heard of such a place as Bessop's Castle, and thought that she could guide me to it, but that it was not a castle, nor a tavern, but a high rock.
author: EAP

text: "I offered to pay her well for her trouble, and, after some demur, she consented to accompany me to the spot.
author: EAP

text: We found it without much difficulty, when, dismissing her, I proceeded to examine the place.
author: EAP

text: The 'castle' consisted of an irregular assemblage of cliffs and rocks --one of the latter being quite remarkable for its height as well as for its insulated and artificial appearance.
author: EAP

text: I clambered to its apex, and then felt much at a loss as to what should be next done.
author: EAP

text: "While I was busied in reflection, my eyes fell upon a narrow ledge in the eastern face of the rock, perhaps a yard below the summit on which I stood.
author: EAP

text: This ledge projected about eighteen inches, and was not more than a foot wide, while a niche in the cliff just above it, gave it a rude resemblance to one of the hollow-backed chairs used by our ancestors.
author: EAP

text: I made no doubt that here was the 'devil's-seat' alluded to in the MS., and now I seemed to grasp the full secret of the riddle.
author: EAP

text: "The 'good glass,' I knew, could have reference to nothing but a telescope; for the word 'glass' is rarely employed in any other sense by seamen.
author: EAP

text: Now here, I at once saw, was a telescope to be used, and a definite point of view, admitting no variation, from which to use it.
author: EAP

text: Nor did I hesitate to believe that the phrases, 'twenty-one degrees and thirteen minutes,' and northeast and by north,' were intended as directions for the levelling of the glass.
author: EAP

text: Greatly excited by these discoveries, I hurried home, procured a telescope, and returned to the rock.
author: EAP

text: "I let myself down to the ledge, and found that it was impossible to retain a seat on it unless in one particular position.
author: EAP

text: This fact confirmed my preconceived idea.
author: EAP

text: I proceeded to use the glass.
author: EAP

text: Of course, the 'twenty-one degrees and thirteen minutes' could allude to nothing but elevation above the visible horizon, since the horizontal direction was clearly indicated by the words, 'northeast and by north.'
author: EAP

text: This latter direction I at once established by means of a pocket-compass; then, pointing the glass as nearly at an angle of twenty-one degrees of elevation as I could do it by guess, I moved it cautiously up or down, until my attention was arrested by a circular rift or opening in the foliage of a large tree that overtopped its fellows in the distance.
author: EAP

text: In the centre of this rift I perceived a white spot, but could not, at first, distinguish what it was.
author: EAP

text: Adjusting the focus of the telescope, I again looked, and now made it out to be a human skull.
author: EAP

text: "On this discovery I was so sanguine as to consider the enigma solved; for the phrase 'main branch, seventh limb, east side,' could refer only to the position of the skull on the tree, while shoot from the left eye of the death's-head' admitted, also, of but one interpretation, in regard to a search for buried treasure.
author: EAP

text: Its decorations were rich, yet tattered and antique.
author: EAP

text: Its walls were hung with tapestry and bedecked with manifold and multiform armorial trophies, together with an unusually great number of very spirited modern paintings in frames of rich golden arabesque.
author: EAP

text: In these paintings, which depended from the walls not only in their main surfaces, but in very many nooks which the bizarre architecture of the chateau rendered necessary -- in these paintings my incipient delirium, perhaps, had caused me to take deep interest; so that I bade Pedro to close the heavy shutters of the room -- since it was already night -- to light the tongues of a tall candelabrum which stood by the head of my bed -- and to throw open far and wide the fringed curtains of black velvet which enveloped the bed itself.
author: EAP

text: I wished all this done that I might resign myself, if not to sleep, at least alternately to the contemplation of these pictures, and the perusal of a small volume which had been found upon the pillow, and which purported to criticise and describe them.

text: Long -- long I read -- and devoutly, devotedly I gazed.
author: EAP

text: Rapidly and gloriously the hours flew by and the deep midnight came.

text: The position of the candelabrum displeased me, and outreaching my hand with difficulty, rather than disturb my slumbering valet, I placed it so as to throw its rays more fully upon the book.

text: The rays of the numerous candles (for there were many) now fell within a niche of the room which had hitherto been thrown into deep shade by one of the bed-posts.
author: EAP

text: I thus saw in vivid light a picture all unnoticed before.

text: In a very few moments I again looked fixedly at the painting.
author: EAP

text: That I now saw aright I could not and would not doubt; for the first flashing of the candles upon that canvas had seemed to dissipate the dreamy stupor which was stealing over my senses, and to startle me at once into waking life.

text: The portrait, I have already said, was that of a young girl.

text: It was a mere head and shoulders, done in what is technically termed a vignette manner; much in the style of the favorite heads of Sully.

text: The arms, the bosom, and even the ends of the radiant hair melted imperceptibly into the vague yet deep shadow which formed the back-ground of the whole.

text: As a thing of art nothing could be more admirable than the painting itself.

text: The confession I am about to make will add another to the already almost innumerable instances of the truth of the position.
