text: My story requires that I should be somewhat minute.
author: EAP

text: I am still a very young man -- not yet twenty-two years of age.
author: EAP

text: My name, at present, is a very usual and rather plebeian one -- Simpson.
author: EAP

text: I say "at present;" for it is only lately that I have been so called -- having legislatively adopted this surname within the last year in order to receive a large inheritance left me by a distant male relative, Adolphus Simpson, Esq.
author: EAP

text: The bequest was conditioned upon my taking the name of the testator, -- the family, not the Christian name; my Christian name is Napoleon Bonaparte -- or, more properly, these are my first and middle appellations.
author: EAP

text: I assumed the name, Simpson, with some reluctance, as in my true patronym, Froissart, I felt a very pardonable pride -- believing that I could trace a descent from the immortal author of the Chronicles.
author: EAP

text: While on the subject of names, by the bye, I may mention a singular coincidence of sound attending the names of some of my immediate predecessors.
author: EAP

text: My father was a Monsieur Froissart, of Paris.
author: EAP

text: His wife -- my mother, whom he married at fifteen -- was a Mademoiselle Croissart, eldest daughter of Croissart the banker, whose wife, again, being only sixteen when married, was the eldest daughter of one Victor Voissart.
author: EAP

text: Monsieur Voissart, very singularly, had married a lady of similar name -- a Mademoiselle Moissart.
author: EAP

text: She, too, was quite a child when married; and her mother, also, Madame Moissart, was only fourteen when led to the altar.
author: EAP

text: These early marriages are usual in France.
author: EAP

text: Here, however, are Moissart, Voissart, Croissart, and Froissart, all in the direct line of descent.
author: EAP

text: My own name, though, as I say, became Simpson, by act of Legislature, and with so much repugnance on my part, that, at one period, I actually hesitated about accepting the legacy with the useless and annoying proviso attached.
author: EAP

text: As to personal endowments, I am by no means deficient.
author: EAP

text: On the contrary, I believe that I am well made, and possess what nine tenths of the world would call a handsome face.
author: EAP

text: In height I am five feet eleven.
author: EAP

text: My hair is black and curling.
author: EAP

text: My nose is sufficiently good.
author: EAP

text: My eyes are large and gray; and although, in fact they are weak a very inconvenient degree, still no defect in this regard would be suspected from their appearance.
author: EAP

text: The weakness itself, however, has always much annoyed me, and I have resorted to every remedy -- short of wearing glasses.
author: EAP

text: Being youthful and good-looking, I naturally dislike these, and have resolutely refused to employ them.
author: EAP

text: I know nothing, indeed, which so disfigures the countenance of a young person, or so impresses every feature with an air of demureness, if not altogether of sanctimoniousness and of age.
author: EAP

text: An eyeglass, on the other hand, has a savor of downright foppery and affectation.
author: EAP

text: I have hitherto managed as well as I could without either.
author: EAP

text: But something too much of these merely personal details, which, after all, are of little importance.
author: EAP

text: I will content myself with saying, in addition, that my temperament is sanguine, rash, ardent, enthusiastic -- and that all my life I have been a devoted admirer of the women.
author: EAP

text: One night last winter I entered a box at the P- -- Theatre, in company with a friend, Mr. Talbot.
author: EAP

text: It was an opera night, and the bills presented a very rare attraction, so that the house was excessively crowded.
author: EAP

text: We were in time, however, to obtain the front seats which had been reserved for us, and into which, with some little difficulty, we elbowed our way.
author: EAP

text: For two hours my companion, who was a musical fanatico, gave his undivided attention to the stage; and, in the meantime, I amused myself by observing the audience, which consisted, in chief part, of the very elite of the city.
author: EAP

text: Having satisfied myself upon this point, I was about turning my eyes to the prima donna, when they were arrested and riveted by a figure in one of the private boxes which had escaped my observation.
author: EAP

text: If I live a thousand years, I can never forget the intense emotion with which I regarded this figure.
author: EAP

text: It was that of a female, the most exquisite I had ever beheld.
author: EAP

text: The face was so far turned toward the stage that, for some minutes, I could not obtain a view of it -- but the form was divine; no other word can sufficiently express its magnificent proportion -- and even the term "divine" seems ridiculously feeble as I write it.
author: EAP

text: The magic of a lovely form in woman -- the necromancy of female gracefulness -- was always a power which I had found it impossible to resist, but here was grace personified, incarnate, the beau ideal of my wildest and most enthusiastic visions.
author: EAP

text: The figure, almost all of which the construction of the box permitted to be seen, was somewhat above the medium height, and nearly approached, without positively reaching, the majestic.
author: EAP

text: Its perfect fullness and tournure were delicious.
author: EAP

text: The head of which only the back was visible, rivalled in outline that of the Greek Psyche, and was rather displayed than concealed by an elegant cap of gaze aerienne, which put me in mind of the ventum textilem of Apuleius.
author: EAP

text: The right arm hung over the balustrade of the box, and thrilled every nerve of my frame with its exquisite symmetry.
author: EAP

text: Its upper portion was draperied by one of the loose open sleeves now in fashion.
author: EAP

text: This extended but little below the elbow.
author: EAP

text: Beneath it was worn an under one of some frail material, close-fitting, and terminated by a cuff of rich lace, which fell gracefully over the top of the hand, revealing only the delicate fingers, upon one of which sparkled a diamond ring, which I at once saw was of extraordinary value.
author: EAP

text: The admirable roundness of the wrist was well set off by a bracelet which encircled it, and which also was ornamented and clasped by a magnificent aigrette of jewels-telling, in words that could not be mistaken, at once of the wealth and fastidious taste of the wearer.
author: EAP

text: I gazed at this queenly apparition for at least half an hour, as if I had been suddenly converted to stone; and, during this period, I felt the full force and truth of all that has been said or sung concerning "love at first sight."
author: EAP

text: My feelings were totally different from any which I had hitherto experienced, in the presence of even the most celebrated specimens of female loveliness.
author: EAP

text: An unaccountable, and what I am compelled to consider a magnetic, sympathy of soul for soul, seemed to rivet, not only my vision, but my whole powers of thought and feeling, upon the admirable object before me.
author: EAP

text: I saw -- I felt -- I knew that I was deeply, madly, irrevocably in love -- and this even before seeing the face of the person beloved.
author: EAP

text: So intense, indeed, was the passion that consumed me, that I really believe it would have received little if any abatement had the features, yet unseen, proved of merely ordinary character, so anomalous is the nature of the only true love -- of the love at first sight -- and so little really dependent is it upon the external conditions which only seem to create and control it.
author: EAP

text: While I was thus wrapped in admiration of this lovely vision, a sudden disturbance among the audience caused her to turn her head partially toward me, so that I beheld the entire profile of the face.

text: Its beauty even exceeded my anticipations -- and yet there was something about it which disappointed me without my being able to tell exactly what it was.

text: This state of feeling arose, perhaps, from the Madonna-like and matronly air of the face; and yet I at once understood that it could not have arisen entirely from this.

text: In fact, I was just in that condition of mind which prepares a young and susceptible man for any act of extravagance.
author: EAP

text: Had the lady been alone, I should undoubtedly have entered her box and accosted her at all hazards; but, fortunately, she was attended by two companions -- a gentleman, and a strikingly beautiful woman, to all appearance a few years younger than herself.

text: DURING the autumn of 18--, while on a tour through the extreme southern provinces of France, my route led me within a few miles of a certain Maison de Sante or private mad-house, about which I had heard much in Paris from my medical friends.
author: EAP

text: As I had never visited a place of the kind, I thought the opportunity too good to be lost; and so proposed to my travelling companion (a gentleman with whom I had made casual acquaintance a few days before) that we should turn aside, for an hour or so, and look through the establishment.
author: EAP

text: To this he objected -- pleading haste in the first place, and, in the second, a very usual horror at the sight of a lunatic.

text: I had heard, at Paris, that the institution of Monsieur Maillard was managed upon what is vulgarly termed the "system of soothing" -- that all punishments were avoided -- that even confinement was seldom resorted to -- that the patients, while secretly watched, were left much apparent liberty, and that most of them were permitted to roam about the house and grounds in the ordinary apparel of persons in right mind.

text: "And I to your long life."
author: EAP

text: He again took my arm, and we proceeded.
author: EAP

author: EAP

text: "The Montresors," I replied, "were a great and numerous family."
author: EAP

text: "I forget your arms."

author: EAP

text: My own fancy grew warm with the Medoc.

text: We had passed through long walls of piled skeletons, with casks and puncheons intermingling, into the inmost recesses of the catacombs.
author: EAP

text: I paused again, and this time I made bold to seize Fortunato by an arm above the elbow.
author: EAP

author: EAP

author: EAP

author: EAP

text: Your cough --" "It is nothing," he said; "let us go on.

author: EAP

text: His eyes flashed with a fierce light.
author: EAP

author: EAP

author: EAP

text: "You do not comprehend?"
author: EAP

author: EAP

author: EAP

author: EAP

text: "Yes, yes," I said; "yes, yes."
author: EAP

text: "A mason," I replied.
author: EAP

text: "A sign," he said, "a sign."
author: EAP

text: "It is this," I answered, producing from beneath the folds of my roquelaire a trowel.
author: EAP

text: "You jest," he exclaimed, recoiling a few paces.
author: EAP

text: "But let us proceed to the Amontillado."
author: EAP

text: "Be it so," I said, replacing the tool beneath the cloak and again offering him my arm.
author: EAP

text: He leaned upon it heavily.
author: EAP

text: We continued our route in search of the Amontillado.
author: EAP

text: We passed through a range of low arches, descended, passed on, and descending again, arrived at a deep crypt, in which the foulness of the air caused our flambeaux rather to glow than flame.
author: EAP

text: At the most remote end of the crypt there appeared another less spacious.
author: EAP

text: Its walls had been lined with human remains, piled to the vault overhead, in the fashion of the great catacombs of Paris.
author: EAP

text: Three sides of this interior crypt were still ornamented in this manner.
author: EAP

text: From the fourth side the bones had been thrown down, and lay promiscuously upon the earth, forming at one point a mound of some size.
author: EAP

text: Within the wall thus exposed by the displacing of the bones, we perceived a still interior crypt or recess, in depth about four feet, in width three, in height six or seven.
author: EAP

text: It seemed to have been constructed for no especial use within itself, but formed merely the interval between two of the colossal supports of the roof of the catacombs, and was backed by one of their circumscribing walls of solid granite.
author: EAP

text: It was in vain that Fortunato, uplifting his dull torch, endeavoured to pry into the depth of the recess.
author: EAP

text: Its termination the feeble light did not enable us to see.
author: EAP

text: "Proceed," I said; "herein is the Amontillado.
author: EAP

text: As for Luchresi --" "He is an ignoramus," interrupted my friend, as he stepped unsteadily forward, while I followed immediately at his heels.
author: EAP

text: In an instant he had reached the extremity of the niche, and finding his progress arrested by the rock, stood stupidly bewildered.
author: EAP

text: A moment more and I had fettered him to the granite.
author: EAP

text: In its surface were two iron staples, distant from each other about two feet, horizontally.
author: EAP

text: From one of these depended a short chain, from the other a padlock.
author: EAP

text: Throwing the links about his waist, it was but the work of a few seconds to secure it.
author: EAP

text: He was too much astounded to resist.
author: EAP

text: Withdrawing the key I stepped back from the recess.
author: EAP

text: "Pass your hand," I said, "over the wall; you cannot help feeling the nitre.
author: EAP

text: Indeed, it is very damp.
author: EAP

text: Once more let me implore you to return.
author: EAP

text: Then I must positively leave you.
author: EAP

text: But I must first render you all the little attentions in my power."
author: EAP

text: ejaculated my friend, not yet recovered from his astonishment.

text: "True," I replied; "the Amontillado."
author: EAP

text: As I said these words I busied myself among the pile of bones of which I have before spoken.
author: EAP

text: Throwing them aside, I soon uncovered a quantity of building stone and mortar.
author: EAP

text: With these materials and with the aid of my trowel, I began vigorously to wall up the entrance of the niche.
author: EAP

text: I had scarcely laid the first tier of the masonry when I discovered that the intoxication of Fortunato had in a great measure worn off.
author: EAP

text: The earliest indication I had of this was a low moaning cry from the depth of the recess.
author: EAP

text: It was not the cry of a drunken man.
author: EAP

text: There was then a long and obstinate silence.
author: EAP

text: I laid the second tier, and the third, and the fourth; and then I heard the furious vibrations of the chain.
author: EAP

text: The noise lasted for several minutes, during which, that I might hearken to it with the more satisfaction, I ceased my labours and sat down upon the bones.
author: EAP

text: When at last the clanking subsided, I resumed the trowel, and finished without interruption the fifth, the sixth, and the seventh tier.
author: EAP

text: The wall was now nearly upon a level with my breast.
author: EAP

text: I again paused, and holding the flambeaux over the mason-work, threw a few feeble rays upon the figure within.
author: EAP

text: A succession of loud and shrill screams, bursting suddenly from the throat of the chained form, seemed to thrust me violently back.
author: EAP

text: For a brief moment I hesitated, I trembled.
author: EAP

text: Unsheathing my rapier, I began to grope with it about the recess; but the thought of an instant reassured me.
author: EAP

text: I placed my hand upon the solid fabric of the catacombs, and felt satisfied.
author: EAP

text: I reapproached the wall; I replied to the yells of him who clamoured.
author: EAP

text: I re-echoed, I aided, I surpassed them in volume and in strength.
author: EAP

text: I did this, and the clamourer grew still.
author: EAP

text: It was now midnight, and my task was drawing to a close.
author: EAP

text: I had completed the eighth, the ninth and the tenth tier.
author: EAP

text: I had finished a portion of the last and the eleventh; there remained but a single stone to be fitted and plastered in.
author: EAP

text: I struggled with its weight; I placed it partially in its destined position.
author: EAP

text: But now there came from out the niche a low laugh that erected the hairs upon my head.
author: EAP

text: It was succeeded by a sad voice, which I had difficulty in recognizing as that of the noble Fortunato.
author: EAP

text: The voice said-- "Ha!
author: EAP

text: --a very good joke, indeed --an excellent jest.
author: EAP

text: We will have many a rich laugh about it at the palazzo --he!
author: EAP

text: --over our wine --he!
author: EAP

text: But is it not getting late?
author: EAP

text: Will not they be awaiting us at the palazzo, the Lady Fortunato and the rest?
author: EAP

text: Let us be gone."
author: EAP

text: "Yes," I said, "let us be gone."
author: EAP

text: "For the love of God, Montresor!"
author: EAP

text: "Yes," I said, "for the love of God!"
author: EAP

text: But to these words I hearkened in vain for a reply.
author: EAP

text: I called aloud -- "Fortunato!"
author: EAP

text: I called again -- "Fortunato!"
author: EAP

author: EAP

text: There came forth in return only a jingling of the bells.
author: EAP

text: My heart grew sick; it was the dampness of the catacombs that made it so.
author: EAP

text: I hastened to make an end of my labour.
author: EAP

text: I forced the last stone into its position; I plastered it up.
author: EAP

text: Against the new masonry I re-erected the old rampart of bones.
author: EAP

text: For the half of a century no mortal has disturbed them.

text: At Paris, just after dark one gusty evening in the autumn of 18--, I was enjoying the twofold luxury of meditation and a meerschaum, in company with my friend C. Auguste Dupin, in his little back library, or book-closet, au troisieme, No.
author: EAP

text: 33, Rue Dunot, Faubourg St. Germain.
author: EAP

text: For one hour at least we had maintained a profound silence; while each, to any casual observer, might have seemed intently and exclusively occupied with the curling eddies of smoke that oppressed the atmosphere of the chamber.
author: EAP

text: For myself, however, I was mentally discussing certain topics which had formed matter for conversation between us at an earlier period of the evening; I mean the affair of the Rue Morgue, and the mystery attending the murder of Marie Roget.
author: EAP

text: I looked upon it, therefore, as something of a coincidence, when the door of our apartment was thrown open and admitted our old acquaintance, Monsieur G--, the Prefect of the Parisian police.
author: EAP

text: We gave him a hearty welcome; for there was nearly half as much of the entertaining as of the contemptible about the man, and we had not seen him for several years.
author: EAP

text: We had been sitting in the dark, and Dupin now arose for the purpose of lighting a lamp, but sat down again, without doing so, upon G.'s saying that he had called to consult us, or rather to ask the opinion of my friend, about some official business which had occasioned a great deal of trouble.
author: EAP

text: "If it is any point requiring reflection," observed Dupin, as he forbore to enkindle the wick, "we shall examine it to better purpose in the dark."
author: EAP

text: "That is another of your odd notions," said the Prefect, who had a fashion of calling every thing "odd" that was beyond his comprehension, and thus lived amid an absolute legion of "oddities."
author: EAP

text: "Very true," said Dupin, as he supplied his visitor with a pipe, and rolled towards him a comfortable chair.
author: EAP

text: "And what is the difficulty now?"
author: EAP

text: "Nothing more in the assassination way, I hope?"
author: EAP

text: "Oh no; nothing of that nature.
author: EAP

text: The fact is, the business is very simple indeed, and I make no doubt that we can manage it sufficiently well ourselves; but then I thought Dupin would like to hear the details of it, because it is so excessively odd."
author: EAP

text: "Simple and odd," said Dupin.
author: EAP

text: "Why, yes; and not exactly that, either.
author: EAP

text: The fact is, we have all been a good deal puzzled because the affair is so simple, and yet baffles us altogether."
author: EAP

text: "Perhaps it is the very simplicity of the thing which puts you at fault," said my friend.
author: EAP

text: "What nonsense you do talk!"
author: EAP

text: replied the Prefect, laughing heartily.
author: EAP

text: "Perhaps the mystery is a little too plain," said Dupin.
author: EAP

text: who ever heard of such an idea?"
author: EAP

text: "A little too self-evident."
author: EAP

text: --roared our visitor, profoundly amused, "oh, Dupin, you will be the death of me yet!"
author: EAP

text: "And what, after all, is the matter on hand?"
author: EAP

text: "Why, I will tell you," replied the Prefect, as he gave a long, steady, and contemplative puff, and settled himself in his chair.
author: EAP

text: "I will tell you in a few words; but, before I begin, let me caution you that this is an affair demanding the greatest secrecy, and that I should most probably lose the position I now hold, were it known that I confided it to any one.
author: EAP

text: "Or not," said Dupin.
author: EAP

text: "Well, then; I have received personal information, from a very high quarter, that a certain document of the last importance, has been purloined from the royal apartments.
author: EAP

text: The individual who purloined it is known; this beyond a doubt; he was seen to take it.
author: EAP

text: It is known, also, that it still remains in his possession."
author: EAP

text: "How is this known?"
author: EAP

text: "It is clearly inferred," replied the Prefect, "from the nature of the document, and from the nonappearance of certain results which would at once arise from its passing out of the robber's possession; --that is to say, from his employing it as he must design in the end to employ it."
author: EAP

text: "Be a little more explicit," I said.
author: EAP

text: "Well, I may venture so far as to say that the paper gives its holder a certain power in a certain quarter where such power is immensely valuable."
author: EAP

text: The Prefect was fond of the cant of diplomacy.
author: EAP

text: "Still I do not quite understand," said Dupin.
author: EAP

text: Well; the disclosure of the document to a third person, who shall be nameless, would bring in question the honor of a personage of most exalted station; and this fact gives the holder of the document an ascendancy over the illustrious personage whose honor and peace are so jeopardized."
author: EAP

text: "But this ascendancy," I interposed, "would depend upon the robber's knowledge of the loser's knowledge of the robber.
author: EAP

text: Who would dare--" "The thief," said G., is the Minister D--, who dares all things, those unbecoming as well as those becoming a man.
author: EAP

text: The method of the theft was not less ingenious than bold.
author: EAP

text: The document in question --a letter, to be frank --had been received by the personage robbed while alone in the royal boudoir.
author: EAP

text: During its perusal she was suddenly interrupted by the entrance of the other exalted personage from whom especially it was her wish to conceal it.
author: EAP

text: After a hurried and vain endeavor to thrust it in a drawer, she was forced to place it, open as it was, upon a table.
author: EAP

text: The address, however, was uppermost, and, the contents thus unexposed, the letter escaped notice.
author: EAP

text: At this juncture enters the Minister D--.
author: EAP

text: His lynx eye immediately perceives the paper, recognises the handwriting of the address, observes the confusion of the personage addressed, and fathoms her secret.
author: EAP

text: After some business transactions, hurried through in his ordinary manner, he produces a letter somewhat similar to the one in question, opens it, pretends to read it, and then places it in close juxtaposition to the other.
author: EAP

text: Again he converses, for some fifteen minutes, upon the public affairs.
author: EAP

text: At length, in taking leave, he takes also from the table the letter to which he had no claim.
author: EAP

text: Its rightful owner saw, but, of course, dared not call attention to the act, in the presence of the third personage who stood at her elbow.
author: EAP

text: The minister decamped; leaving his own letter --one of no importance --upon the table."
author: EAP

text: "Here, then," said Dupin to me, "you have precisely what you demand to make the ascendancy complete --the robber's knowledge of the loser's knowledge of the robber."
author: EAP

text: "Yes," replied the Prefect; "and the power thus attained has, for some months past, been wielded, for political purposes, to a very dangerous extent.
author: EAP

text: The personage robbed is more thoroughly convinced, every day, of the necessity of reclaiming her letter.
author: EAP

text: But this, of course, cannot be done openly.
author: EAP

text: In fine, driven to despair, she has committed the matter to me."
author: EAP

text: "Than whom," said Dupin, amid a perfect whirlwind of smoke, "no more sagacious agent could, I suppose, be desired, or even imagined."
author: EAP

text: "You flatter me," replied the Prefect; "but it is possible that some such opinion may have been entertained."
author: EAP

text: "It is clear," said I, "as you observe, that the letter is still in possession of the minister; since it is this possession, and not any employment of the letter, which bestows the power.
author: EAP

text: With the employment the power departs."
author: EAP

text: "True," said G. "and upon this conviction I proceeded.
author: EAP

text: My first care was to make thorough search of the minister's hotel; and here my chief embarrassment lay in the necessity of searching without his knowledge.
author: EAP

text: Beyond all things, I have been warned of the danger which would result from giving him reason to suspect our design."
author: EAP

text: "But," said I, "you are quite au fait in these investigations.
author: EAP

text: The Parisian police have done this thing often before."
author: EAP

text: "Oh yes; and for this reason I did not despair.
author: EAP

text: The habits of the minister gave me, too, a great advantage.
author: EAP

text: He is frequently absent from home all night.
author: EAP

text: His servants are by no means numerous.
author: EAP

text: They sleep at a distance from their master's apartment, and, being chiefly Neapolitans, are readily made drunk.
author: EAP

text: I have keys, as you know, with which I can open any chamber or cabinet in Paris.
author: EAP

text: For three months a night has not passed, during the greater part of which I have not been engaged, personally, in ransacking the D-- Hotel.
author: EAP

text: My honor is interested, and, to mention a great secret, the reward is enormous.
author: EAP

text: So I did not abandon the search until I had become fully satisfied that the thief is a more astute man than myself.
author: EAP

text: I fancy that I have investigated every nook and corner of the premises in which it is possible that the paper can be concealed."
author: EAP

text: "But is it not possible," I suggested, "that although the letter may be in possession of the minister, as it unquestionably is, he may have concealed it elsewhere than upon his own premises?"
author: EAP

text: "This is barely possible," said Dupin.
author: EAP

text: "The present peculiar condition of affairs at court, and especially of those intrigues in which D-- is known to be involved, would render the instant availability of the document --its susceptibility of being produced at a moment's notice --a point of nearly equal importance with its possession."
author: EAP

text: "Its susceptibility of being produced?"
author: EAP

text: "That is to say, of being destroyed," said Dupin.
author: EAP

text: "True," I observed; "the paper is clearly then upon the premises.
author: EAP

text: As for its being upon the person of the minister, we may consider that as out of the question."
author: EAP

text: "Entirely," said the Prefect.
author: EAP

text: "He has been twice waylaid, as if by footpads, and his person rigorously searched under my own inspection.
author: EAP

text: "You might have spared yourself this trouble," said Dupin.
author: EAP

text: "D--, I presume, is not altogether a fool, and, if not, must have anticipated these waylayings, as a matter of course."
author: EAP

text: "Not altogether a fool," said G., "but then he's a poet, which I take to be only one remove from a fool."
author: EAP

text: "True," said Dupin, after a long and thoughtful whiff from his meerschaum, "although I have been guilty of certain doggerel myself."
author: EAP

text: "Suppose you detail," said I, "the particulars of your search."
author: EAP

text: "Why the fact is, we took our time, and we searched every where.
author: EAP

text: I have had long experience in these affairs.
author: EAP

text: I took the entire building, room by room; devoting the nights of a whole week to each.
author: EAP

text: We examined, first, the furniture of each apartment.
author: EAP

text: We opened every possible drawer; and I presume you know that, to a properly trained police agent, such a thing as a secret drawer is impossible.
author: EAP

text: Any man is a dolt who permits a 'secret' drawer to escape him in a search of this kind.
author: EAP

text: The thing is so plain.
author: EAP

text: There is a certain amount of bulk --of space --to be accounted for in every cabinet.
author: EAP

text: Then we have accurate rules.
author: EAP

text: The fiftieth part of a line could not escape us.
author: EAP

text: After the cabinets we took the chairs.
author: EAP

text: The cushions we probed with the fine long needles you have seen me employ.
author: EAP

text: From the tables we removed the tops."
author: EAP

text: "Sometimes the top of a table, or other similarly arranged piece of furniture, is removed by the person wishing to conceal an article; then the leg is excavated, the article deposited within the cavity, and the top replaced.
author: EAP

text: The bottoms and tops of bedposts are employed in the same way."
author: EAP

text: "But could not the cavity be detected by sounding?"
author: EAP

text: "By no means, if, when the article is deposited, a sufficient wadding of cotton be placed around it.
author: EAP

text: Besides, in our case, we were obliged to proceed without noise."
author: EAP

text: "But you could not have removed --you could not have taken to pieces all articles of furniture in which it would have been possible to make a deposit in the manner you mention.
author: EAP

text: A letter may be compressed into a thin spiral roll, not differing much in shape or bulk from a large knitting-needle, and in this form it might be inserted into the rung of a chair, for example.
author: EAP

text: You did not take to pieces all the chairs?"
author: EAP

text: "Certainly not; but we did better --we examined the rungs of every chair in the hotel, and, indeed, the jointings of every description of furniture, by the aid of a most powerful microscope.
author: EAP

text: Had there been any traces of recent disturbance we should not have failed to detect it instantly.
author: EAP

text: A single grain of gimlet-dust, for example, would have been as obvious as an apple.
author: EAP

text: Any disorder in the glueing --any unusual gaping in the joints --would have sufficed to insure detection."
author: EAP

text: "I presume you looked to the mirrors, between the boards and the plates, and you probed the beds and the bed-clothes, as well as the curtains and carpets."
author: EAP

text: "That of course; and when we had absolutely completed every particle of the furniture in this way, then we examined the house itself.
author: EAP

text: We divided its entire surface into compartments, which we numbered, so that none might be missed; then we scrutinized each individual square inch throughout the premises, including the two houses immediately adjoining, with the microscope, as before."
author: EAP

text: "The two houses adjoining!"
author: EAP

text: I exclaimed; "you must have had a great deal of trouble."
author: EAP

text: "We had; but the reward offered is prodigious.
author: EAP

text: "You include the grounds about the houses?"
author: EAP

text: "All the grounds are paved with brick.
author: EAP

text: They gave us comparatively little trouble.
author: EAP

text: We examined the moss between the bricks, and found it undisturbed."
author: EAP

text: "You looked among D--'s papers, of course, and into the books of the library?"
author: EAP

text: "Certainly; we opened every package and parcel; we not only opened every book, but we turned over every leaf in each volume, not contenting ourselves with a mere shake, according to the fashion of some of our police officers.
author: EAP

text: We also measured the thickness of every book-cover, with the most accurate admeasurement, and applied to each the most jealous scrutiny of the microscope.
author: EAP

text: Had any of the bindings been recently meddled with, it would have been utterly impossible that the fact should have escaped observation.
author: EAP

text: Some five or six volumes, just from the hands of the binder, we carefully probed, longitudinally, with the needles."
author: EAP

text: "You explored the floors beneath the carpets?"
author: EAP

text: We removed every carpet, and examined the boards with the microscope."
author: EAP

text: "And the paper on the walls?"
author: EAP

text: "You looked into the cellars?"
author: EAP

text: "Then," I said, "you have been making a miscalculation, and the letter is not upon the premises, as you suppose.
author: EAP

text: "I fear you are right there," said the Prefect.
author: EAP

text: "And now, Dupin, what would you advise me to do?"
author: EAP

text: "To make a thorough re-search of the premises."
author: EAP

text: "That is absolutely needless," replied G--.
author: EAP

text: "I am not more sure that I breathe than I am that the letter is not at the Hotel."
author: EAP

text: "I have no better advice to give you," said Dupin.
author: EAP

text: "You have, of course, an accurate description of the letter?"
author: EAP

text: --And here the Prefect, producing a memorandum-book, proceeded to read aloud a minute account of the internal, and especially of the external appearance of the missing document.
author: EAP

text: Soon after finishing the perusal of this description, he took his departure, more entirely depressed in spirits than I had ever known the good gentleman before.
author: EAP

text: In about a month afterwards he paid us another visit, and found us occupied very nearly as before.
author: EAP

text: He took a pipe and a chair and entered into some ordinary conversation.
author: EAP

text: At length I said,-- "Well, but G--, what of the purloined letter?
author: EAP

text: I presume you have at last made up your mind that there is no such thing as overreaching the Minister?"
author: EAP

text: "Confound him, say I --yes; I made the reexamination, however, as Dupin suggested --but it was all labor lost, as I knew it would be."
author: EAP

text: "How much was the reward offered, did you say?"
author: EAP

text: "Why, a very great deal --a very liberal reward --I don't like to say how much, precisely; but one thing I will say, that I wouldn't mind giving my individual check for fifty thousand francs to any one who could obtain me that letter.
author: EAP

text: The fact is, it is becoming of more and more importance every day; and the reward has been lately doubled.
author: EAP

text: If it were trebled, however, I could do no more than I have done."
author: EAP

text: "Why, yes," said Dupin, drawlingly, between the whiffs of his meerschaum, "I really --think, G--, you have not exerted yourself--to the utmost in this matter.
author: EAP

text: You might --do a little more, I think, eh?"
author: EAP

text: "Why --puff, puff --you might --puff, puff --employ counsel in the matter, eh?
author: EAP

text: Do you remember the story they tell of Abernethy?"
author: EAP

text: But, once upon a time, a certain rich miser conceived the design of spunging upon this Abernethy for a medical opinion.
author: EAP

text: Getting up, for this purpose, an ordinary conversation in a private company, he insinuated his case to the physician, as that of an imaginary individual.
author: EAP

text: "'We will suppose,' said the miser, 'that his symptoms are such and such; now, doctor, what would you have directed him to take?'
author: EAP

text: said Abernethy, 'why, take advice, to be sure.'"
author: EAP

text: "But," said the Prefect, a little discomposed, "I am perfectly willing to take advice, and to pay for it.
author: EAP

text: I would really give fifty thousand francs to any one who would aid me in the matter."
author: EAP

text: "In that case," replied Dupin, opening a drawer, and producing a check-book, "you may as well fill me up a check for the amount mentioned.
author: EAP

text: When you have signed it, I will hand you the letter."
author: EAP

text: The Prefect appeared absolutely thunderstricken.
author: EAP

text: For some minutes he remained speechless and motionless, less, looking incredulously at my friend with open mouth, and eyes that seemed starting from their sockets; then, apparently in some measure, he seized a pen, and after several pauses and vacant stares, finally filled up and signed a check for fifty thousand francs, and handed it across the table to Dupin.
author: EAP

text: The latter examined it carefully and deposited it in his pocket-book; then, unlocking an escritoire, took thence a letter and gave it to the Prefect.
author: EAP

text: This functionary grasped it in a perfect agony of joy, opened it with a trembling hand, cast a rapid glance at its contents, and then, scrambling and struggling to the door, rushed at length unceremoniously from the room and from the house, without having uttered a syllable since Dupin had requested him to fill up the check.
author: EAP

text: When he had gone, my friend entered into some explanations.
author: EAP

text: "The Parisian police," he said, "are exceedingly able in their way.
author: EAP

text: They are persevering, ingenious, cunning, and thoroughly versed in the knowledge which their duties seem chiefly to demand.
author: EAP

text: Thus, when G-- detailed to us his mode of searching the premises at the Hotel D--, I felt entire confidence in his having made a satisfactory investigation --so far as his labors extended."
author: EAP

text: "So far as his labors extended?"
author: EAP

text: "The measures adopted were not only the best of their kind, but carried out to absolute perfection.
author: EAP

text: Had the letter been deposited within the range of their search, these fellows would, beyond a question, have found it."
author: EAP

text: I merely laughed --but he seemed quite serious in all that he said.
author: EAP

text: "The measures, then," he continued, "were good in their kind, and well executed; their defect lay in their being inapplicable to the case, and to the man.
author: EAP

text: A certain set of highly ingenious resources are, with the Prefect, a sort of Procrustean bed, to which he forcibly adapts his designs.
author: EAP

text: But he perpetually errs by being too deep or too shallow, for the matter in hand; and many a schoolboy is a better reasoner than he.
author: EAP

text: I knew one about eight years of age, whose success at guessing in the game of 'even and odd' attracted universal admiration.
author: EAP

text: This game is simple, and is played with marbles.
author: EAP

text: One player holds in his hand a number of these toys, and demands of another whether that number is even or odd.
author: EAP

text: If the guess is right, the guesser wins one; if wrong, he loses one.
author: EAP

text: The boy to whom I allude won all the marbles of the school.
author: EAP

text: Of course he had some principle of guessing; and this lay in mere observation and admeasurement of the astuteness of his opponents.
author: EAP

text: For example, an arrant simpleton is his opponent, and, holding up his closed hand, asks, 'are they even or odd?'
author: EAP

text: Our schoolboy replies, 'odd,' and loses; but upon the second trial he wins, for he then says to himself, the simpleton had them even upon the first trial, and his amount of cunning is just sufficient to make him have them odd upon the second; I will therefore guess odd'; --he guesses odd, and wins.
author: EAP

text: Now, with a simpleton a degree above the first, he would have reasoned thus: 'This fellow finds that in the first instance I guessed odd, and, in the second, he will propose to himself upon the first impulse, a simple variation from even to odd, as did the first simpleton; but then a second thought will suggest that this is too simple a variation, and finally he will decide upon putting it even as before.
author: EAP

text: I will therefore guess even' guesses even, and wins.
author: EAP

text: Now this mode of reasoning in the schoolboy, whom his fellows termed "lucky," --what, in its last analysis, is it?"
author: EAP

text: "It is merely," I said, "an identification of the reasoner's intellect with that of his opponent."
author: EAP

text: "It is," said Dupin;" and, upon inquiring of the boy by what means he effected the thorough identification in which his success consisted, I received answer as follows: 'When I wish to find out how wise, or how stupid, or how good, or how wicked is any one, or what are his thoughts at the moment, I fashion the expression of my face, as accurately as possible, in accordance with the expression of his, and then wait to see what thoughts or sentiments arise in my mind or heart, as if to match or correspond with the expression.'
author: EAP

text: This response of the schoolboy lies at the bottom of all the spurious profundity which has been attributed to Rochefoucauld, to La Bougive, to Machiavelli, and to Campanella."
author: EAP

text: "And the identification," I said, "of the reasoner's intellect with that of his opponent, depends, if I understand you aright upon the accuracy with which the opponent's intellect is admeasured."
author: EAP

text: "For its practical value it depends upon this," replied Dupin; and the Prefect and his cohort fall so frequently, first, by default of this identification, and, secondly, by ill-admeasurement, or rather through non-admeasurement, of the intellect with which they are engaged.
author: EAP

text: They consider only their own ideas of ingenuity; and, in searching for anything hidden, advert only to the modes in which they would have hidden it.
author: EAP

text: They are right in this much --that their own ingenuity is a faithful representative of that of the mass; but when the cunning of the individual felon is diverse in character from their own, the felon foils them, of course.
author: EAP

text: This always happens when it is above their own, and very usually when it is below.
author: EAP

text: They have no variation of principle in their investigations; at best, when urged by some unusual emergency --by some extraordinary reward --they extend or exaggerate their old modes of practice, without touching their principles.
author: EAP

text: What, for example, in this case of D--, has been done to vary the principle of action?
author: EAP

text: What is all this boring, and probing, and sounding, and scrutinizing with the microscope, and dividing the surface of the building into registered square inches --what is it all but an exaggeration of the application of the one principle or set of principles of search, which are based upon the one set of notions regarding human ingenuity, to which the Prefect, in the long routine of his duty, has been accustomed?
author: EAP

text: Do you not see he has taken it for granted that all men proceed to conceal a letter, --not exactly in a gimlet-hole bored in a chair-leg --but, at least, in some hole or corner suggested by the same tenor of thought which would urge a man to secrete a letter in a gimlet-hole bored in a chair-leg?
author: EAP

text: And do you not see also, that such recherches nooks for concealment are adapted only for ordinary occasions, and would be adopted only by ordinary intellects; for, in all cases of concealment, a disposal of the article concealed --a disposal of it in this recherche manner, --is, in the very first instance, presumable and presumed; and thus its discovery depends, not at all upon the acumen, but altogether upon the mere care, patience, and determination of the seekers; and where the case is of importance --or, what amounts to the same thing in the policial eyes, when the reward is of magnitude, --the qualities in question have never been known to fall.
author: EAP

text: You will now understand what I meant in suggesting that, had the purloined letter been hidden anywhere within the limits of the Prefect's examination --in other words, had the principle of its concealment been comprehended within the principles of the Prefect --its discovery would have been a matter altogether beyond question.
author: EAP

text: This functionary, however, has been thoroughly mystified; and the remote source of his defeat lies in the supposition that the Minister is a fool, because he has acquired renown as a poet.
author: EAP

text: All fools are poets; this the Prefect feels; and he is merely guilty of a non distributio medii in thence inferring that all poets are fools."
author: EAP

text: "But is this really the poet?"
author: EAP

text: "There are two brothers, I know; and both have attained reputation in letters.
author: EAP

text: The Minister I believe has written learnedly on the Differential Calculus.
author: EAP

text: He is a mathematician, and no poet."
author: EAP

text: "You are mistaken; I know him well; he is both.
author: EAP

text: As poet and mathematician, he would reason well; as mere mathematician, he could not have reasoned at all, and thus would have been at the mercy of the Prefect."
author: EAP

text: "You surprise me," I said, "by these opinions, which have been contradicted by the voice of the world.
author: EAP

text: You do not mean to set at naught the well-digested idea of centuries.
author: EAP

text: The mathematical reason has long been regarded as the reason par excellence.
author: EAP

text: "'Il y a a parier,'" replied Dupin, quoting from Chamfort, "'que toute idee publique, toute convention recue, est une sottise, car elle a convenu au plus grand nombre.'
author: EAP

text: The mathematicians, I grant you, have done their best to promulgate the popular error to which you allude, and which is none the less an error for its promulgation as truth.
author: EAP

text: With an art worthy a better cause, for example, they have insinuated the term 'analysis' into application to algebra.
author: EAP

text: The French are the originators of this particular deception; but if a term is of any importance --if words derive any value from applicability --then 'analysis' conveys 'algebra' about as much as, in Latin, 'ambitus' implies 'ambition,' 'religio' religion or 'homines honesti,' a set of honorable men."
author: EAP

text: "You have a quarrel on hand, I see," said I, "with some of the algebraists of Paris; but proceed."
author: EAP

text: "I dispute the availability, and thus the value, of that reason which is cultivated in any especial form other than the abstractly logical.
author: EAP

text: I dispute, in particular, the reason educed by mathematical study.
author: EAP

text: The mathematics are the science of form and quantity; mathematical reasoning is merely logic applied to observation upon form and quantity.
author: EAP

text: The great error lies in supposing that even the truths of what is called pure algebra, are abstract or general truths.
author: EAP

text: And this error is so egregious that I am confounded at the universality with which it has been received.
author: EAP

text: Mathematical axioms are not axioms of general truth.
author: EAP

text: What is true of relation --of form and quantity --is often grossly false in regard to morals, for example.
author: EAP

text: In this latter science it is very usually untrue that the aggregated parts are equal to the whole.
author: EAP

text: In chemistry also the axiom fails.
author: EAP

text: In the consideration of motive it fails; for two motives, each of a given value, have not, necessarily, a value when united, equal to the sum of their values apart.
author: EAP

text: There are numerous other mathematical truths which are only truths within the limits of relation.
author: EAP

text: But the mathematician argues, from his finite truths, through habit, as if they were of an absolutely general applicability --as the world indeed imagines them to be.
author: EAP

text: Bryant, in his very learned 'Mythology,' mentions an analogous source of error, when he says that 'although the Pagan fables are not believed, yet we forget ourselves continually, and make inferences from them as existing realities.'
author: EAP

text: With the algebraists, however, who are Pagans themselves, the 'Pagan fables' are believed, and the inferences are made, not so much through lapse of memory, as through an unaccountable addling of the brains.
author: EAP

text: In short, I never yet encountered the mere mathematician who could be trusted out of equal roots, or one who did not clandestinely hold it as a point of his faith that x squared + px was absolutely and unconditionally equal to q.
author: EAP

text: Say to one of these gentlemen, by way of experiment, if you please, that you believe occasions may occur where x squared + px is not altogether equal to q, and, having made him understand what you mean, get out of his reach as speedily as convenient, for, beyond doubt, he will endeavor to knock you down.
author: EAP

text: I mean to say," continued Dupin, while I merely laughed at his last observations, "that if the Minister had been no more than a mathematician, the Prefect would have been under no necessity of giving me this check.
author: EAP

text: I knew him, however, as both mathematician and poet, and my measures were adapted to his capacity, with reference to the circumstances by which he was surrounded.
author: EAP

text: I knew him as a courtier, too, and as a bold intriguant.
author: EAP

text: Such a man, I considered, could not fall to be aware of the ordinary policial modes of action.
author: EAP

text: He could not have failed to anticipate --and events have proved that he did not fail to anticipate --the waylayings to which he was subjected.
author: EAP

text: He must have foreseen, I reflected, the secret investigations of his premises.
author: EAP

text: His frequent absences from home at night, which were hailed by the Prefect as certain aids to his success, I regarded only as ruses, to afford opportunity for thorough search to the police, and thus the sooner to impress them with the conviction to which G--, in fact, did finally arrive --the conviction that the letter was not upon the premises.
author: EAP

text: I felt, also, that the whole train of thought, which I was at some pains in detailing to you just now, concerning the invariable principle of policial action in searches for articles concealed --I felt that this whole train of thought would necessarily pass through the mind of the Minister.
author: EAP

text: It would imperatively lead him to despise all the ordinary nooks of concealment.
author: EAP

text: He could not, I reflected, be so weak as not to see that the most intricate and remote recess of his hotel would be as open as his commonest closets to the eyes, to the probes, to the gimlets, and to the microscopes of the Prefect.
author: EAP

text: I saw, in fine, that he would be driven, as a matter of course, to simplicity, if not deliberately induced to it as a matter of choice.
author: EAP

text: You will remember, perhaps, how desperately the Prefect laughed when I suggested, upon our first interview, that it was just possible this mystery troubled him so much on account of its being so very self-evident."
author: EAP

text: "Yes," said I, "I remember his merriment well.
author: EAP

text: I really thought he would have fallen into convulsions."
author: EAP

text: "The material world," continued Dupin, "abounds with very strict analogies to the immaterial; and thus some color of truth has been given to the rhetorical dogma, that metaphor, or simile, may be made to strengthen an argument, as well as to embellish a description.
author: EAP

text: The principle of the vis inertiae, for example, seems to be identical in physics and metaphysics.
author: EAP

text: It is not more true in the former, that a large body is with more difficulty set in motion than a smaller one, and that its subsequent momentum is commensurate with this difficulty, than it is, in the latter, that intellects of the vaster capacity, while more forcible, more constant, and more eventful in their movements than those of inferior grade, are yet the less readily moved, and more embarrassed and full of hesitation in the first few steps of their progress.
author: EAP

text: Again: have you ever noticed which of the street signs, over the shop doors, are the most attractive of attention?"
author: EAP

text: "I have never given the matter a thought," I said.
author: EAP

text: "There is a game of puzzles," he resumed, "which is played upon a map.
author: EAP

text: One party playing requires another to find a given word --the name of town, river, state or empire --any word, in short, upon the motley and perplexed surface of the chart.
author: EAP

text: A novice in the game generally seeks to embarrass his opponents by giving them the most minutely lettered names; but the adept selects such words as stretch, in large characters, from one end of the chart to the other.
author: EAP

text: These, like the over-largely lettered signs and placards of the street, escape observation by dint of being excessively obvious; and here the physical oversight is precisely analogous with the moral inapprehension by which the intellect suffers to pass unnoticed those considerations which are too obtrusively and too palpably self-evident.
author: EAP

text: But this is a point, it appears, somewhat above or beneath the understanding of the Prefect.
author: EAP

text: He never once thought it probable, or possible, that the Minister had deposited the letter immediately beneath the nose of the whole world, by way of best preventing any portion of that world from perceiving it.
author: EAP

text: "But the more I reflected upon the daring, dashing, and discriminating ingenuity of D--; upon the fact that the document must always have been at hand, if he intended to use it to good purpose; and upon the decisive evidence, obtained by the Prefect, that it was not hidden within the limits of that dignitary's ordinary search --the more satisfied I became that, to conceal this letter, the Minister had resorted to the comprehensive and sagacious expedient of not attempting to conceal it at all.
author: EAP

text: "Full of these ideas, I prepared myself with a pair of green spectacles, and called one fine morning, quite by accident, at the Ministerial hotel.
author: EAP

text: I found D-- at home, yawning, lounging, and dawdling, as usual, and pretending to be in the last extremity of ennui.
author: EAP

text: He is, perhaps, the most really energetic human being now alive --but that is only when nobody sees him.
author: EAP

text: "To be even with him, I complained of my weak eyes, and lamented the necessity of the spectacles, under cover of which I cautiously and thoroughly surveyed the apartment, while seemingly intent only upon the conversation of my host.
author: EAP

text: "I paid special attention to a large writing-table near which he sat, and upon which lay confusedly, some miscellaneous letters and other papers, with one or two musical instruments and a few books.
author: EAP

text: Here, however, after a long and very deliberate scrutiny, I saw nothing to excite particular suspicion.
author: EAP

text: "At length my eyes, in going the circuit of the room, fell upon a trumpery filigree card-rack of pasteboard, that hung dangling by a dirty blue ribbon, from a little brass knob just beneath the middle of the mantelpiece.
author: EAP

text: In this rack, which had three or four compartments, were five or six visiting cards and a solitary letter.
author: EAP

text: This last was much soiled and crumpled.
author: EAP

text: It was torn nearly in two, across the middle --as if a design, in the first instance, to tear it entirely up as worthless, had been altered, or stayed, in the second.
author: EAP

text: It had a large black seal, bearing the D-- cipher very conspicuously, and was addressed, in a diminutive female hand, to D--, the minister, himself.
author: EAP

text: It was thrust carelessly, and even, as it seemed, contemptuously, into one of the upper divisions of the rack.
author: EAP

text: "No sooner had I glanced at this letter, than I concluded it to be that of which I was in search.
author: EAP

text: To be sure, it was, to all appearance, radically different from the one of which the Prefect had read us so minute a description.
author: EAP

text: Here the seal was large and black, with the D-- cipher; there it was small and red, with the ducal arms of the S-- family.
author: EAP

text: Here, the address, to the Minister, was diminutive and feminine; there the superscription, to a certain royal personage, was markedly bold and decided; the size alone formed a point of correspondence.
author: EAP

text: But, then, the radicalness of these differences, which was excessive; the dirt; the soiled and torn condition of the paper, so inconsistent with the true methodical habits of D--, and so suggestive of a design to delude the beholder into an idea of the worthlessness of the document; these things, together with the hyperobtrusive situation of this document, full in the view of every visitor, and thus exactly in accordance with the conclusions to which I had previously arrived; these things, I say, were strongly corroborative of suspicion, in one who came with the intention to suspect.
author: EAP

text: "I protracted my visit as long as possible, and, while I maintained a most animated discussion with the Minister, on a topic which I knew well had never failed to interest and excite him, I kept my attention really riveted upon the letter.
author: EAP

text: In this examination, I committed to memory its external appearance and arrangement in the rack; and also fell, at length, upon a discovery which set at rest whatever trivial doubt I might have entertained.
author: EAP

text: In scrutinizing the edges of the paper, I observed them to be more chafed than seemed necessary.
author: EAP

text: They presented the broken appearance which is manifested when a stiff paper, having been once folded and pressed with a folder, is refolded in a reversed direction, in the same creases or edges which had formed the original fold.
author: EAP

text: This discovery was sufficient.
author: EAP

text: It was clear to me that the letter had been turned, as a glove, inside out, re-directed, and re-sealed.
author: EAP

text: I bade the Minister good morning, and took my departure at once, leaving a gold snuff-box upon the table.
author: EAP

text: "The next morning I called for the snuff-box, when we resumed, quite eagerly, the conversation of the preceding day.
author: EAP

text: While thus engaged, however, a loud report, as if of a pistol, was heard immediately beneath the windows of the hotel, and was succeeded by a series of fearful screams, and the shoutings of a mob.
author: EAP

text: D-- rushed to a casement, threw it open, and looked out.
author: EAP

text: In the meantime, I stepped to the card-rack, took the letter, put it in my pocket, and replaced it by a fac-simile, (so far as regards externals,) which I had carefully prepared at my lodgings; imitating the D-- cipher, very readily, by means of a seal formed of bread.
author: EAP

text: "The disturbance in the street had been occasioned by the frantic behavior of a man with a musket.
author: EAP

text: He had fired it among a crowd of women and children.
author: EAP

text: It proved, however, to have been without ball, and the fellow was suffered to go his way as a lunatic or a drunkard.
author: EAP

text: When he had gone, D-came from the window, whither I had followed him immediately upon securing the object in view.
author: EAP

text: Soon afterwards I bade him farewell.
author: EAP

text: The pretended lunatic was a man in my own pay.
author: EAP

text: "But what purpose had you," I asked, in replacing the letter by a fac-simile?
author: EAP

text: Would it not have been better, at the first visit, to have seized it openly, and departed?"
author: EAP

text: "D--," replied Dupin, "is a desperate man, and a man of nerve.
author: EAP

text: His hotel, too, is not without attendants devoted to his interests.
author: EAP

text: Had I made the wild attempt you suggest, I might never have left the Ministerial presence alive.
author: EAP

text: The good people of Paris might have heard of me no more.
author: EAP

text: But I had an object apart from these considerations.
author: EAP

text: You know my political prepossessions.
author: EAP

text: In this matter, I act as a partisan of the lady concerned.
author: EAP

text: For eighteen months the Minister has had her in his power.
author: EAP

text: She has now him in hers; since, being unaware that the letter is not in his possession, he will proceed with his exactions as if it was.
author: EAP

text: Thus will he inevitably commit himself, at once, to his political destruction.
author: EAP

text: His downfall, too, will not be more precipitate than awkward.
author: EAP

text: It is all very well to talk about the facilis descensus Averni; but in all kinds of climbing, as Catalani said of singing, it is far more easy to get up than to come down.
author: EAP

text: In the present instance I have no sympathy --at least no pity --for him who descends.
author: EAP

text: He is the monstrum horrendum, an unprincipled man of genius.
author: EAP

text: I confess, however, that I should like very well to know the precise character of his thoughts, when, being defied by her whom the Prefect terms 'a certain personage,' he is reduced to opening the letter which I left for him in the card-rack."
author: EAP

text: did you put any thing particular in it?"
author: EAP

text: "Why --it did not seem altogether right to leave the interior blank --that would have been insulting.
author: EAP

text: D--, at Vienna once, did me an evil turn, which I told him, quite good-humoredly, that I should remember.
author: EAP

text: So, as I knew he would feel some curiosity in regard to the identity of the person who had outwitted him, I thought it a pity not to give him a clue.
author: EAP

text: He is well acquainted with my MS., and I just copied into the middle of the blank sheet the words--
author: EAP

text: I NEVER knew anyone so keenly alive to a joke as the king was.
author: EAP

text: He seemed to live only for joking.
author: EAP

text: To tell a good story of the joke kind, and to tell it well, was the surest road to his favor.
author: EAP

text: Thus it happened that his seven ministers were all noted for their accomplishments as jokers.
author: EAP

text: They all took after the king, too, in being large, corpulent, oily men, as well as inimitable jokers.
author: EAP

text: Whether people grow fat by joking, or whether there is something in fat itself which predisposes to a joke, I have never been quite able to determine; but certain it is that a lean joker is a rara avis in terris.
author: EAP

text: About the refinements, or, as he called them, the 'ghost' of wit, the king troubled himself very little.
author: EAP

text: He had an especial admiration for breadth in a jest, and would often put up with length, for the sake of it.
author: EAP

text: He would have preferred Rabelais' 'Gargantua' to the 'Zadig' of Voltaire: and, upon the whole, practical jokes suited his taste far better than verbal ones.
author: EAP

text: At the date of my narrative, professing jesters had not altogether gone out of fashion at court.
author: EAP

text: Several of the great continental 'powers' still retain their 'fools,' who wore motley, with caps and bells, and who were expected to be always ready with sharp witticisms, at a moment's notice, in consideration of the crumbs that fell from the royal table.
author: EAP

text: Our king, as a matter of course, retained his 'fool.'
author: EAP

text: The fact is, he required something in the way of folly -- if only to counterbalance the heavy wisdom of the seven wise men who were his ministers -- not to mention himself.
author: EAP

text: His fool, or professional jester, was not only a fool, however.
author: EAP

text: His value was trebled in the eyes of the king, by the fact of his being also a dwarf and a cripple.
author: EAP

text: Dwarfs were as common at court, in those days, as fools; and many monarchs would have found it difficult to get through their days (days are rather longer at court than elsewhere) without both a jester to laugh with, and a dwarf to laugh at.
author: EAP

text: But, as I have already observed, your jesters, in ninety-nine cases out of a hundred, are fat, round, and unwieldy -- so that it was no small source of self-gratulation with our king that, in Hop-Frog (this was the fool's name), he possessed a triplicate treasure in one person.
author: EAP

text: I believe the name 'Hop-Frog' was not that given to the dwarf by his sponsors at baptism, but it was conferred upon him, by general consent of the several ministers, on account of his inability to walk as other men do.
author: EAP

text: In fact, Hop-Frog could only get along by a sort of interjectional gait -- something between a leap and a wriggle -- a movement that afforded illimitable amusement, and of course consolation, to the king, for (notwithstanding the protuberance of his stomach and a constitutional swelling of the head) the king, by his whole court, was accounted a capital figure.
author: EAP

text: But although Hop-Frog, through the distortion of his legs, could move only with great pain and difficulty along a road or floor, the prodigious muscular power which nature seemed to have bestowed upon his arms, by way of compensation for deficiency in the lower limbs, enabled him to perform many feats of wonderful dexterity, where trees or ropes were in question, or any thing else to climb.
author: EAP

text: At such exercises he certainly much more resembled a squirrel, or a small monkey, than a frog.
author: EAP

text: I am not able to say, with precision, from what country Hop-Frog originally came.
author: EAP

text: It was from some barbarous region, however, that no person ever heard of -- a vast distance from the court of our king.
author: EAP

text: Hop-Frog, and a young girl very little less dwarfish than himself (although of exquisite proportions, and a marvellous dancer), had been forcibly carried off from their respective homes in adjoining provinces, and sent as presents to the king, by one of his ever-victorious generals.
author: EAP

text: Under these circumstances, it is not to be wondered at that a close intimacy arose between the two little captives.
author: EAP

text: Indeed, they soon became sworn friends.
author: EAP

text: Hop-Frog, who, although he made a great deal of sport, was by no means popular, had it not in his power to render Trippetta many services; but she, on account of her grace and exquisite beauty (although a dwarf), was universally admired and petted; so she possessed much influence; and never failed to use it, whenever she could, for the benefit of Hop-Frog.
author: EAP

text: The depth in the centre of the Moskoe-strï¿½m must be immeasurably greater ; and no better proof of this fact is necessary than can be obtained from even the sidelong glance into the abyss of the whirl which may be had from the highest crag of Helseggen.
