text: Who has not, a hundred times, found himself committing a vile or a silly action, for no other reason than because he knows he should not?
author: EAP

text: Have we not a perpetual inclination, in the teeth of our best judgment, to violate that which is Law, merely because we understand it to be such?
author: EAP

text: This spirit of perverseness, I say, came to my final overthrow.
author: EAP

text: It was this unfathomable longing of the soul to vex itself -- to offer violence to its own nature -- to do wrong for the wrong's sake only -- that urged me to continue and finally to consummate the injury I had inflicted upon the unoffending brute.
author: EAP

text: One morning, in cool blood, I slipped a noose about its neck and hung it to the limb of a tree; -- hung it with the tears streaming from my eyes, and with the bitterest remorse at my heart; -- hung it because I knew that it had loved me, and because I felt it had given me no reason of offence; -- hung it because I knew that in so doing I was committing a sin -- a deadly sin that would so jeopardize my immortal soul as to place it -- if such a thing were possible -- even beyond the reach of the infinite mercy of the Most Merciful and Most Terrible God.
author: EAP

text: On the night of the day on which this cruel deed was done, I was aroused from sleep by the cry of fire.
author: EAP

text: The curtains of my bed were in flames.
author: EAP

text: The whole house was blazing.
author: EAP

text: It was with great difficulty that my wife, a servant, and myself, made our escape from the conflagration.
author: EAP

text: The destruction was complete.
author: EAP

text: My entire worldly wealth was swallowed up, and I resigned myself thenceforward to despair.
author: EAP

text: I am above the weakness of seeking to establish a sequence of cause and effect, between the disaster and the atrocity.
author: EAP

text: But I am detailing a chain of facts -- and wish not to leave even a possible link imperfect.
author: EAP

text: On the day succeeding the fire, I visited the ruins.
author: EAP

text: The walls, with one exception, had fallen in.
author: EAP

text: This exception was found in a compartment wall, not very thick, which stood about the middle of the house, and against which had rested the head of my bed.
author: EAP

text: The plastering had here, in great measure, resisted the action of the fire -- a fact which I attributed to its having been recently spread.
author: EAP

text: About this wall a dense crowd were collected, and many persons seemed to be examining a particular portion of it with very minute and eager attention.
author: EAP

text: and other similar expressions, excited my curiosity.
author: EAP

text: I approached and saw, as if graven in bas relief upon the white surface, the figure of a gigantic cat.
author: EAP

text: The impression was given with an accuracy truly marvellous.
author: EAP

text: There was a rope about the animal's neck.
author: EAP

text: When I first beheld this apparition -- for I could scarcely regard it as less -- my wonder and my terror were extreme.
author: EAP

text: But at length reflection came to my aid.
author: EAP

text: The cat, I remembered, had been hung in a garden adjacent to the house.
author: EAP

text: Upon the alarm of fire, this garden had been immediately filled by the crowd -- by some one of whom the animal must have been cut from the tree and thrown, through an open window, into my chamber.
author: EAP

text: This had probably been done with the view of arousing me from sleep.
author: EAP

text: The falling of other walls had compressed the victim of my cruelty into the substance of the freshly-spread plaster; the lime of which, with the flames, and the ammonia from the carcass, had then accomplished the portraiture as I saw it.
author: EAP

text: Although I thus readily accounted to my reason, if not altogether to my conscience, for the startling fact just detailed, it did not the less fail to make a deep impression upon my fancy.
author: EAP

text: For months I could not rid myself of the phantasm of the cat; and, during this period, there came back into my spirit a half-sentiment that seemed, but was not, remorse.
author: EAP

text: I went so far as to regret the loss of the animal, and to look about me, among the vile haunts which I now habitually frequented, for another pet of the same species, and of somewhat similar appearance, with which to supply its place.
author: EAP

text: One night as I sat, half stupified, in a den of more than infamy, my attention was suddenly drawn to some black object, reposing upon the head of one of the immense hogsheads of Gin, or of Rum, which constituted the chief furniture of the apartment.
author: EAP

text: I had been looking steadily at the top of this hogshead for some minutes, and what now caused me surprise was the fact that I had not sooner perceived the object thereupon.
author: EAP

text: I approached it, and touched it with my hand.
author: EAP

text: It was a black cat -- a very large one -- fully as large as Pluto, and closely resembling him in every respect but one.
author: EAP

text: Pluto had not a white hair upon any portion of his body; but this cat had a large, although indefinite splotch of white, covering nearly the whole region of the breast.
author: EAP

text: Upon my touching him, he immediately arose, purred loudly, rubbed against my hand, and appeared delighted with my notice.
author: EAP

text: This, then, was the very creature of which I was in search.
author: EAP

text: I at once offered to purchase it of the landlord; but this person made no claim to it -- knew nothing of it -- had never seen it before.
author: EAP

text: I continued my caresses, and, when I prepared to go home, the animal evinced a disposition to accompany me.
author: EAP

text: I permitted it to do so; occasionally stooping and patting it as I proceeded.
author: EAP

text: When it reached the house it domesticated itself at once, and became immediately a great favorite with my wife.
author: EAP

text: For my own part, I soon found a dislike to it arising within me.
author: EAP

text: This was just the reverse of what I had anticipated; but -- I know not how or why it was -- its evident fondness for myself rather disgusted and annoyed.
author: EAP

text: By slow degrees, these feelings of disgust and annoyance rose into the bitterness of hatred.
author: EAP

text: I avoided the creature; a certain sense of shame, and the remembrance of my former deed of cruelty, preventing me from physically abusing it.
author: EAP

text: I did not, for some weeks, strike, or otherwise violently ill use it; but gradually -- very gradually -- I came to look upon it with unutterable loathing, and to flee silently from its odious presence, as from the breath of a pestilence.
author: EAP

text: What added, no doubt, to my hatred of the beast, was the discovery, on the morning after I brought it home, that, like Pluto, it also had been deprived of one of its eyes.
author: EAP

text: This circumstance, however, only endeared it to my wife, who, as I have already said, possessed, in a high degree, that humanity of feeling which had once been my distinguishing trait, and the source of many of my simplest and purest pleasures.
author: EAP

text: With my aversion to this cat, however, its partiality for myself seemed to increase.
author: EAP

text: It followed my footsteps with a pertinacity which it would be difficult to make the reader comprehend.
author: EAP

text: Whenever I sat, it would crouch beneath my chair, or spring upon my knees, covering me with its loathsome caresses.
author: EAP

text: If I arose to walk it would get between my feet and thus nearly throw me down, or, fastening its long and sharp claws in my dress, clamber, in this manner, to my breast.
author: EAP

text: At such times, although I longed to destroy it with a blow, I was yet withheld from so doing, partly by a memory of my former crime, but chiefly -- let me confess it at once -- by absolute dread of the beast.
author: EAP

text: This dread was not exactly a dread of physical evil -- and yet I should be at a loss how otherwise to define it.
author: EAP

text: I am almost ashamed to own -- yes, even in this felon's cell, I am almost ashamed to own -- that the terror and horror with which the animal inspired me, had been heightened by one of the merest chimï¿½ras it would be possible to conceive.
author: EAP

text: My wife had called my attention, more than once, to the character of the mark of white hair, of which I have spoken, and which constituted the sole visible difference between the strange beast and the one I had destroyed.
author: EAP

text: The reader will remember that this mark, although large, had been originally very indefinite; but, by slow degrees -- degrees nearly imperceptible, and which for a long time my Reason struggled to reject as fanciful -- it had, at length, assumed a rigorous distinctness of outline.
author: EAP

text: It was now the representation of an object that I shudder to name -- and for this, above all, I loathed, and dreaded, and would have rid myself of the monster had I dared -- it was now, I say, the image of a hideous -- of a ghastly thing -- of the GALLOWS !
author: EAP

text: -- oh, mournful and terrible engine of Horror and of Crime -- of Agony and of Death !
author: EAP

text: And now was I indeed wretched beyond the wretchedness of mere Humanity.
author: EAP

text: And a brute beast -- whose fellow I had contemptuously destroyed -- a brute beast to work out for me -- for me a man, fashioned in the image of the High God -- so much of insufferable wo!
author: EAP

text: neither by day nor by night knew I the blessing of Rest any more!
author: EAP

text: During the former the creature left me no moment alone; and, in the latter, I started, hourly, from dreams of unutterable fear, to find the hot breath of the thing upon my face, and its vast weight -- an incarnate Night-Mare that I had no power to shake off -- incumbent eternally upon my heart !
author: EAP

text: Beneath the pressure of torments such as these, the feeble remnant of the good within me succumbed.
author: EAP

text: Evil thoughts became my sole intimates -- the darkest and most evil of thoughts.
author: EAP

text: The moodiness of my usual temper increased to hatred of all things and of all mankind; while, from the sudden, frequent, and ungovernable outbursts of a fury to which I now blindly abandoned myself, my uncomplaining wife, alas!
author: EAP

text: was the most usual and the most patient of sufferers.
author: EAP

text: One day she accompanied me, upon some household errand, into the cellar of the old building which our poverty compelled us to inhabit.
author: EAP

text: The cat followed me down the steep stairs, and, nearly throwing me headlong, exasperated me to madness.
author: EAP

text: Uplifting an axe, and forgetting, in my wrath, the childish dread which had hitherto stayed my hand, I aimed a blow at the animal which, of course, would have proved instantly fatal had it descended as I wished.
author: EAP

text: But this blow was arrested by the hand of my wife.
author: EAP

text: Goaded, by the interference, into a rage more than demoniacal, I withdrew my arm from her grasp and buried the axe in her brain.
author: EAP

text: She fell dead upon the spot, without a groan.
author: EAP

text: This hideous murder accomplished, I set myself forthwith, and with entire deliberation, to the task of concealing the body.
author: EAP

text: I knew that I could not remove it from the house, either by day or by night, without the risk of being observed by the neighbors.
author: EAP

text: Many projects entered my mind.
author: EAP

text: At one period I thought of cutting the corpse into minute fragments, and destroying them by fire.
author: EAP

text: At another, I resolved to dig a grave for it in the floor of the cellar.
author: EAP

text: Again, I deliberated about casting it in the well in the yard -- about packing it in a box, as if merchandize, with the usual arrangements, and so getting a porter to take it from the house.
author: EAP

text: Finally I hit upon what I considered a far better expedient than either of these.
author: EAP

text: I determined to wall it up in the cellar -- as the monks of the middle ages are recorded to have walled up their victims.
author: EAP

text: For a purpose such as this the cellar was well adapted.
author: EAP

text: Its walls were loosely constructed, and had lately been plastered throughout with a rough plaster, which the dampness of the atmosphere had prevented from hardening.
author: EAP

text: Moreover, in one of the walls was a projection, caused by a false chimney, or fireplace, that had been filled up, and made to resemble the rest of the cellar.
author: EAP

text: I made no doubt that I could readily displace the bricks at this point, insert the corpse, and wall the whole up as before, so that no eye could detect any thing suspicious.
author: EAP

text: And in this calculation I was not deceived.
author: EAP

text: By means of a crow-bar I easily dislodged the bricks, and, having carefully deposited the body against the inner wall, I propped it in that position, while, with little trouble, I re-laid the whole structure as it originally stood.
author: EAP

text: Having procured mortar, sand, and hair, with every possible precaution, I prepared a plaster which could not be distinguished from the old, and with this I very carefully went over the new brick-work.
author: EAP

text: When I had finished, I felt satisfied that all was right.
author: EAP

text: The wall did not present the slightest appearance of having been disturbed.
author: EAP

text: The rubbish on the floor was picked up with the minutest care.
author: EAP

text: I looked around triumphantly, and said to myself -- "Here at least, then, my labor has not been in vain."
author: EAP

text: My next step was to look for the beast which had been the cause of so much wretchedness; for I had, at length, firmly resolved to put it to death.
author: EAP

text: Had I been able to meet with it, at the moment, there could have been no doubt of its fate; but it appeared that the crafty animal had been alarmed at the violence of my previous anger, and forebore to present itself in my present mood.
author: EAP

text: It is impossible to describe, or to imagine, the deep, the blissful sense of relief which the absence of the detested creature occasioned in my bosom.
author: EAP

text: It did not make its appearance during the night -- and thus for one night at least, since its introduction into the house, I soundly and tranquilly slept; aye, slept even with the burden of murder upon my soul!
author: EAP

text: The second and the third day passed, and still my tormentor came not.
author: EAP

text: Once again I breathed as a freeman.
author: EAP

text: The monster, in terror, had fled the premises forever!
author: EAP

text: I should behold it no more!
author: EAP

text: My happiness was supreme!
author: EAP

text: The guilt of my dark deed disturbed me but little.
author: EAP

text: Some few inquiries had been made, but these had been readily answered.
author: EAP

text: Even a search had been instituted -- but of course nothing was to be discovered.
author: EAP

text: I looked upon my future felicity as secured.
author: EAP

text: Upon the fourth day of the assassination, a party of the police came, very unexpectedly, into the house, and proceeded again to make rigorous investigation of the premises.
author: EAP

text: Secure, however, in the inscrutability of my place of concealment, I felt no embarrassment whatever.
author: EAP

text: The officers bade me accompany them in their search.
author: EAP

text: They left no nook or corner unexplored.
author: EAP

text: At length, for the third or fourth time, they descended into the cellar.
author: EAP

text: I quivered not in a muscle.
author: EAP

text: My heart beat calmly as that of one who slumbers in innocence.
author: EAP

text: I walked the cellar from end to end.
author: EAP

text: I folded my arms upon my bosom, and roamed easily to and fro.
author: EAP

text: The police were thoroughly satisfied and prepared to depart.
author: EAP

text: The glee at my heart was too strong to be restrained.
author: EAP

text: I burned to say if but one word, by way of triumph, and to render doubly sure their assurance of my guiltlessness.
author: EAP

text: "Gentlemen," I said at last, as the party ascended the steps, "I delight to have allayed your suspicions.
author: EAP

text: I wish you all health, and a little more courtesy.
author: EAP

text: By the bye, gentlemen, this -- this is a very well constructed house."
author: EAP

text: (In the rabid desire to say something easily, I scarcely knew what I uttered at all.)
author: EAP

text: -- "I may say an excellently well constructed house.
author: EAP

text: These walls -- are you going, gentlemen?
author: EAP

text: -- these walls are solidly put together;" and here, through the mere phrenzy of bravado, I rapped heavily, with a cane which I held in my hand, upon that very portion of the brick-work behind which stood the corpse of the wife of my bosom.
author: EAP

text: But may God shield and deliver me from the fangs of the Arch-Fiend !
author: EAP

text: No sooner had the reverberation of my blows sunk into silence, than I was answered by a voice from within the tomb!
author: EAP

text: -- by a cry, at first muffled and broken, like the sobbing of a child, and then quickly swelling into one long, loud, and continuous scream, utterly anomalous and inhuman -- a howl -- a wailing shriek, half of horror and half of triumph, such as might have arisen only out of hell, conjointly from the throats of the dammed in their agony and of the demons that exult in the damnation.
author: EAP

text: Of my own thoughts it is folly to speak.
author: EAP

text: Swooning, I staggered to the opposite wall.
author: EAP

text: For one instant the party upon the stairs remained motionless, through extremity of terror and of awe.
author: EAP

text: In the next, a dozen stout arms were toiling at the wall.
author: EAP

text: The corpse, already greatly decayed and clotted with gore, stood erect before the eyes of the spectators.
author: EAP

text: Upon its head, with red extended mouth and solitary eye of fire, sat the hideous beast whose craft had seduced me into murder, and whose informing voice had consigned me to the hangman.
author: EAP

text: I had walled the monster up within the tomb!
author: EAP

text: Of course I shall not pretend to consider it any matter for wonder, that the extraordinary case of M. Valdemar has excited discussion.
author: EAP

text: It would have been a miracle had it not -- especially under the circumstances.
author: EAP

text: Through the desire of all parties concerned, to keep the affair from the public, at least for the present, or until we had farther opportunities for investigation -- through our endeavors to effect this -- a garbled or exaggerated account made its way into society, and became the source of many unpleasant misrepresentations; and, very naturally, of a great deal of disbelief.
author: EAP

text: It is now rendered necessary that I give the facts -- as far as I comprehend them myself.
author: EAP

text: They are, succinctly, these: My attention, for the last three years, had been repeatedly drawn to the subject of Mesmerism; and, about nine months ago, it occurred to me, quite suddenly, that in the series of experiments made hitherto, there had been a very remarkable and most unaccountable omission: no person had as yet been mesmerized in articulo mortis.
author: EAP

text: It remained to be seen, first, whether, in such condition, there existed in the patient any susceptibility to the magnetic influence; secondly, whether, if any existed, it was impaired or increased by the condition; thirdly, to what extent, or for how long a period, the encroachments of Death might be arrested by the process.
author: EAP

text: There were other points to be ascertained, but these most excited my curiosity -- the last in especial, from the immensely important character of its consequences.
author: EAP

text: In looking around me for some subject by whose means I might test these particulars, I was brought to think of my friend, M. Ernest Valdemar, the well-known compiler of the "Bibliotheca Forensica," and author (under the nom de plume of Issachar Marx) of the Polish versions of "Wallenstein" and "Gargantua."
author: EAP

text: M. Valdemar, who has resided principally at Harlem, N. Y., since the year 1839, is (or was) particularly noticeable for the extreme spareness of his person -- his lower limbs much resembling those of John Randolph; and, also, for the whiteness of his whiskers, in violent contrast to the blackness of his hair -- the latter, in consequence, being very generally mistaken for a wig.
author: EAP

text: His temperament was markedly nervous, and rendered him a good subject for mesmeric experiment.
author: EAP

text: On two or three occasions I had put him to sleep with little difficulty, but was disappointed in other results which his peculiar constitution had naturally led me to anticipate.
author: EAP

text: His will was at no period positively, or thoroughly, under my control, and in regard to clairvoyance, I could accomplish with him nothing to be relied upon.
author: EAP

text: I always attributed my failure at these points to the disordered state of his health.
author: EAP

text: For some months previous to my becoming acquainted with him, his physicians had declared him in a confirmed phthisis.
author: EAP

text: It was his custom, indeed, to speak calmly of his approaching dissolution, as of a matter neither to be avoided nor regretted.
author: EAP

text: When the ideas to which I have alluded first occurred to me, it was of course very natural that I should think of M. Valdemar.
author: EAP

text: I knew the steady philosophy of the man too well to apprehend any scruples from him; and he had no relatives in America who would be likely to interfere.
author: EAP

text: I spoke to him frankly upon the subject; and, to my surprise, his interest seemed vividly excited.
author: EAP

text: I say to my surprise; for, although he had always yielded his person freely to my experiments, he had never before given me any tokens of sympathy with what I did.
author: EAP

text: His disease was of that character which would admit of exact calculation in respect to the epoch of its termination in death; and it was finally arranged between us that he would send for me about twenty-four hours before the period announced by his physicians as that of his decease.
author: EAP

text: It is now rather more than seven months since I received, from M. Valdemar himself, the subjoined note: "MY DEAR P___, You may as well come now.
author: EAP

text: D___ and F___ are agreed that I cannot hold out beyond to-morrow midnight; and I think they have hit the time very nearly.
author: EAP

text: I received this note within half an hour after it was written, and in fifteen minutes more I was in the dying man's chamber.
author: EAP

text: I had not seen him for ten days, and was appalled by the fearful alteration which the brief interval had wrought in him.
author: EAP

text: His face wore a leaden hue; the eyes were utterly lustreless; and the emaciation was so extreme, that the skin had been broken through by the cheek-bones.
author: EAP

text: His expectoration was excessive.
author: EAP

text: The pulse was barely perceptible.
author: EAP

text: He retained, nevertheless, in a very remarkable manner, both his mental power and a certain degree of physical strength.
author: EAP

text: He spoke with distinctness -- took some palliative medicines without aid -- and, when I entered the room, was occupied in penciling memoranda in a pocket-book.
author: EAP

text: He was propped up in the bed by pillows.
author: EAP

text: Doctors D___ and F___ were in attendance.
author: EAP

text: After pressing Valdemar's hand, I took these gentlemen aside, and obtained from them a minute account of the patient's condition.
author: EAP

text: The left lung had been for eighteen months in a semi-osseous or cartilaginous state, and was, of course, entirely useless for all purposes of vitality.
author: EAP

text: The right, in its upper portion, was also partially, if not thoroughly, ossified, while the lower region was merely a mass of purulent tubercles, running one into another.
author: EAP

text: Several extensive perforations existed; and, at one point, permanent adhesion to the ribs had taken place.
author: EAP

text: These appearances in the right lobe were of comparatively recent date.
author: EAP

text: The ossification had proceeded with very unusual rapidity; no sign of it had discovered a month before, and the adhesion had only been observed during the three previous days.
author: EAP

text: Independently of the phthisis, the patient was suspected of aneurism of the aorta; but on this point the osseous symptoms rendered an exact diagnosis impossible.
author: EAP

text: It was the opinion of both physicians that M. Valdemar would die about midnight on the morrow (Sunday.)
author: EAP

text: It was then seven o'clock on Saturday evening.
author: EAP

text: On quitting the invalid's bed-side to hold conversation with myself, Doctors D___ and F___ had bidden him a final farewell.
author: EAP

text: It had not been their intention to return; but, at my request, they agreed to look in upon the patient about ten the next night.
author: EAP

text: When they had gone, I spoke freely with M. Valdemar on the subject of his approaching dissolution, as well as, more particularly, of the experiment proposed.
author: EAP

text: He still professed himself quite willing and even anxious to have it made, and urged me to commence it at once.
author: EAP

text: A male and a female nurse were in attendance; but I did not feel myself altogether at liberty to engage in a task of this character with no more reliable witnesses than these people, in case of sudden accident, might prove.
author: EAP

text: I therefore postponed operations until about eight the next night, when the arrival of a medical student, with whom I had some acquaintance, (Mr. Theodore L___l,) relieved me from farther embarrassment.
author: EAP

text: It had been my design, originally, to wait for the physicians; but I was induced to proceed, first, by the urgent entreaties of M. Valdemar, and secondly, by my conviction that I had not a moment to lose, as he was evidently sinking fast.
author: EAP

text: Mr. L___l was so kind as to accede to my desire that he would take notes of all that occurred; and it is from his memoranda that what I now have to relate is, for the most part, either condensed or copied verbatim.
author: EAP

text: It wanted about five minutes of eight when, taking the patient's hand, I begged him to state, as distinctly as he could, to Mr. L___l, whether he (M. Valdemar,) was entirely willing that I should make the experiment of mesmerizing him in his then condition.
author: EAP

text: He replied feebly, yet quite audibly, "Yes, I wish to be mesmerized" -- adding immediately afterwards, "I fear you have deferred it too long."
author: EAP

text: While he spoke thus, I commenced the passes which I had already found most effectual in subduing him.
author: EAP

text: He was evidently influenced with the first lateral stroke of my hand across his forehead; but although I exerted all my powers, no farther perceptible effect was induced until some minutes after ten o'clock, when Doctors D___ and F___ called, according to appointment.
author: EAP

text: I explained to them, in a few words, what I designed, and as they opposed no objection, saying that the patient was already in the death agony, I proceeded without hesitation -- exchanging, however, the lateral passes for downward ones, and directing my gaze entirely into the right eye of the sufferer.
author: EAP

text: By this time his pulse was imperceptible and his breathing was stertorous, and at intervals of half a minute.
author: EAP

text: This condition was nearly unaltered for a quarter of an hour.
author: EAP

text: At the expiration of this period, however, a natural although a very deep sigh escaped the bosom of the dying man, and the stertorous breathing ceased -- that is to say, its stertorousness was no longer apparent; the intervals were undiminished.
author: EAP

text: The patient's extremities were of an icy coldness.
author: EAP

text: At five minutes before eleven, I perceived unequivocal signs of the mesmeric influence.
author: EAP

text: The glassy roll of the eye was changed for that expression of uneasy inward examination which is never seen except in cases of sleep-waking, and which it is quite impossible to mistake.
author: EAP

text: With a few rapid lateral passes I made the lids quiver, as in incipient sleep, and with a few more I closed them altogether.
author: EAP

text: I was not satisfied, however, with this, but continued the manipulations vigorously, and with the fullest exertion of the will, until I had completely stiffened the limbs of the slumberer, after placing them in a seemingly easy position.
author: EAP

text: The legs were at full length; the arms were nearly so, and reposed on the bed at a moderate distance from the loins.
author: EAP

text: The head was very slightly elevated.
author: EAP

text: When I had accomplished this, it was fully midnight, and I requested the gentlemen present to examine M. Valdemar's condition.
author: EAP

text: After a few experiments, they admitted him to be in an unusually perfect state of mesmeric trance.
author: EAP

text: The curiosity of both the physicians was greatly excited.
author: EAP

text: Dr. D___ resolved at once to remain with the patient all night, while Dr. F___ took leave with a promise to return at daybreak.
author: EAP

text: Mr. L___l and the nurses remained.
author: EAP

text: We left M. Valdemar entirely undisturbed until about three o'clock in the morning, when I approached him and found him in precisely the same condition as when Dr. F___ went away -- that is to say, he lay in the same position; the pulse was imperceptible; the breathing was gentle (scarcely noticeable, unless through the application of a mirror to the lips;) the eyes were closed naturally; and the limbs were as rigid and as cold as marble.
author: EAP

text: Still, the general appearance was certainly not that of death.
author: EAP

text: As I approached M. Valdemar I made a kind of half effort to influence his right arm into pursuit of my own, as I passed the latter gently to and fro above his person.
author: EAP

text: In such experiments with this patient, I had never perfectly succeeded before, and assuredly I had little thought of succeeding now; but to my astonishment, his arm very readily, although feebly, followed every direction I assigned it with mine.
author: EAP

text: I determined to hazard a few words of conversation.
author: EAP

text: "M. Valdemar," I said, "are you asleep?"
author: EAP

text: He made no answer, but I perceived a tremor about the lips, and was thus induced to repeat the question, again and again.
author: EAP

text: At its third repetition, his whole frame was agitated by a very slight shivering; the eye-lids unclosed themselves so far as to display a white line of a ball; the lips moved sluggishly, and from between them, in a barely audible whisper, issued the words: "Yes; asleep now.
author: EAP

text: Do not wake me!
author: EAP

text: -- let me die so!"
author: EAP

text: I here felt the limbs and found them as rigid as ever.
author: EAP

text: The right arm, as before, obeyed the direction of my hand.
author: EAP

text: I questioned the sleep-waker again: "Do you still feel pain in the breast, M.
author: EAP

text: The answer now was immediate, but even less audible than before: "No pain -- I am dying."
author: EAP

text: I did not think it advisable to disturb him farther just then, and nothing more was said or done until the arrival of Dr. F___, who came a little before sunrise, and expressed unbounded astonishment at finding the patient still alive.
author: EAP

text: After feeling the pulse and applying a mirror to the lips, he requested me to speak to the sleep-waker again.
author: EAP

text: I did so, saying: "M. Valdemar, do you still sleep?"
author: EAP

text: As before, some minutes elapsed ere a reply was made; and during the interval the dying man seemed to be collecting his energies to speak.
author: EAP

text: At my fourth repetition of the question, he said very faintly, almost inaudibly: "Yes; still asleep -- dying."
author: EAP

text: It was now the opinion, or rather the wish, of the physicians, that M. Valdemar should be suffered to remain undisturbed in his present apparently tranquil condition, until death should supervene -- and this, it was generally agreed, must now take place within a few minutes.
author: EAP

text: I concluded, however, to speak to him once more, and merely repeated my previous question.
author: EAP

text: While I spoke, there came a marked change over the countenance of the sleep-waker.
author: EAP

text: The eyes rolled themselves slowly open, the pupils disappearing upwardly; the skin generally assumed a cadaverous hue, resembling not so much parchment as white paper; and the circular hectic spots which, hitherto, had been strongly defined in the centre of each cheek, went out at once.
author: EAP

text: I use this expression, because the suddenness of their departure put me in mind of nothing so much as the extinguishment of a candle by a puff of the breath.
author: EAP

text: The upper lip, at the same time, writhed itself away from the teeth, which it had previously covered completely; while the lower jaw fell with an audible jerk, leaving the mouth widely extended, and disclosing in full view the swollen and blackened tongue.
author: EAP

text: I presume that no member of the party then present had been unaccustomed to death-bed horrors; but so hideous beyond conception was the appearance of M. Valdemar at this moment, that there was a general shrinking back from the region of the bed.
author: EAP

text: I now feel that I have reached a point of this narrative at which every reader will be startled into positive disbelief.
author: EAP

text: It is my business, however, simply to proceed.
author: EAP

text: There was no longer the faintest sign of vitality in M. Valdemar; and concluding him to be dead, we were consigning him to the charge of the nurses, when a strong vibratory motion was observable in the tongue.
author: EAP

text: This continued for perhaps a minute.
author: EAP

text: At the expiration of this period, there issued from the distended and motionless jaws a voice -- such as it would be madness in me to attempt describing.
author: EAP

text: There are, indeed, two or three epithets which might be considered as applicable to it in part; I might say, for example, that the sound was harsh, and broken and hollow; but the hideous whole is indescribable, for the simple reason that no similar sounds have ever jarred upon the ear of humanity.
author: EAP

text: There were two particulars, nevertheless, which I thought then, and still think, might fairly be stated as characteristic of the intonation -- as well adapted to convey some idea of its unearthly peculiarity.
author: EAP

text: In the first place, the voice seemed to reach our ears -- at least mine -- from a vast distance, or from some deep cavern within the earth.
author: EAP

text: In the second place, it impressed me (I fear, indeed, that it will be impossible to make myself comprehended) as gelatinous or glutinous matters impress the sense of touch.
author: EAP

text: I have spoken both of "sound" and of "voice."
author: EAP

text: I mean to say that the sound was one of distinct -- of even wonderfully, thrillingly distinct -- syllabification.
author: EAP

text: M. Valdemar spoke -- obviously in reply to the question I had propounded to him a few minutes before.
author: EAP

text: I had asked him, it will be remembered, if he still slept.
author: EAP

text: He now said: "Yes; -- no; -- I have been sleeping -- and now -- now -- I am dead.
author: EAP

text: No person present even affected to deny, or attempted to repress, the unutterable, shuddering horror which these few words, thus uttered, were so well calculated to convey.
author: EAP

text: Mr. L___l (the student) swooned.
author: EAP

text: The nurses immediately left the chamber, and could not be induced to return.
author: EAP

text: My own impressions I would not pretend to render intelligible to the reader.
author: EAP

text: For nearly an hour, we busied ourselves, silently -- without the utterance of a word -- in endeavors to revive Mr. L___l.
author: EAP

text: When he came to himself, we addressed ourselves again to an investigation of M. Valdemar's condition.
author: EAP

text: It remained in all respects as I have last described it, with the exception that the mirror no longer afforded evidence of respiration.
author: EAP

text: An attempt to draw blood from the arm failed.
author: EAP

text: I should mention, too, that this limb was no farther subject to my will.
author: EAP

text: I endeavored in vain to make it follow the direction of my hand.
author: EAP

text: The only real indication, indeed, of the mesmeric influence, was now found in the vibratory movement of the tongue, whenever I addressed M. Valdemar a question.
author: EAP

text: He seemed to be making an effort to reply, but had no longer sufficient volition.
author: EAP

text: To queries put to him by any other person than myself he seemed utterly insensible -- although I endeavored to place each member of the company in mesmeric rapport with him.
author: EAP

text: I believe that I have now related all that is necessary to an understanding of the sleep-waker's state at this epoch.
author: EAP

text: Other nurses were procured; and at ten o'clock I left the house in company with the two physicians and Mr. L___l.
author: EAP

text: In the afternoon we all called again to see the patient.
author: EAP

text: His condition remained precisely the same.
author: EAP

text: We had now some discussion as to the propriety and feasibility of awakening him; but we had little difficulty in agreeing that no good purpose would be served by so doing.
author: EAP

text: It was evident that, so far, death (or what is usually termed death) had been arrested by the mesmeric process.
author: EAP

text: It seemed clear to us all that to awaken M. Valdemar would be merely to insure his instant, or at least his speedy dissolution.
author: EAP

text: From this period until the close of last week -- an interval of nearly seven months -- we continued to make daily calls at M. Valdemar's house, accompanied, now and then, by medical and other friends.
author: EAP

text: All this time the sleeper-waker remained exactly as I have last described him.
author: EAP

text: The nurses' attentions were continual.
author: EAP

text: It was on Friday last that we finally resolved to make the experiment of awakening, or attempting to awaken him; and it is the (perhaps) unfortunate result of this latter experiment which has given rise to so much discussion in private circles -- to so much of what I cannot help thinking unwarranted popular feeling.
author: EAP

text: For the purpose of relieving M. Valdemar from the mesmeric trance, I made use of the customary passes.
author: EAP

text: These, for a time, were unsuccessful.
author: EAP

text: The first indication of revival was afforded by a partial descent of the iris.
author: EAP

text: It was observed, as especially remarkable, that this lowering of the pupil was accompanied by the profuse out-flowing of a yellowish ichor (from beneath the lids) of a pungent and highly offensive odor.
author: EAP

text: It was now suggested that I should attempt to influence the patient's arm, as heretofore.
author: EAP

text: I made the attempt and failed.
author: EAP

text: Dr. F___ then intimated a desire to have me put a question.
author: EAP

text: I did so, as follows: "M. Valdemar, can you explain to us what are your feelings or wishes now?"
author: EAP

text: There was an instant return of the hectic circles on the cheeks; the tongue quivered, or rather rolled violently in the mouth (although the jaws and lips remained rigid as before;) and at length the same hideous voice which I have already described, broke forth: "For God's sake!
author: EAP

text: -- put me to sleep -- or, quick!
author: EAP

text: -- I say to you that I am dead!"
author: EAP

text: I was thoroughly unnerved, and for an instant remained undecided what to do.
author: EAP

text: At first I made an endeavor to re-compose the patient; but, failing in this through total abeyance of the will, I retraced my steps and as earnestly struggled to awaken him.
author: EAP

text: In this attempt I soon saw that I should be successful -- or at least I soon fancied that my success would be complete -- and I am sure that all in the room were prepared to see the patient awaken.
author: EAP

text: For what really occurred, however, it is quite impossible that any human being could have been prepared.
author: EAP

text: As I rapidly made the mesmeric passes, amid ejaculations of "dead!
author: EAP

text: absolutely bursting from the tongue and not from the lips of the sufferer, his whole frame at once -- within the space of a single minute, or even less, shrunk -- crumbled -- absolutely rotted away beneath my hands.
author: EAP

text: Upon the bed, before that whole company, there lay a nearly liquid mass of loathsome -- of detestable putridity.
author: EAP
